text: Patch Set 5:> (5 comments) >  > Starts to look good. Confirm you have tested it and it works well > now?Not perfect yet. It works well for a pre-defined table created with direct sql like:CREATE TABLE "myTable" ("id" INTEGER NOT NULL,"decNumber" DECIMAL(9,3), PRIMARY KEY  ("id"))But in the Table Design GUI I still cannot change the field properties "Decimal places" and "Length". The sql statement generated after creating a table with a decimal in it looks like:CREATE TABLE "myTable" ("id" INTEGER NOT NULL,"decNum" DECIMAL, PRIMARY KEY  ("id"))So (precision, scale) part is missing. I think this part is missing in Tables::createStandardColumnPart, and I can fix it.But I still don't know why are the property fields not editable. There may be some settings somewhere to enable it, and I could query those numbers through PROPERTY_ID_SCALE and PROPERTY_ID_PRECISION...
Text: Patch Set 5:> (5 comments) >  > Starts to look good. Confirm you have tested it and it works well > now?Not perfect yet. It works well for a pre-defined table created with direct sql like:CREATE TABLE "myTable" ("id" INTEGER NOT NULL,"decNumber" DECIMAL(9,3), PRIMARY KEY  ("id"))But in the Table Design GUI I still cannot change the field properties "Decimal places" and "Length". The sql statement generated after creating a table with a decimal in it looks like:CREATE TABLE "myTable" ("id" INTEGER NOT NULL,"decNum" DECIMAL, PRIMARY KEY  ("id"))So (precision, scale) part is missing. I think this part is missing in Tables::createStandardColumnPart, and I can fix it.But I still don't know why are the property fields not editable. There may be some settings somewhere to enable it, and I could query those numbers through PROPERTY_ID_SCALE and PROPERTY_ID_PRECISION...

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1Although a big change, I think it is safe. Only documents created outside of LibreOffice should currently be able to create document like this.  Plus, the ODF spec says it should be honoured anyway, if it is defined.The downside is that now the document will display properly, but if someone tries to edit those settings (and perhaps only GO to any format dialog, and then hit OK instead of cancel), the layout will reset to zero padding. Basically, we get read-only compatibility in 5.3, where before we had no compatibility at all.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1Although a big change, I think it is safe. Only documents created outside of LibreOffice should currently be able to create document like this.  Plus, the ODF spec says it should be honoured anyway, if it is defined.The downside is that now the document will display properly, but if someone tries to edit those settings (and perhaps only GO to any format dialog, and then hit OK instead of cancel), the layout will reset to zero padding. Basically, we get read-only compatibility in 5.3, where before we had no compatibility at all.

text: Patch Set 2:This I don't understand.A new document with LOGNORMDIST(a)LOGNORMDIST(a,b)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)is saved as ods asLOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)and saved as xlsx asLOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d), just as I intended.Opening these saved documents with Excel produces for the ods:LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)and for the xlsx:LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)which IMHO shows that the conversions done by Calc are OK and that Excel cannot handle ODF documents well.Could you explain what is not good yet with this patch set?To me the backward compatibility for LOGNORMDIST within Calc is preserved (concerning the now optional last 3 arguments) and the interoperability with Excel is taken care of.
Text: Patch Set 2:This I don't understand.A new document with LOGNORMDIST(a)LOGNORMDIST(a,b)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)is saved as ods asLOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)and saved as xlsx asLOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d), just as I intended.Opening these saved documents with Excel produces for the ods:LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)LOGNORM.DIST(a,b,c,d)and for the xlsx:LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c)LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d)which IMHO shows that the conversions done by Calc are OK and that Excel cannot handle ODF documents well.Could you explain what is not good yet with this patch set?To me the backward compatibility for LOGNORMDIST within Calc is preserved (concerning the now optional last 3 arguments) and the interoperability with Excel is taken care of.

text: Patch Set 1:* If you feel that a bugzilla issue would be useful to add more information, then by all means create one.* I wouldn't split this into two changes; it's easier to understand new functionality together with a use case of it, so I'd (almost) always combine in a single change the newly introduced functionality with the use case that motivated its introduction.
Text: Patch Set 1:* If you feel that a bugzilla issue would be useful to add more information, then by all means create one.* I wouldn't split this into two changes; it's easier to understand new functionality together with a use case of it, so I'd (almost) always combine in a single change the newly introduced functionality with the use case that motivated its introduction.

text: Patch Set 1:Module sd is curious in that it's source is split into sd/source/core/ and sd/source/ui/, yet much of sd/source/ui/ is actually included in the core sd/Library_sd.mk, not the UI sd/Library_sdui.mk.  That means that .cxx from sd/source/core/ routinely include .hxx from sd/source/ui/inc/.  I'm not sure what the best overall fix is for that, maybe it asks for a reorganization of the the files?  Thorsten or Armin may have an opinion.  (And if nobody has a good opinion, it's probably fine to include this as-is, as the sd/soruce/ui/inc/ include directory is apparently already made visible when compiling sd/source/core/.)
Text: Patch Set 1:Module sd is curious in that it's source is split into sd/source/core/ and sd/source/ui/, yet much of sd/source/ui/ is actually included in the core sd/Library_sd.mk, not the UI sd/Library_sdui.mk.  That means that .cxx from sd/source/core/ routinely include .hxx from sd/source/ui/inc/.  I'm not sure what the best overall fix is for that, maybe it asks for a reorganization of the the files?  Thorsten or Armin may have an opinion.  (And if nobody has a good opinion, it's probably fine to include this as-is, as the sd/soruce/ui/inc/ include directory is apparently already made visible when compiling sd/source/core/.)

text: Patch Set 1:> I'm not sure what > the best overall fix is for that, maybe it asks for a > reorganization of the the files?  Thorsten or Armin may have an > opinion.  (And if nobody has a good opinion, it's probably fine to > include this as-is, as the sd/soruce/ui/inc/ include directory is > apparently already made visible when compiling sd/source/core/.)Yes, this change is useful regardless - a reorg sounds good, and getting rid of relative include paths even helps with that.
Text: Patch Set 1:> I'm not sure what > the best overall fix is for that, maybe it asks for a > reorganization of the the files?  Thorsten or Armin may have an > opinion.  (And if nobody has a good opinion, it's probably fine to > include this as-is, as the sd/soruce/ui/inc/ include directory is > apparently already made visible when compiling sd/source/core/.)Yes, this change is useful regardless - a reorg sounds good, and getting rid of relative include paths even helps with that.

text: Patch Set 5:(2 comments)So I'm not going to remove my -2 from this patch, until this is implemented better from the architecture POV.Suggested implementation would contain a struct or class holding pointers to the buttons and some operations on them, such as i) pressing buttons on/off ii) making sure only one buttons is pressed at time iii) containing some mapping of buttons (pointers to them respectively) and pointers to functions to call when the button is pressed See for example sc/source/ui/cctrl/checklistmenu.cxx, ScTabStops therein is example of such structureHaving 5+ if-else's to controlling the workflow is simply not acceptable (well, maybe it is in some freshman university C++ introductory course, but not here)
Text: Patch Set 5:(2 comments)So I'm not going to remove my -2 from this patch, until this is implemented better from the architecture POV.Suggested implementation would contain a struct or class holding pointers to the buttons and some operations on them, such as i) pressing buttons on/off ii) making sure only one buttons is pressed at time iii) containing some mapping of buttons (pointers to them respectively) and pointers to functions to call when the button is pressed See for example sc/source/ui/cctrl/checklistmenu.cxx, ScTabStops therein is example of such structureHaving 5+ if-else's to controlling the workflow is simply not acceptable (well, maybe it is in some freshman university C++ introductory course, but not here)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Your patch is basically right. But note that this is introducing new feature,because so far '%' is a reserved keyword only to mark up line comments (started with "%%")and to encode greek symbols such as %alpha. And a single '%' is an empty token.Now we are making a single '%' represent itself. I would like to see- fix calculation of m_aCurToken.nCol at line 660 in case of a single '%', and- a unit test.Thanks.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Your patch is basically right. But note that this is introducing new feature,because so far '%' is a reserved keyword only to mark up line comments (started with "%%")and to encode greek symbols such as %alpha. And a single '%' is an empty token.Now we are making a single '%' represent itself. I would like to see- fix calculation of m_aCurToken.nCol at line 660 in case of a single '%', and- a unit test.Thanks.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Sorry, I had mistaken but the original calculation of m_aCurToken.nCol is OKeven in case of single %. text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1I could have put the SetMustRepaint here or in editview.cxx void EditView::InsertText(...)It seems a bit scary that this is needed in either place.  This is high-traffic area isn't it - with lots of different areas of the programming calling the InsertText function?  Why is this omission not showing up in other places?  Anyway, it seems like a safe enough change, and the current impedit2 already had the pPortion variable defined.  Is this one worth backporting to 5.2?

text: Patch Set 2:might be worth leaving ScDocumentPool alone for now.It looks like we can make ScPatternAttr "un-special" because ScPatternAttr is only special because the ref-count used to be sal_uInt16.But now the ref-count is sal_uLong, we could remove the "special-ness" of ScPatternAttr, and then only fix the ScDocumentPool destructor.
Text: Patch Set 2:might be worth leaving ScDocumentPool alone for now.It looks like we can make ScPatternAttr "un-special" because ScPatternAttr is only special because the ref-count used to be sal_uInt16.But now the ref-count is sal_uLong, we could remove the "special-ness" of ScPatternAttr, and then only fix the ScDocumentPool destructor.

text: Patch Set 5:Not a regression, I think this has always been the case that this won't work. But you were on the right track, only this is a recursive function so we should just bail out of resolveEmbeddingsStream when we discover that we are trying to resolve a missing header or footer. I'll test this out and see if my change works. Nice bit of troubleshooting there Julien!
Text: Patch Set 5:Not a regression, I think this has always been the case that this won't work. But you were on the right track, only this is a recursive function so we should just bail out of resolveEmbeddingsStream when we discover that we are trying to resolve a missing header or footer. I'll test this out and see if my change works. Nice bit of troubleshooting there Julien!

text: Patch Set 2:If you keep the part, which toggles s1 and s2, so that the test statistic is always greater 1, then you get more accuracy in case one variance is huge and the FTEST result is near zero. But I think, for all realistic use cases with alpha=5% is makes no difference.
Text: Patch Set 2:If you keep the part, which toggles s1 and s2, so that the test statistic is always greater 1, then you get more accuracy in case one variance is huge and the FTEST result is near zero. But I think, for all realistic use cases with alpha=5% is makes no difference.

text: Patch Set 5:Looks great, but there were some bugs and tweaks that are needed.Default should be the first entry in the submenu menu.If set to notebookbar, restarting LO wont show notebookbar and changing it to another mode and then back to notebookbar wont make it appear.If notebookbar is enabled, .uno:AvailableToolbars should be disabled.If notebookbar isnt enabled, .uno:Notebookbar should be disabled.For default mode, if the sidebar is opened/closed/only showing the 'show' arrow button, it should be opened only showing the tab bars (what it looks like when you open writer with a cleared profile).For single toolbar mode, the sidebar should be enabled but collapsed only showing the 'show' arrow button, the toolbar icons need to be changed to small if they are set to automatic and the icon style should be changed to sifr if set to automatic. this means that before the activation of single toolbar mode, the icon size and style needs to be preserved in the user profile for non-single toolbar mode, as well as saving it for when exiting single toolbar mode so it can be restored when returning to single toolbar mode. In this mode, all contextual toolbar should be disabled (https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=92218#c13).For sidebar mode, the sidbear should be fully opened whatever state it is in and set to the properties tab.For notebookbar mode, the sidebar should be collapsed to show the 'show' arrrow button, similar to single toolbar mode.
Text: Patch Set 5:Looks great, but there were some bugs and tweaks that are needed.Default should be the first entry in the submenu menu.If set to notebookbar, restarting LO wont show notebookbar and changing it to another mode and then back to notebookbar wont make it appear.If notebookbar is enabled, .uno:AvailableToolbars should be disabled.If notebookbar isnt enabled, .uno:Notebookbar should be disabled.For default mode, if the sidebar is opened/closed/only showing the 'show' arrow button, it should be opened only showing the tab bars (what it looks like when you open writer with a cleared profile).For single toolbar mode, the sidebar should be enabled but collapsed only showing the 'show' arrow button, the toolbar icons need to be changed to small if they are set to automatic and the icon style should be changed to sifr if set to automatic. this means that before the activation of single toolbar mode, the icon size and style needs to be preserved in the user profile for non-single toolbar mode, as well as saving it for when exiting single toolbar mode so it can be restored when returning to single toolbar mode. In this mode, all contextual toolbar should be disabled (https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=92218#c13).For sidebar mode, the sidbear should be fully opened whatever state it is in and set to the properties tab.For notebookbar mode, the sidebar should be collapsed to show the 'show' arrrow button, similar to single toolbar mode.

text: Patch Set 2:Did you try adding a testcase for the style deletion undo? E.g. SwUiWriterTest::testBookmarkUndo() could be a good example; uiwriter gives you access to the internal API, so you can delete the style using the same codepath as used by the UI. And then you could assert that an undo action is created on the undo stack. Could you please look into that?
Text: Patch Set 2:Did you try adding a testcase for the style deletion undo? E.g. SwUiWriterTest::testBookmarkUndo() could be a good example; uiwriter gives you access to the internal API, so you can delete the style using the same codepath as used by the UI. And then you could assert that an undo action is created on the undo stack. Could you please look into that?

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1Love the idea - thanks for de-bonging this =) great to share the same thread pool with several sets of tasks. While you are there - it would be rather nice to add a big-fat DBGUTIL-only assertion (using a thread variable - if there is some nice wrapper for those) - that we never wait on a job - from a thread-pool thread ourselves.I'd like to try to keep our threading code using as simple leaf helper code as possible - and we can live without the re-enterancy hazards in those cases =) is that do-able too ?

text: Patch Set 2:> luckily FUNCLIB_EUROTOOL is casted to sal_uInt8 before the shift so the result is 0x0000 (or undefined?)Not true. (sal_uInt8 << 12) is promoted to int before casted to sal_uInt16. The result is 0x1000.
Text: Patch Set 2:> luckily FUNCLIB_EUROTOOL is casted to sal_uInt8 before the shift so the result is 0x0000 (or undefined?)Not true. (sal_uInt8 << 12) is promoted to int before casted to sal_uInt16. The result is 0x1000.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hmm - so - I would be rather happier to have some much deeper unit tests here. We have hit a problem in the parsing, we are trying to fix it - and I don't see a unit test for this behaviour - which is a red flag.First I'd like to see an example of a new file with assertion code that mis-uses defined namespaces without resolving them; eg. checking "office:foo" for any value of the office namespace.How we propagage unknown namespaces properly - is an open question - but I see only one path (of a rather complex function) in FastSaxParserImpl::callbackStartElement with a method added to it - I would like to see test files, and assertions that exercise all of the paths here - so we can check we have a good, comprehensive solution.Thanks ! =)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hmm - so - I would be rather happier to have some much deeper unit tests here. We have hit a problem in the parsing, we are trying to fix it - and I don't see a unit test for this behaviour - which is a red flag.First I'd like to see an example of a new file with assertion code that mis-uses defined namespaces without resolving them; eg. checking "office:foo" for any value of the office namespace.How we propagage unknown namespaces properly - is an open question - but I see only one path (of a rather complex function) in FastSaxParserImpl::callbackStartElement with a method added to it - I would like to see test files, and assertions that exercise all of the paths here - so we can check we have a good, comprehensive solution.Thanks ! =)

text: Patch Set 1:Hmm... I'm not convinced that misusing a toolbox controller as a way to place a control inside a .ui file is a good approach in general. It might be fine for simple controls like comboboxes, because those can be placed on a "classic" toolbar too, but using it for a whole panel seems like overkill. Why not register SlideTransitionPane as a proper glade control, and use it directly?About the late init problem: You can try some kind of event notification. If none of the existing notifications proves to be useful - you can use the dispatch status updates mechanism. (And of course making the whole notebookbar init much later is an option too, but I have no idea how hard it would be.)
Text: Patch Set 1:Hmm... I'm not convinced that misusing a toolbox controller as a way to place a control inside a .ui file is a good approach in general. It might be fine for simple controls like comboboxes, because those can be placed on a "classic" toolbar too, but using it for a whole panel seems like overkill. Why not register SlideTransitionPane as a proper glade control, and use it directly?About the late init problem: You can try some kind of event notification. If none of the existing notifications proves to be useful - you can use the dispatch status updates mechanism. (And of course making the whole notebookbar init much later is an option too, but I have no idea how hard it would be.)

text: Patch Set 23:Hi Thorsten,Thanks for the help. I think I could have never found out it myself, I've changed it to pass it by reference.Regarding the accessor functions question, initially, if I remember well, I decided to change the struct to be a class, as the other impls I converted to cow_wrapper previously were classes too, so I think it was just a matter of consistency, thus the members became private and I needed access to them when using ImplGetConstData(). Do you think it's better to use struct over class in the case?

text: Patch Set 1:It is the aforementioned Scottish Gaelic Spellchecker, prior LibreOffice versions were shipping with v2.8, but license file was missing, so the extension wasn't working. I added the license file, and updated to the current version (3.1), future updates will come from this extension as well.For me this is a bit stressful, as it was my first commit meddling with dictionaries, and I made a few mistakes as well when I was trying to figure out how this was working. Therefore for the sake of future updates, I'd like to have the absolute minimal modifications compared to the original, so you can just overwrite the whole thing, and see right away if anything was changed apart from the dictionary files (likely not, but you never know). These are the only reasons why I'm not eager to modify the directory structure and description.xml.However, as I said, if this is important, I'm fine with making the changes, and then I'll ask the dictionary/extension maintainers to update theirs.
Text: Patch Set 1:It is the aforementioned Scottish Gaelic Spellchecker, prior LibreOffice versions were shipping with v2.8, but license file was missing, so the extension wasn't working. I added the license file, and updated to the current version (3.1), future updates will come from this extension as well.For me this is a bit stressful, as it was my first commit meddling with dictionaries, and I made a few mistakes as well when I was trying to figure out how this was working. Therefore for the sake of future updates, I'd like to have the absolute minimal modifications compared to the original, so you can just overwrite the whole thing, and see right away if anything was changed apart from the dictionary files (likely not, but you never know). These are the only reasons why I'm not eager to modify the directory structure and description.xml.However, as I said, if this is important, I'm fine with making the changes, and then I'll ask the dictionary/extension maintainers to update theirs.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =)Thanks.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =)Thanks.

text: Patch Set 2:> Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my > lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code > that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various > exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with > this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case > sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =) >  > Thanks.So EHs only affects whether we catch the SEH or not. It does not affect how other code handles it. Of course if we get a lot of SEH excepions from outside of our control that are currently caught in one of the catch all handlers we are going to crash a lot.EHs has basically two effects on the code. catch(...) will not catch SEH exceptions and there is no stack nwinding and destructor calls going to be for SEH exceptions.I think both are fine in our code. The case that some external part is handling SEH with EHa should not concern us as if we get a SEH from that cod ewe will just crash and if that code handles it we are not going to see it anyway.
Text: Patch Set 2:> Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my > lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code > that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various > exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with > this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case > sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =) >  > Thanks.So EHs only affects whether we catch the SEH or not. It does not affect how other code handles it. Of course if we get a lot of SEH excepions from outside of our control that are currently caught in one of the catch all handlers we are going to crash a lot.EHs has basically two effects on the code. catch(...) will not catch SEH exceptions and there is no stack nwinding and destructor calls going to be for SEH exceptions.I think both are fine in our code. The case that some external part is handling SEH with EHa should not concern us as if we get a SEH from that cod ewe will just crash and if that code handles it we are not going to see it anyway.

text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1(1 comment)This commit needs to be split into at least 2 if not more patches.This mixes so many things (even if they are all related to validation). E.g. I'm unhappy with the DOCX part in the chart test unless someone is going to maintain them. I'm happy to maintain the calc parts and as far as I know I'm the only one really caring about the chart tests.At least all the non binary validation changes in the chart code need to go into an independent patch that can be discussed independently. With the current chart change this -1 should be seen as meaning a -2 with the chance to remove the -1 by splitting the unrelated parts into an own commit.For the calc part it is surely not the best idea to add uncommented code when are actually discouraging that. Hide it behind a ifdef or something like that to make it clearer that it is actually useful and should not be removed directly.
Text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1(1 comment)This commit needs to be split into at least 2 if not more patches.This mixes so many things (even if they are all related to validation). E.g. I'm happy to maintain the calc parts and as far as I know I'm the only one really caring about the chart tests.At least all the non binary validation changes in the chart code need to go into an independent patch that can be discussed independently. With the current chart change this -1 should be seen as meaning a -2 with the chance to remove the -1 by splitting the unrelated parts into an own commit.For the calc part it is surely not the best idea to add uncommented code when are actually discouraging that. Hide it behind a ifdef or something like that to make it clearer that it is actually useful and should not be removed directly.

text: Patch Set 2:> So, in the end, should I replace it by assert(!IsModified()), or > better to mark the class as SAL_FINAL ?hmm.... with a shared_ptr its not obvious who actually deletes the instance, so probably you have to leave this in the dtor.best to add a SAL_FINAL with a comment like "// see non-virtual call in dtor", so if anybody ever creates a sub-class they know to check that. > I assume I will have to do > the same for 6eebac959595f4bd7d4bd40c8325f1bc2782b3b8, isn't it?yes.

text: Patch Set 4:> problem in sd/xml/effects.xml - the preset effect always had > 'horizontal' before, so with your change, old odf files (which > display with circle effect in old versions) will now display with > the ellipse transition. >  > Can you look into effects.xml, and propose a solution?I tested it and it is working same as prior. I saved odf file with circle transition and circle animation on text. Transition is working as required but animation is showing ellipse and not circle which is not due to patch because it's elliptical(with animation name as circle) only in previous versions. (Tested on 5.0.5.2 on Ubuntu and 5.1.2 on Windows)
Text: Patch Set 4:> problem in sd/xml/effects.xml - the preset effect always had > 'horizontal' before, so with your change, old odf files (which > display with circle effect in old versions) will now display with > the ellipse transition. >  > Can you look into effects.xml, and propose a solution?I tested it and it is working same as prior. I saved odf file with circle transition and circle animation on text. Transition is working as required but animation is showing ellipse and not circle which is not due to patch because it's elliptical(with animation name as circle) only in previous versions. (Tested on 5.0.5.2 on Ubuntu and 5.1.2 on Windows)

text: Patch Set 4:> Yep, roundtrip looks good - > pushed a light touchup of your patch here, which highlights a > problem in sd/xml/effects.xml - the preset effect always had > 'horizontal' before, so with your change, old odf files (which > display with circle effect in old versions) will now display with > the ellipse transition. >  > Can you look into effects.xml, and propose a solution?I looked into effects.xml, changing 'smil type' to 'circle' from 'horizontal' in 'circle animation' results in a "circle" which is not elliptic( which was elliptic previously) and 'oval animation' works as required but when circle animation loaded from old ODF file( elliptic circle) it calls the 'oval animation'(elliptic). So, the possible solutions are:1.Since, old 'circle animation' and new 'oval animation' are both elliptic(smil type=horizontal). They can be left as such.2.If 'circle animation' is still to be kept as elliptic then the solution would include changing 'smil type' of oval to something else(like 'default') and make changes to other files accordingly.So, which solution should I push?
Text: Patch Set 4:> Yep, roundtrip looks good - > pushed a light touchup of your patch here, which highlights a > problem in sd/xml/effects.xml - the preset effect always had > 'horizontal' before, so with your change, old odf files (which > display with circle effect in old versions) will now display with > the ellipse transition. >  > Can you look into effects.xml, and propose a solution?I looked into effects.xml, changing 'smil type' to 'circle' from 'horizontal' in 'circle animation' results in a "circle" which is not elliptic( which was elliptic previously) and 'oval animation' works as required but when circle animation loaded from old ODF file( elliptic circle) it calls the 'oval animation'(elliptic). So, the possible solutions are:1.Since, old 'circle animation' and new 'oval animation' are both elliptic(smil type=horizontal). They can be left as such.2.If 'circle animation' is still to be kept as elliptic then the solution would include changing 'smil type' of oval to something else(like 'default') and make changes to other files accordingly.So, which solution should I push?

text: Patch Set 1:Well, I don't agree here:) My aim is not to satisfy complainers, but to show that LO has great configuration capabilities, even if they are not available in UI.Some thoughts:- The memory page seems to be appropriate for these information and one more paragraph does not make any harm there.- The warning at the Expert Configuration page is sufficient for me.- I really cannot say that no one in the world has use case for this - generally, this option is recommended to reduce memory consumption and I believe it can be still useful for some machines.- Maybe we should have some agreement how to reflect expert configurations in documentation (a topic for the documentation team?) - and then write them consistently (now I did it the same way as before).
Text: Patch Set 1:Well, I don't agree here:) My aim is not to satisfy complainers, but to show that LO has great configuration capabilities, even if they are not available in UI.Some thoughts:- The memory page seems to be appropriate for these information and one more paragraph does not make any harm there.- The warning at the Expert Configuration page is sufficient for me.- I really cannot say that no one in the world has use case for this - generally, this option is recommended to reduce memory consumption and I believe it can be still useful for some machines.- Maybe we should have some agreement how to reflect expert configurations in documentation (a topic for the documentation team?) - and then write them consistently (now I did it the same way as before).

text: Patch Set 3:My question is about the referenced ODF issue. ODF has at least the attributes <fo:text-align> and <style:tab-stop>, and it has to be specified how the new attribute <number:fill-character> will interact with these settings. Please add such information to OFFICE-3765. A remark whether something is special in RTL-writing environments would be nice too.

text: Patch Set 2:not sure about the UI-interaction here..All "please wait, I'm doing something"-indicators I've come across involve spinning things (hourglass in windows, beachball on Mac, various spinning circles in browsertabs, android apps)Flashing/pulsating items however stand for "new info available [click to show more]" - at most it stands for "almost there, click me to continue". So it represents the opposite, waiting for the user to do something, and not for a task that's running in the background.I initially wanted a circle spinner around the FAB, but gave up before I got it working...For stuff like this I see no problem using different animations depending on the android version, it is no critical thing, doesn't  involve program or makes it not work on other systems. (So I'd rename the amination xml to a generic fabanimation or something, then we can use different ones by using versioned resources)(ps: had to rewrite my comment, as gerrit did not remember)
Text: Patch Set 2:not sure about the UI-interaction here..All "please wait, I'm doing something"-indicators I've come across involve spinning things (hourglass in windows, beachball on Mac, various spinning circles in browsertabs, android apps)Flashing/pulsating items however stand for "new info available [click to show more]" - at most it stands for "almost there, click me to continue". So it represents the opposite, waiting for the user to do something, and not for a task that's running in the background.I initially wanted a circle spinner around the FAB, but gave up before I got it working...For stuff like this I see no problem using different animations depending on the android version, it is no critical thing, doesn't  involve program or makes it not work on other systems. (So I'd rename the amination xml to a generic fabanimation or something, then we can use different ones by using versioned resources)(ps: had to rewrite my comment, as gerrit did not remember)

text: Patch Set 1:I based my changes on https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=97831#c43 and concluded that Excel handles the argument from left to right and quits at the first error encountered.With respect to jumps, I reverse the stack and only read the arguments I need. So I don't know how much advantage there is using jumps. I haven't started that yet. But I do know that I will have to change some things as the maximum count now is something like 30 and I may have up to 127 expressions/values to compare.
Text: Patch Set 1:I based my changes on https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=97831#c43 and concluded that Excel handles the argument from left to right and quits at the first error encountered.With respect to jumps, I reverse the stack and only read the arguments I need. So I don't know how much advantage there is using jumps. I haven't started that yet. But I do know that I will have to change some things as the maximum count now is something like 30 and I may have up to 127 expressions/values to compare.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1> I based my changes on https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=97831#c43 > and concluded that Excel handles the argument from left to right > and quits at the first error encountered.Looks like. > With respect to jumps, I reverse the stack and only read the > arguments I need. So I don't know how much advantage there is using > jumps.The advantage of jumps is, that non-matching code paths are not executed at all, which can make a performance difference. Currently all arguments are calculated before SWITCH is called. > I haven't started that yet. But I do know that I will have > to change some things as the maximum count now is something like 30 > and I may have up to 127 expressions/values to compare.The 30 parameters limitation is only in the UI Function Wizard, compiler and interpreter handle up to 255 parameters per function.It would be nice though to get rid of that limit in the Function Wizard, where further arguments currently pile up in the last parameter edit field, and descriptions still talk about max 30 arguments.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1> I based my changes on https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=97831#c43 > and concluded that Excel handles the argument from left to right > and quits at the first error encountered.Looks like. > With respect to jumps, I reverse the stack and only read the > arguments I need. So I don't know how much advantage there is using > jumps.The advantage of jumps is, that non-matching code paths are not executed at all, which can make a performance difference. Currently all arguments are calculated before SWITCH is called. > I haven't started that yet. But I do know that I will have > to change some things as the maximum count now is something like 30 > and I may have up to 127 expressions/values to compare.The 30 parameters limitation is only in the UI Function Wizard, compiler and interpreter handle up to 255 parameters per function.It would be nice though to get rid of that limit in the Function Wizard, where further arguments currently pile up in the last parameter edit field, and descriptions still talk about max 30 arguments.

text: Patch Set 12:Just a note about commits:I didn't mean that the whole new template manager should be in a single commit - just that each commit contains one logical change.For example, don't introduce a new class without using it, but make use of it in the same patch.Maybe you can finish what you started in this patch and then create a new one based on this. You can also push a series of patches to gerrit (one based on the other).I'm not yet sure if we want this stuff in 5.2 or whether its better to wait until 5.3. Maybe we can chat a bit about this when you are back home :)

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1Hi Akshay,looks like a good start - I guess you want to start with implementing the filter combobox and remove the folders?I'd prefer to have the whole change in one patch, not small pieces like this separated all over the place.Of course you can push existing code before its ready, just start your commit msg with "WIP: ...".One comment on this patch: include/sfx2 should only be used when you need to use this file outside of sfx2, if it's a sfx2-only header, you should put it in sfx2/inc.

text: Patch Set 3:Hi,I think you convert too much.When you add a method SdrGrafObj::getOriginalSize() it should return the size in the same units the SdrModel is defined in. This is not always 100thMM. In Draw/Impress/Calc it is, but in Writer it is Twips. So the method has to convert to the units of the SdrModel used, you can get that using GetModel()->GetScaleUnit() in/at the SdrObject which gives you the target MapUnit. Looks as if the original code you copied did not do that, but that is okay since it originally was only used in sd. With a method at SdrGrafObj it has to be done correct since e.g. it can be called in the future in Writer code and has to convert to Twips then.It is not needed to hand over the SdrObject again to the getOriginalSize() implementation as parameter, use the local C++ this ptr which is already the SdrGrafObj from which you need the size.In drviews7, the call to GetLogicRect() will already return the data in the model units, so I think the conversion there to 100thMM is not needed at all, just compare aRect.GetSize() with pSdrGrafObj->getOriginalSize, that should then compare both sizes in the same, correct model units.HTH!
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi,I think you convert too much.When you add a method SdrGrafObj::getOriginalSize() it should return the size in the same units the SdrModel is defined in. This is not always 100thMM. In Draw/Impress/Calc it is, but in Writer it is Twips. So the method has to convert to the units of the SdrModel used, you can get that using GetModel()->GetScaleUnit() in/at the SdrObject which gives you the target MapUnit. Looks as if the original code you copied did not do that, but that is okay since it originally was only used in sd. With a method at SdrGrafObj it has to be done correct since e.g. it can be called in the future in Writer code and has to convert to Twips then.It is not needed to hand over the SdrObject again to the getOriginalSize() implementation as parameter, use the local C++ this ptr which is already the SdrGrafObj from which you need the size.In drviews7, the call to GetLogicRect() will already return the data in the model units, so I think the conversion there to 100thMM is not needed at all, just compare aRect.GetSize() with pSdrGrafObj->getOriginalSize, that should then compare both sizes in the same, correct model units.HTH!

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2As Michael says the motivation behind this service is that in case an out-of-process UNO client registers a dispatch provider, then on startup the ~200 uno commands are queried a number of times -- and that's a lot of traffic, when the use case is that most of these commands are disabled, and only a few of them is forwarded to the salve dispatcher or handled directly. With this service, it's possible to handle most of the commands directly in core via cheap c++ virtual member function calls (vs. more expensive C++ <-> URP <-> external client ones, and the same marshaling + parsing back with the result). The configuration-based approach is great if you want to make these changes permanent -- this one doesn't touch the configuration, so the effect can be dynamic, and is automatically thrown away when the process ends.So to sum up, it seems to me the two are not conflicting, they rather complement each other.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2As Michael says the motivation behind this service is that in case an out-of-process UNO client registers a dispatch provider, then on startup the ~200 uno commands are queried a number of times -- and that's a lot of traffic, when the use case is that most of these commands are disabled, and only a few of them is forwarded to the salve dispatcher or handled directly. With this service, it's possible to handle most of the commands directly in core via cheap c++ virtual member function calls (vs. more expensive C++ <-> URP <-> external client ones, and the same marshaling + parsing back with the result). The configuration-based approach is great if you want to make these changes permanent -- this one doesn't touch the configuration, so the effect can be dynamic, and is automatically thrown away when the process ends.So to sum up, it seems to me the two are not conflicting, they rather complement each other.

text: Patch Set 1:It seems I was too confident :-(Just thinking loud:we're on document destructor because of "delete pRefUndoDoc;" (line 2415 in docfunc.cxx)pRefUndoDoc is made from this same file line 2356.However, I'm just wondering the mechanism of this:pRefUndoDoc->InitUndo( &rDoc, 0, nTabCount-1 ); (line 2357)InitUndo calls SharePooledResources(pSrcDoc); (see http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sc/source/core/data/document.cxx#1918)This last one does:    266     xPoolHelper = pSrcDoc->xPoolHelper;    267     mpCellStringPool = pSrcDoc->mpCellStringPool;Argh, must go now but wonder if we really lose the ref.
Text: Patch Set 1:It seems I was too confident :-(Just thinking loud:we're on document destructor because of "delete pRefUndoDoc;" (line 2415 in docfunc.cxx)pRefUndoDoc is made from this same file line 2356.However, I'm just wondering the mechanism of this:pRefUndoDoc->InitUndo( &rDoc, 0, nTabCount-1 ); (line 2357)InitUndo calls SharePooledResources(pSrcDoc); (see http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sc/source/core/data/document.cxx#1918)This last one does:    266     xPoolHelper = pSrcDoc->xPoolHelper;    267     mpCellStringPool = pSrcDoc->mpCellStringPool;Argh, must go now but wonder if we really lose the ref.

text: RestoredI'll try a new patch tonight.Replace:if ( xPoolHelper.is() && !bIsClip )byif ( xPoolHelper.is() && !bIsClip && !bIsUndo )Indeed, since pRefUndoDoc has been created like this"new ScDocument( SCDOCMODE_UNDO );", it shouldn't call xPoolHelper->SourceDocumentGone();The source doc hasn't gone, we're in the destructor of an "Undo doc".
Text: RestoredI'll try a new patch tonight.Replace:if ( xPoolHelper.is() && !bIsClip )byif ( xPoolHelper.is() && !bIsClip && !bIsUndo )Indeed, since pRefUndoDoc has been created like this"new ScDocument( SCDOCMODE_UNDO );", it shouldn't call xPoolHelper->SourceDocumentGone();The source doc hasn't gone, we're in the destructor of an "Undo doc".

text: Patch Set 3:All the previous suggestions have be implemented and it looks great. There were a few minor UI things that should be fixed.1) The separator and grid should align on the left with the labels2) The theme name shouldnt be centered between 'Own Theme' label and the 'Select Theme' button, it should be left aligned next to 'Own Theme' and should likely have parenthesis around it. (e.g. "Own Theme (Office 2003 for LibreOffice)" )Regarding the adding of a firefox theme url in the field, we need to make a few changes.1) When clicking the 'Search' button, it should download the theme, apply it, and close the dialog without any other user interaction.2) We should change the button label from 'Search' to 'Go', so it make sense in scenarios.
Text: Patch Set 3:All the previous suggestions have be implemented and it looks great. There were a few minor UI things that should be fixed.1) The separator and grid should align on the left with the labels2) The theme name shouldnt be centered between 'Own Theme' label and the 'Select Theme' button, it should be left aligned next to 'Own Theme' and should likely have parenthesis around it. (e.g. "Own Theme (Office 2003 for LibreOffice)" )Regarding the adding of a firefox theme url in the field, we need to make a few changes.1) When clicking the 'Search' button, it should download the theme, apply it, and close the dialog without any other user interaction.2) We should change the button label from 'Search' to 'Go', so it make sense in scenarios.

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1I think this is good enough to push. We can fine tune during drive-by ... so you can continue on MINIFS/MAXIFSA high class master challenge would be to rewrite both functions using code jumps as is done with IF() and CHOOSE() ;-) As is, all arguments have to be calculated before the function is called, which is unnecessary as only one result path will be chosen and also the conditionals would have to be calculated only on demand, but it works.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1I think this is good enough to push. We can fine tune during drive-by ... so you can continue on MINIFS/MAXIFSA high class master challenge would be to rewrite both functions using code jumps as is done with IF() and CHOOSE() ;-) As is, all arguments have to be calculated before the function is called, which is unnecessary as only one result path will be chosen and also the conditionals would have to be calculated only on demand, but it works.

text: Patch Set 3:This patch broke the firefox theme search. The previous one works fine, this one breaks it. My patch here at https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/23385/ is no longer working due to this.The openFileRead in personalization.cxx in getPreviewFile (line 730) throws timed out exception i think and returns. No search results come up.
Text: Patch Set 3:This patch broke the firefox theme search. The previous one works fine, this one breaks it. My patch here at https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/23385/ is no longer working due to this.The openFileRead in personalization.cxx in getPreviewFile (line 730) throws timed out exception i think and returns. No search results come up.

text: Patch Set 3:> > This patch broke the firefox theme search. The previous one works > > fine, this one breaks it. My patch here at https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/23385/ > > is no longer working due to this. > > > > The openFileRead in personalization.cxx in getPreviewFile (line > > 730) throws timed out exception i think and returns. No search > > results come up. >  > My guess is the getPreviewFile gets a https:// site with a > certificate that needs deeper checks. >  > In this case you need to change the way the file is accessed, > duplicating what I did on try..catch construct that starts at line > 583 of master. >  > In case of a https:// protocol you need a XInteractionHandler to > manage the certificates inside the ucp.webdav provider.Thank you for that! Issue resolved :)
Text: Patch Set 3:> > This patch broke the firefox theme search. The previous one works > > fine, this one breaks it. My patch here at https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/23385/ > > is no longer working due to this. > > > > The openFileRead in personalization.cxx in getPreviewFile (line > > 730) throws timed out exception i think and returns. No search > > results come up. >  > My guess is the getPreviewFile gets a https:// site with a > certificate that needs deeper checks. >  > In this case you need to change the way the file is accessed, > duplicating what I did on try..catch construct that starts at line > 583 of master. >  > In case of a https:// protocol you need a XInteractionHandler to > manage the certificates inside the ucp.webdav provider.Thank you for that! Issue resolved :)

text: Patch Set 1:To reproduce with a new certificate :mkdir -p dbopenssl req -new > cert.csropenssl rsa -in privkey.pem -out cert.keyopenssl x509 -in cert.csr -out cert.cert -req -signkey cert.key -days 99999openssl pkcs12 -export -out cert.p12 -inkey cert.key -in cert.cert -certfile cert.certcertutil -N -d dbpk12util -i cert.p12 -d dbIn LibreOffice -> Tools -> Options -> Security -> Certificate Path, choose the new directory "db" and valid the form.Restart LibreOffice.Create a new ods file.In Tools -> Macros -> Organize Macros ... -> LibreOffice Basic ..., Select the current file -> Standart and click on "New", close the window and save the document.In Tools -> Macros -> Digital Signature.. -> Click on "Sign Document ...", select the new certificate.Close the window and save.Close the document and re-open it.Save a copyof the document or wait for the autosave, edit the document and try to save.
Text: Patch Set 1:To reproduce with a new certificate :mkdir -p dbopenssl req -new > cert.csropenssl rsa -in privkey.pem -out cert.keyopenssl x509 -in cert.csr -out cert.cert -req -signkey cert.key -days 99999openssl pkcs12 -export -out cert.p12 -inkey cert.key -in cert.cert -certfile cert.certcertutil -N -d dbpk12util -i cert.p12 -d dbIn LibreOffice -> Tools -> Options -> Security -> Certificate Path, choose the new directory "db" and valid the form.Restart LibreOffice.Create a new ods file.In Tools -> Macros -> Organize Macros ... -> LibreOffice Basic ..., Select the current file -> Standart and click on "New", close the window and save the document.In Tools -> Macros -> Digital Signature.. -> Click on "Sign Document ...", select the new certificate.Close the window and save.Close the document and re-open it.Save a copyof the document or wait for the autosave, edit the document and try to save.

text: Patch Set 5:Yes, I think the patch set should be final.(As a matter of fact, the next 2 functions, IFS and SWITCH, are waiting for this patch set to be pushed so that hey can be submitted.)I have one change I would like to make to this patch set, but that can also be done in a separate patch. In ScInterpreter::ScTextJoin I reverse the parameter stack. I want to make a separate function ScInterpreter::ReverseStack( sal_uInt8 nParamCount ) for that as I reverse the stack for IFS and SWITCH as well (and possibly for MINIFS and MAXIFS). Just a matter of avoiding identical code blocks.

text: Patch Set 2:> Is it fine if the variable for the return value only used in > OSL_ENSURE?Yes, OSL_ENSURE internally uses the sal/log.hxx machinery, which makes the checked expression "visible" to the compiler even if it is never executed in non-debug builds.
Text: Patch Set 2:> Is it fine if the variable for the return value only used in > OSL_ENSURE?Yes, OSL_ENSURE internally uses the sal/log.hxx machinery, which makes the checked expression "visible" to the compiler even if it is never executed in non-debug builds.

text: Patch Set 6:I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the client's request with an exception.
Text: Patch Set 6:I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the client's request with an exception.

text: Patch Set 2:> Looks great to me in general; just for the checking - instead of > checking that things have the possible values, I'd instead use some > concrete values that have some interesting cases; like >  > * one active / enabled entry > * one disabled entry > * one entry with a checkbox - checked (if possible) > * one entry with a checkboxs - unchecked (if possible) >  > Also I'd bind it to some concrete .uno: command, not to a position > in the menu, so that we are agnostic to reordering in the menu > (though we have it hardcoded in the user template, so maybe that's > not a problem - but for the easier updating the next time). >  > Can you please update that? :-)Okay, so besides this, added module-specific unit test to check for concrete values - https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/24006
Text: Patch Set 2:> Looks great to me in general; just for the checking - instead of > checking that things have the possible values, I'd instead use some > concrete values that have some interesting cases; like >  > * one active / enabled entry > * one disabled entry > * one entry with a checkbox - checked (if possible) > * one entry with a checkboxs - unchecked (if possible) >  > Also I'd bind it to some concrete .uno: command, not to a position > in the menu, so that we are agnostic to reordering in the menu > (though we have it hardcoded in the user template, so maybe that's > not a problem - but for the easier updating the next time). >  > Can you please update that? :-)Okay, so besides this, added module-specific unit test to check for concrete values - https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/24006

text: Patch Set 1:Looks great to me in general; just for the checking - instead of checking that things have the possible values, I'd instead use some concrete values that have some interesting cases; like* one active / enabled entry* one disabled entry* one entry with a checkbox - checked (if possible)* one entry with a checkboxs - unchecked (if possible)Also I'd bind it to some concrete .uno: command, not to a position in the menu, so that we are agnostic to reordering in the menu (though we have it hardcoded in the user template, so maybe that's not a problem - but for the easier updating the next time).Can you please update that? :-)
Text: Patch Set 1:Looks great to me in general; just for the checking - instead of checking that things have the possible values, I'd instead use some concrete values that have some interesting cases; like* one active / enabled entry* one disabled entry* one entry with a checkbox - checked (if possible)* one entry with a checkboxs - unchecked (if possible)Also I'd bind it to some concrete .uno: command, not to a position in the menu, so that we are agnostic to reordering in the menu (though we have it hardcoded in the user template, so maybe that's not a problem - but for the easier updating the next time).Can you please update that? :-)

[0x30E35B6] in (optimized out: previous OPENSSL_rdtsc) [0x30E35B0]      liblo-native-code.so: (memory/data?) text: Patch Set 4:Thanks for pushing > I think if possible, it would be better to have this as an external > Python script, rather than a macro that you have to run directly > from inside LibreOffice, but if this does the job, it's definitely > better than not having any scripting here at all :-)As I saw it when writing the tool, the main consumer of the tool would be localizers checking that their changes to translations, or reorganizations to the menus, don't mess up accelerators. As I saw it it is probably easier for them to push a button in a document then running an external python script. >  > Niklas - thank you for making it happen!no problem
Text: Patch Set 4:Thanks for pushing > I think if possible, it would be better to have this as an external > Python script, rather than a macro that you have to run directly > from inside LibreOffice, but if this does the job, it's definitely > better than not having any scripting here at all :-)As I saw it when writing the tool, the main consumer of the tool would be localizers checking that their changes to translations, or reorganizations to the menus, don't mess up accelerators. As I saw it it is probably easier for them to push a button in a document then running an external python script. >  > Niklas - thank you for making it happen!no problem

text: Patch Set 3:> Yeah, I wanted to make it without classes too, but it looked more > difficult, because these functions call other functions that need > to be implemented for each platform (init/deInit/...) and so on. >  > I guess I should try it again =)Not having looked at your changes in detail yet, just a generic remark:If there is a common skeleton of code across the different platforms, and just some functions need to be implemented differently, it's IMO fine to* have the common skeleton source code in one place,* have a common include file that declares the functions that need to be implemented per platform,* have per-platform source files defining those functions.That works for both C and C++ code.  See bridges/inc/bridges/cpp_uno/shared/vtablefactory.hxx for an example of a (non-virtual) C++ class VtableFactory that leaves some of its member functions (that all happen to be static, but that's irrelevant here) to be implemented per-platform.

See bridges/inc/bridges/cpp_uno/shared/vtablefactory.hxx for an example of a (non-virtual) C++ class VtableFactory that leaves some of its member functions (that all happen to be static, but that's irrelevant here) to be implemented per-platform.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1So - I give a -1 - but this is a really good start; nice research and work here - I think we want another iteration though:** You fixed Eike's concerns - thanks =)** Comments:	+ please pass the parameter as an integer:		+ this is what is done for all the UNO APIs:		+ you can get those integers from here:    sal_uInt32 SvNumberFormatter::GetEntryKey(const OUString& sStr,    	       				      LanguageType eLnge)    const SvNumberformat* GetEntry( sal_uInt32 nKey ) const;	+ Lets store the "GetEntryKey" results into	  the list box with the class VCL_DLLPUBLIC ListBox : public Control...    void                SetEntryData( sal_Int32  nPos, void* pNewData );    void*               GetEntryData( sal_Int32  nPos ) const;	+ so we can do all of this in one place.	+ you will need to use:	m_pCurrencyLb->SetEntryData( nPos, reinterpret_cast<void*>(i) );	+ or somesuch.** Beyond that:	+ I think instead of doing the 'set' inside the SvxCurrencyList_Impl		+ we need to propagate this setting up to the		  SvxCurrencyToolBoxControl		  => we can store it as a member		  - next time we pop-up the currency list we should		    pre-select the right EntryKey in there.		  - when we subsequently click the '$' sign we should		    use this last currency selected that we now remember.	+ Toggling currency is still a fine behavior for that button I think;	  that is what people want; just with a configurable / easy to use	  currency selection.	With those cleanups (and I hope) simplifications, we can merge this.
Text: With those cleanups (and I hope) simplifications, we can merge this."

text: Patch Set 4:Hi Armin, thank you for looking into this! > - Green is hard to read against blue, if it is simple to change > that I would prefer something with more ocntrastI'll do that ASAP; the color choice was simply random. :( > - Diffs on some pages, e.g. Page1, shape 'Oval 71'4th line, 2nd > from left, centerd on PPT, left in our version. Other diffs 'Oval > 73', 'Oval 74', 'Oval 75-79' (hard to see with green), 'Oval > 91-99', 'Oval 111, 113-119' > - More on other pagesWell, I noticed that; though I only tested if the patch (targeted at one specific problem) does some regressions. > I hope you do not think I am too nit-picking, but of course to get > that right is central for compatibility.Well, I do wholeheartly agree; but imo the patch should be very specific, as it at least *looks* dangerous; so that it could be possible later to bisect right to it in case of a regression. I suppose other improvements should go in follow-ups, don't you agree? > It might be that green and > red mean something like 'this should work, this not' that I do not > know.No, I have mislead you with these colours; I only wanted to make things distinguishable. > For automatic comparison (test case): Hm. That would need to > compare against PPT state or against a saved PPT state. Do we have > a bitmap compare - it would be possible to get a bitmap from a > whole page in a good resolution and compare against a saved PPT one > of that page. Also single shapes, but that may be too > expensive/runtime extensiveI ask you to please guide (push) me in a promising direction, because I can't figure how to do this. If I'll be able to probrammatically generate a bitmap (preferably to file), I'll try to generate a reference bitmap from MSO to be able to test this; however, that would be silly to expect pixel-to-pixel match. Some fuzz would be required...

text: Patch Set 4:Hi Mike, please have a look at HtmlExport::CreateImagesForPresPages, there a drawing::GraphicExportFilter is used to create images of the single pages. You can strip down, use a fixed format and set as source the page (xGraphicExporter->setSourceDocument(...)), a temp URL as target. HTH!
Text: Patch Set 4:Hi Mike, please have a look at HtmlExport::CreateImagesForPresPages, there a drawing::GraphicExportFilter is used to create images of the single pages. You can strip down, use a fixed format and set as source the page (xGraphicExporter->setSourceDocument(...)), a temp URL as target. HTH!

text: Patch Set 3:Thanks Armin, Thorsten!1. I'm not very familiar with therminology. Could you please tell me what to use as CustomShape? Will MS Impress Rectangle do? (I see that I can use OLE/bitmap as non-CS.)2. As to unit test: I already looked for a way to make one. I cannot invent it: testing the adjustment feels not right, because the desired view may be attained differently. That would definitely say something about the correctness of the display.Maybe there's a way to know the actual position text is written to?

text: Patch Set 1:The problem in tdf#93124 is the following:1. The title text is aligned vertically to bottom, and its height is greater than its rectangle.2. In this case, when text isn't aligned to full width of the object, it ignores the vertical anchor setting (be it to middle or bottom), and aligns vertically to top. So, to retain correct position, the text must be aligned to full width.3. Full width alignment is only available when horisontal alignment is to center.4. All paragraphs in the text box are aligned to left, so LO "optimizes" the text object alignment to left bottom corner, thus disabling full width setting, and breaks the test position.Another approach could be to either allow full width for any horisontal alignment, or to fix incorrect anchoring in case when text height is greater than the rectangle (IMO, the latter is preferable). But that change is much more invasive, and I suppose that removing the optimization (lines 898-922 and 952-976) that uses word "sensible", i.e. it's not mandatory, just intended to be more performant (?) in some cases, may be more suitable here.Also, the line 1034 makes some kinds of text objects to auto-align its contents to the box. As may be seen in tdf#41245, that's not correct, so I removed it. If auto-fit is to be used on import, it must be enabled only when PPT specifies that explicitly.And even with the previous fix, some objects keep getting auto-fit flag just because the template specifies that, and that's why I needed to explicitly override it in 1093-1100. If later the auto-fit is to be enabled, it's the place where we should check for PPT (explicit) auto-fit setting, and enable it if set, and keep disabling otherwise.
Text: Patch Set 1:The problem in tdf#93124 is the following:1. The title text is aligned vertically to bottom, and its height is greater than its rectangle.2. In this case, when text isn't aligned to full width of the object, it ignores the vertical anchor setting (be it to middle or bottom), and aligns vertically to top. So, to retain correct position, the text must be aligned to full width.3. Full width alignment is only available when horisontal alignment is to center.4. All paragraphs in the text box are aligned to left, so LO "optimizes" the text object alignment to left bottom corner, thus disabling full width setting, and breaks the test position.Another approach could be to either allow full width for any horisontal alignment, or to fix incorrect anchoring in case when text height is greater than the rectangle (IMO, the latter is preferable). But that change is much more invasive, and I suppose that removing the optimization (lines 898-922 and 952-976) that uses word "sensible", i.e. it's not mandatory, just intended to be more performant (?) in some cases, may be more suitable here.Also, the line 1034 makes some kinds of text objects to auto-align its contents to the box. As may be seen in tdf#41245, that's not correct, so I removed it. If auto-fit is to be used on import, it must be enabled only when PPT specifies that explicitly.And even with the previous fix, some objects keep getting auto-fit flag just because the template specifies that, and that's why I needed to explicitly override it in 1093-1100. If later the auto-fit is to be enabled, it's the place where we should check for PPT (explicit) auto-fit setting, and enable it if set, and keep disabling otherwise.

text: Patch Set 6:(3 comments)Will upload new patch set -that should be mergeable too- with current changes.About the unittest: I prefer the test method as with the Excel2013 functions (no csv, but smart checking if no errors), but the problem is that Excel will almost always have different results than Calc. We're talking about forecasts, here. So should I create an ods file or should I create an xlsx and compare with verified Calc results?
Text: Patch Set 6:(3 comments)Will upload new patch set -that should be mergeable too- with current changes.About the unittest: I prefer the test method as with the Excel2013 functions (no csv, but smart checking if no errors), but the problem is that Excel will almost always have different results than Calc. We're talking about forecasts, here. So should I create an ods file or should I create an xlsx and compare with verified Calc results?

text: Patch Set 6:A new delay:Testing with Excel2016 revealed that with argument 'Seasonality' having a value of 0 (meaning that no seasonal influence is to be taken into account), Excel uses exponential double smoothing, where it says that linear forecasting is used. So The Excel functions are exponential smoothing functions, not necessarily exponential triple smoothing.More code to make and I intend to rename the LO functions from ETS to ES, making clear what they do.So, you'll have to wait a bit longer for the next patch set.
Text: Patch Set 6:A new delay:Testing with Excel2016 revealed that with argument 'Seasonality' having a value of 0 (meaning that no seasonal influence is to be taken into account), Excel uses exponential double smoothing, where it says that linear forecasting is used. So The Excel functions are exponential smoothing functions, not necessarily exponential triple smoothing.More code to make and I intend to rename the LO functions from ETS to ES, making clear what they do.So, you'll have to wait a bit longer for the next patch set.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1While this may circumvent the crash it will likely cause regressions that formula cells will not be recalculated when cells in the sort range are changed after the sort. Reason is that SplitFormulaGroups() ends the listening on grouped formulas and moving that to a place before intersecting listeners are collected with aGrpListenerRanges after line 1193 may result in listeners been gone that otherwise would had been collected, so these listeners will not be reestablished at the end.I'd like to see some unit tests first that ensure we do not introduce regressions in various overlapping / non-overlapping grouped formula listener scenarios.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1While this may circumvent the crash it will likely cause regressions that formula cells will not be recalculated when cells in the sort range are changed after the sort. Reason is that SplitFormulaGroups() ends the listening on grouped formulas and moving that to a place before intersecting listeners are collected with aGrpListenerRanges after line 1193 may result in listeners been gone that otherwise would had been collected, so these listeners will not be reestablished at the end.I'd like to see some unit tests first that ensure we do not introduce regressions in various overlapping / non-overlapping grouped formula listener scenarios.

text: Patch Set 5:> Just curious, what's the benefit of genLang, compared to the > current l10ntools, after the kill-sdf branch was merged? >  > See http://libreoffice.hu/2012/11/27/featurekillsdf-branch-merged/ > for the background.the kill sdf was a very good thing, but it did not change the tools or the method. The "save" method in the old tools was rewritten to save .pot files.genLang "reinvents" the tools in a C++ fashion, making it more maintainable. You can however argue, that since the old tools work, why change it. The best reason for that is to move away from the central "make translations" that runs find over the source tree, and into adding the files to the local makefiles (e.g. define ui files like you define cxx files).
Text: Patch Set 5:> Just curious, what's the benefit of genLang, compared to the > current l10ntools, after the kill-sdf branch was merged? >  > See http://libreoffice.hu/2012/11/27/featurekillsdf-branch-merged/ > for the background.the kill sdf was a very good thing, but it did not change the tools or the method. The "save" method in the old tools was rewritten to save .pot files.genLang "reinvents" the tools in a C++ fashion, making it more maintainable. You can however argue, that since the old tools work, why change it. The best reason for that is to move away from the central "make translations" that runs find over the source tree, and into adding the files to the local makefiles (e.g. define ui files like you define cxx files).

It seems that someone decided to use MAXRECURSION in the file /core/basic/source/classes/sbxmod.cxx==#if defined LINUX          // Empiric value, 900 = needed bytes/Basic call level          // for Linux including 10% safety margin          nMaxCallLevel = rl.rlim_cur / 900;#elif defined SOLARIS          // Empiric value, 1650 = needed bytes/Basic call level          // for Solaris including 10% safety margin          nMaxCallLevel = rl.rlim_cur / 1650;#elif defined WIN32          nMaxCallLevel = 5800;#else          nMaxCallLevel = MAXRECURSION;#endif==In other platforms, nMaxCallLEvel just uses a literal or calculated value.What should I do?

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Verified+1We should rework commits with `git rebase -i @~X` where X is the number of commits pushed together. This allows us to iron out any issues that we fixed in later commits, such that it'd seem as though they were written perfectly from the start.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Verified+1We should rework commits with `git rebase -i @~X` where X is the number of commits pushed together. This allows us to iron out any issues that we fixed in later commits, such that it'd seem as though they were written perfectly from the start.

text: Patch Set 3:This should take care of the design concern mentioned above. In case of password protected documents, ToPrisoner is closed when no password is provided along with the 'load' command, but ToClient holds and keep listening for further 'load' requests. When another 'load' command comes (with or without a password), the flow goes all the way through broker finding appropriate child to host the new document URI.Additionally, this also prevents caching for password protected documents with the help newly introduced bunch of password related variables and successful document load acknowledgment to parent process.'statusindicatorfinish:' is now used as an acknowledgment of successful document load operation on server side, as well as client side. In case of password protected document, it will be sent only when correct password is provided (because it is triggered by LOK), hence preventing the client to send any additional messages unless document has been opened successfully by providing the correct password.
Text: Patch Set 3:This should take care of the design concern mentioned above. In case of password protected documents, ToPrisoner is closed when no password is provided along with the 'load' command, but ToClient holds and keep listening for further 'load' requests. When another 'load' command comes (with or without a password), the flow goes all the way through broker finding appropriate child to host the new document URI.Additionally, this also prevents caching for password protected documents with the help newly introduced bunch of password related variables and successful document load acknowledgment to parent process.'statusindicatorfinish:' is now used as an acknowledgment of successful document load operation on server side, as well as client side. In case of password protected document, it will be sent only when correct password is provided (because it is triggered by LOK), hence preventing the client to send any additional messages unless document has been opened successfully by providing the correct password.

text: Patch Set 2:> I didn't fully understand. My approach is wrong? Should not I use > SAL_WARN_IF?Your approach is not wrong, but there are cases where using SAL_WARN_IF is not really needed. why use it, if the the code is always true...Take a look at the comments from Tor, his advice is really good. You need to be very carefull when converting logical statements, otherwise the expression works differently. A good approach is to simulate the single parts on paper (true, false) on the original statement and then again on the new statement, do that and you will see some problems.
Text: Patch Set 2:> I didn't fully understand. My approach is wrong? Should not I use > SAL_WARN_IF?Your approach is not wrong, but there are cases where using SAL_WARN_IF is not really needed. why use it, if the the code is always true...Take a look at the comments from Tor, his advice is really good. You need to be very carefull when converting logical statements, otherwise the expression works differently. A good approach is to simulate the single parts on paper (true, false) on the original statement and then again on the new statement, do that and you will see some problems.

text: Patch Set 13:(5 comments)> I didn't notice ScTabViewShell::GetState() warning. But i don't > know how can i handle it.It has a switch where you can handle the commands similar to the Execute method, but this time for the command state. A state of a command is how the UI element (toolbar button, menu item etc.) that bound to this command presented to the user. It can be enabled/disabled, checked/unchecked, its text can dynamically change etc.wrt our case, I see that .uno:FreezePanes is enabled always, even in a read-only doc, and so should be the new commands, so this isn't an issue. What GetState currently does for .uno:FreezePanes is that it sets checked/unchecked state. But I wonder whether we want something similar for the new commands (i.e. detect if the first row/column is frozen and set checked state accordingly), or maybe such indication isn't that useful, and we can just drop the GetState part from tabvwsh.sdi as well.Eike: What do you think on this?
Text: Patch Set 13:(5 comments)> I didn't notice ScTabViewShell::GetState() warning. But i don't > know how can i handle it.It has a switch where you can handle the commands similar to the Execute method, but this time for the command state. A state of a command is how the UI element (toolbar button, menu item etc.) that bound to this command presented to the user. It can be enabled/disabled, checked/unchecked, its text can dynamically change etc.wrt our case, I see that .uno:FreezePanes is enabled always, even in a read-only doc, and so should be the new commands, so this isn't an issue. What GetState currently does for .uno:FreezePanes is that it sets checked/unchecked state. But I wonder whether we want something similar for the new commands (i.e. detect if the first row/column is frozen and set checked state accordingly), or maybe such indication isn't that useful, and we can just drop the GetState part from tabvwsh.sdi as well.Eike: What do you think on this?

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Noel,Thanks for reviewing.As it's done right now, if no 'a' is found, nPos stays in the same position, otherwise, it will be moved to the point right after the 'a'. But I guess it would be better to do: skip_char(rCandidate,'a', nPos, nPos + 1);
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Noel,Thanks for reviewing.As it's done right now, if no 'a' is found, nPos stays in the same position, otherwise, it will be moved to the point right after the 'a'. But I guess it would be better to do: skip_char(rCandidate,'a', nPos, nPos + 1);
