text: Patch Set 3:> One small design concern. The whole code still assumes that aCol[i] > will never return a null pointer. Do you plan to change the > ColumnContainer to store null pointers at some point?I thought that in subsequent patches we will add : if aCol.ColumnExist(i) guard before invoking aCol[i] where ever aCol[i] is used. Please let me know if you have better suggestions for handling nullptr in aCols vector. Thanks.I had to change the int version of [] operator of ScColContainer to SCCOLROW as I found instances of such usage in table*.cxxI have changed the rest of the patch as per your suggestions in the latest.

Please let me know if you have better suggestions for handling nullptr in aCols vector. Thanks.I had to change the int version of [] operator of ScColContainer to SCCOLROW as I found instances of such usage in table*.cxxI have changed the rest of the patch as per your suggestions in the latest.

text: Patch Set 4:Hmm. That will most likely hurt us later but well we can deal with it then.I had chats with Kohei and Eike and I think the solution that seems to be acceptable to all of us is to use a std::vector<ScColumn*> or std::vector<std::unique_ptr<ScColumn>> with the additional requirement that there are no nullptr entries.This provides us with some benefits compared to the version without the additional requirement and the version based on std::vector<ScColumn>. We don't need to check every entry while iterating through columns (just compare once against std::vector::size) and we don't need to worry that pointers to ScColumn instances become invalid when we insert or remove a column. I hope this helps you for the rest of the work.

text: Patch Set 1:Thank you for your valuable feedback. As per my understanding, we cannot tell with certainty if the last entry is a cell name or not without invoking the formula engine. We cannot use a flag to keep track of the last entry because it could have been typed in, so there won't be a trigger for the flag.   The current solution does not cover all situations (for example, if the last letter is a space character), but I think it would cover the most common use cases, without having to invoke formula engine  with every change.If you think the formula is getting parsed with each change already, or if you think it won't be much of an overhead, then if you could give me some pointers, I could use that in the solution.Thanks
Text: Patch Set 1:Thank you for your valuable feedback. As per my understanding, we cannot tell with certainty if the last entry is a cell name or not without invoking the formula engine. We cannot use a flag to keep track of the last entry because it could have been typed in, so there won't be a trigger for the flag.   The current solution does not cover all situations (for example, if the last letter is a space character), but I think it would cover the most common use cases, without having to invoke formula engine  with every change.If you think the formula is getting parsed with each change already, or if you think it won't be much of an overhead, then if you could give me some pointers, I could use that in the solution.Thanks

text: Patch Set 2:> Hi Eike, Thanks for the review. I have taken only the use case of > copying a single row to a single and multiple destination. The bug > description and the bibisected commit mentions only the single row > use case. Can this use case mentioned in example be handled > separately?No. Even if the bug mentions only single row, if fixing only the bug case breaks other behavior it is not a good fix if it introduces regressions in other areas. > The code flow for single row selection and multiple row > are different too.Then you need to handle it in a way that changing one doesn't break the other.
Text: Patch Set 2:> Hi Eike, Thanks for the review. I have taken only the use case of > copying a single row to a single and multiple destination. text: Patch Set 3:The changed line writes a double quoted string to the file, probably because the '--accept' parameter already uses single quotes. Therefore I thought you already need to escape the double quotes $DBGARGS, as it will end in the file, which uses then for the "-ex" string. I'm a bit lost in escaping and indirection here...printf " -ex __\"__set args --norestore --nologo '--accept=pipe,name=$(USER);urp;' %s __\"__" "$(DBGARGS)"So my idea was to just escape double quotes and you're as good as it can get.
Text: Patch Set 3:The changed line writes a double quoted string to the file, probably because the '--accept' parameter already uses single quotes. Therefore I thought you already need to escape the double quotes $DBGARGS, as it will end in the file, which uses then for the "-ex" string. I'm a bit lost in escaping and indirection here...printf " -ex __\"__set args --norestore --nologo '--accept=pipe,name=$(USER);urp;' %s __\"__" "$(DBGARGS)"So my idea was to just escape double quotes and you're as good as it can get.

text: Patch Set 2:Hi Armin, thanks for reviewing.In CSS2, the suggested scaling factor between adjacents is 1.2: https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#propdef-font-size. So, 1.44 = 1.2 * 1.2 and 1.728 = 1.2 * 1.2 * 1.2. I thought I wrote I comment but it looks I forgot it.
Text: Patch Set 2:Hi Armin, thanks for reviewing.In CSS2, the suggested scaling factor between adjacents is 1.2: https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#propdef-font-size. So, 1.44 = 1.2 * 1.2 and 1.728 = 1.2 * 1.2 * 1.2. I thought I wrote I comment but it looks I forgot it.

text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2Hi Xisco,okay, then it should be ready, I'll add it :-)I think it makes absolute sense to add the patch, to secure the precious work and to have a reference for later. The SVG filter itself is a good thing, it may be used as pattern for other importers. It's basic functionality to convert SVG XML to ODF XML is a good basic functionality, the only reasons to 'park' it now and not to invest more work is that SVGIO is capable of more features, that the XML conversion is limited in getting perfect due to ODF restrictions and that it is too much work to develop both. I hope on You to help with SVGIO in the future - it's not yet perfect, too ;-)
Text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2Hi Xisco,okay, then it should be ready, I'll add it :-)I think it makes absolute sense to add the patch, to secure the precious work and to have a reference for later. The SVG filter itself is a good thing, it may be used as pattern for other importers. It's basic functionality to convert SVG XML to ODF XML is a good basic functionality, the only reasons to 'park' it now and not to invest more work is that SVGIO is capable of more features, that the XML conversion is limited in getting perfect due to ODF restrictions and that it is too much work to develop both. I hope on You to help with SVGIO in the future - it's not yet perfect, too ;-)

text: Patch Set 1:> Any reason why he couldn't upload the patch himself?Yes there is. >  > From my POV that's the primary point of the easy hacks to get the > LO build and Gerrit upload working for new developersÔÇªNot only, the easy hacks are also there to let new developers have a early success. It is a total package, we do not need easy hacks to build LO or setup gerrit, but we need new developers experience the whole route, including having contributed.In this case, Dipankar had done all the right things, including gerrit, but had a network problem which probably needs a sysadmin, so I deemed it correct to help him, as I help quite a number of new developers.

text: Patch Set 3:> > Now, these files are way behind master. > > I can commit a changeset for these 3 files that will make them > > "auto-mergeable" with current master. Should I? >  > Ok, I think I was wrong when I said that. > I can't modify the files so that they auto-merge with master. >  > I thought that by adding the changes that the master files already > have (putting this barch's files on the expected final state) git > would be able to automatically resolve the merge conflicts. But I > was wrong.Git can not do magic, even though it is pretty good (it can merge as long as the changes are in different functions). Do you want to give it a try ?
Text: Patch Set 3:> > Now, these files are way behind master. > > I can commit a changeset for these 3 files that will make them > > "auto-mergeable" with current master. Should I? >  > Ok, I think I was wrong when I said that. > I can't modify the files so that they auto-merge with master. >  > I thought that by adding the changes that the master files already > have (putting this barch's files on the expected final state) git > would be able to automatically resolve the merge conflicts. But I > was wrong.Git can not do magic, even though it is pretty good (it can merge as long as the changes are in different functions). Do you want to give it a try ?

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1The naming is ~irrelevant to me; but it should be consistent between 5-1 to master and then locked down IMHO.JanI - we want to see how many threads there are that can run concurrently to start implementing code that best exploits the parallelism out there. The exact processor geometry etc. is too much potentially identifying information IMHO.As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1The naming is ~irrelevant to me; but it should be consistent between 5-1 to master and then locked down IMHO.JanI - we want to see how many threads there are that can run concurrently to start implementing code that best exploits the parallelism out there. The exact processor geometry etc. is too much potentially identifying information IMHO.As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.

text: Patch Set 1: -Code-Review> As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.Happen to disagree. "CPU threads" is for me very different from "threads", but of course might be because I am too deep into how the CPU works.Will not block this, but neither promote it.
Text: Patch Set 1: -Code-Review> As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.Happen to disagree. "CPU threads" is for me very different from "threads", but of course might be because I am too deep into how the CPU works.Will not block this, but neither promote it.

text: Patch Set 1:what's called might be bikeshedding, what certainly is *NOT* is how to deal with reviewers' comments.If people make effort to review and comment on specific changes, than you really should not go and commit regardless not mentioning the concerns at all.Writing "I don't think is necessary" or something like that is OK, just flag that comment as done and be fine. But not doing anything to acknowledge it is a nogo.I also don't care about that naming, otherwise I'd given -1
Text: Patch Set 1:what's called might be bikeshedding, what certainly is *NOT* is how to deal with reviewers' comments.If people make effort to review and comment on specific changes, than you really should not go and commit regardless not mentioning the concerns at all.Writing "I don't think is necessary" or something like that is OK, just flag that comment as done and be fine. But not doing anything to acknowledge it is a nogo.I also don't care about that naming, otherwise I'd given -1

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1You didn't remove the "Insert -> Object -> Insert Plugin" dialouge box (which freezes if you touch it). I added a warning for 5.1 when inserting a plugin - https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/18756/>NPAPI support was discontinued by major browser vendors for years now.To be fair, Mozilla just announced there plan to deprecate it over the next 1-2 years, with a possible exception for Flash.Anyway, as this would just go to master, I think that works out.

text: Patch Set 3:So we just discussed this in the Design Call and came to the following conclusion:Instead of changing the mode of the button, we want to switch icons. So we'll have one icon for the save button indicating that the document is saved (the current one) and one that it has changed (the current one with a decorator, like a start or something).We'll also enable the save button always, no matter the state of the document, so that only the icon changes, but the button is always clickable.In the same run, we'll remove the configuration option for "enable save always" from the options dialogAt last, we'll hide save as from the toolbar.Maxim, Jay, hope you are fine with that?!Maxim, do you have time to work on this?
Text: Patch Set 3:So we just discussed this in the Design Call and came to the following conclusion:Instead of changing the mode of the button, we want to switch icons. So we'll have one icon for the save button indicating that the document is saved (the current one) and one that it has changed (the current one with a decorator, like a start or something).We'll also enable the save button always, no matter the state of the document, so that only the icon changes, but the button is always clickable.In the same run, we'll remove the configuration option for "enable save always" from the options dialogAt last, we'll hide save as from the toolbar.Maxim, Jay, hope you are fine with that?!Maxim, do you have time to work on this?

Andreas has agreed to create an icon. Until then you can use a placeholder icon.

text: Patch Set 3:> Instead of changing the mode of the button, we want to switch icons. So we'll have one icon for the save button indicating that the document is saved (the current one) and one that it has changed (the current one with a decorator, like a start or something).I think using the SaveAs icon would be fine.> We'll also enable the save button always, no matter the state of the document, so that only the icon changes, but the button is always clickable.Then i would suggest that we create a new uno command for this Save+SaveAs feature so that File > Save is disabled and functions checking the .uno:Save commands state wont think the file has been modified.
Text: Patch Set 3:> Instead of changing the mode of the button, we want to switch icons. So we'll have one icon for the save button indicating that the document is saved (the current one) and one that it has changed (the current one with a decorator, like a start or something).I think using the SaveAs icon would be fine.> We'll also enable the save button always, no matter the state of the document, so that only the icon changes, but the button is always clickable.Then i would suggest that we create a new uno command for this Save+SaveAs feature so that File > Save is disabled and functions checking the .uno:Save commands state wont think the file has been modified.

text: Patch Set 7:It is safe in the sense that all UnitTests work plus some tests that I have done extra. It allows bigger docs be loaded on 32bit systems. For not having problems only on win we could think about doing this for all systems, but thit would put risk on these versions without need.I think if problems on win come in these will be identifyable using bibisect pretty reliable.One more thing: When you work on a new doc there will be no UNO API objects until you save or load it (or use any UNO script on it), so when import works well (and it does for all autotests) there will be no difference.

text: Patch Set 4:Hi Noel, good work. Using Primitive2DContainer makes things more isolated for the future. I would have added members for appending and getting the uno::Sequence< Primitive2DReference >, made the vector not a base class, but a member and the uno::Sequence a 2nd member to buffer access, and the BasePrimitive3D stuff...For now this solves the immanent performance problem and is a good first step to take!
Text: Patch Set 4:Hi Noel, good work. Using Primitive2DContainer makes things more isolated for the future. I would have added members for appending and getting the uno::Sequence< Primitive2DReference >, made the vector not a base class, but a member and the uno::Sequence a 2nd member to buffer access, and the BasePrimitive3D stuff...For now this solves the immanent performance problem and is a good first step to take!

text: Patch Set 4:> I would have added members for appending > and getting the uno::Sequence< Primitive2DReference >, made thealready did that in the second patch. > vector not a base class, but a member Did think about that, but did not want to repeat all of the required stuff to make it look like an STL container. > and the uno::Sequence a 2nd > member to buffer access, No need to buffer access, the Sequence is almost never required, and normally only once we are done with the vector.> and the BasePrimitive3D stuff...will get to that in a later patch.Thanks for the review!

text: Patch Set 1:So this feels like have opened a can of worms. My "trick" with the StartOfContent node in AppendDoc to prevent content merging and prevent implementing single-node copy in CopyRange bites here. My first attempt  already broke the Redline handling (which Michael fixed by reverting my patch).Not sure if I should start an other attempt on the single-node copy and an additional parameter to prevent node merging in case of document copying...But since I had to rely on the special semantics of CopyRange here, this results in an additional node compared to the originally intended CopyRange behavior.This patch actually fixes the crash for me and correctly copies the bookmarks. I should add a unit test, but it's late, so I'll add a unit test for bookmark copying in MM tomorrow.Any better ideas?
Text: Patch Set 1:So this feels like have opened a can of worms. text: Patch Set 2:> I have changed this to allow adjacent border deletions only. It no > more turns on the adjacent cell borders.The more I think about this automatic behavior the less I like it..silently modifying attributions of cells that are not selected IMHO isa no-no. There will always be situations where the user does not expectthe result, for example if a row of cells has a thick bottom border asfor header cells, and cells of the table below have thin borders.Removing the thin borders should not remove the adjacent thick border aswell.Though Excel has this behavior, because there adjacent cells share theborder and removing it from one cell removes it also from the adjacentcell.The best would be to offer a checkbox "Remove border from adjacent cellsas well" or some such, to be activated only if borders are to beremoved, and only if checked remove borders from envelope cells.Maybe a second correct attempt, if we don't want another checkbox, couldbe to remove an adjacent border only if it has the same attributes(color, width, style), but that would mean having to compare allenvelope cells with their selected neighbour instead of doing it in onego. > I tested in 5.0. If we turn on all four borders of a cell, then we > wont be able to delete one border at a time using sidebar or the > format cell dialog. For deletion of a particular border  ( say > right ) we have to set "no borders" first, then turn on all borders > except right.? Works for me in the Format Cells dialog. Note that there the bordersare tristate, "Border", "Don't care" (which kicks in if borders aredifferent among selected cells) and "Border". So you may have to clicktwice to remove an existent border.
Text: Patch Set 2:> I have changed this to allow adjacent border deletions only. It no > more turns on the adjacent cell borders.The more I think about this automatic behavior the less I like it..silently modifying attributions of cells that are not selected IMHO isa no-no. There will always be situations where the user does not expectthe result, for example if a row of cells has a thick bottom border asfor header cells, and cells of the table below have thin borders.Removing the thin borders should not remove the adjacent thick border aswell.Though Excel has this behavior, because there adjacent cells share theborder and removing it from one cell removes it also from the adjacentcell.The best would be to offer a checkbox "Remove border from adjacent cellsas well" or some such, to be activated only if borders are to beremoved, and only if checked remove borders from envelope cells.Maybe a second correct attempt, if we don't want another checkbox, couldbe to remove an adjacent border only if it has the same attributes(color, width, style), but that would mean having to compare allenvelope cells with their selected neighbour instead of doing it in onego. > I tested in 5.0. If we turn on all four borders of a cell, then we > wont be able to delete one border at a time using sidebar or the > format cell dialog. For deletion of a particular border  ( say > right ) we have to set "no borders" first, then turn on all borders > except right.? Works for me in the Format Cells dialog. Note that there the bordersare tristate, "Border", "Don't care" (which kicks in if borders aredifferent among selected cells) and "Border". So you may have to clicktwice to remove an existent border.

text: Patch Set 3:Yes, lightening the calc cell grid to #cccccc, and using a darker gray #666666  for the automatic pagebreak makes page breaks in the calc UI more visible than the defined COL_LIGHTGRAY #c0c0c0 and COL_GRAY #808080.  But, it seems like we should expand the defined colors in color.hxx and then use that definition rather than continually adding HEX color one-by-one to UI elements?
Text: Patch Set 3:Yes, lightening the calc cell grid to #cccccc, and using a darker gray #666666  for the automatic pagebreak makes page breaks in the calc UI more visible than the defined COL_LIGHTGRAY #c0c0c0 and COL_GRAY #808080.  But, it seems like we should expand the defined colors in color.hxx and then use that definition rather than continually adding HEX color one-by-one to UI elements?

Text: Patch Set 4:Michael, many thanks for the review. I have fixed the name, also improved the patch to limit GetObject only at repeated image loading/overloading, and pushed to the master. (The  repeated image loading could be a result of the repaint triggered by the second call of GetObject - after the successful asynchronous loading of an image.)

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1This is a starter so that at least a case-sensitive matching list is picked if one exists instead of a case-insensitive one that just happens to be encountered before.Further improvements in case handling can be made in follow-up changes.Also, currently there is no differentiation if lists differ by order of entries, e.g. with lists aaa,bbb,ccc and aaa,ccc,bbb and cells aaa,ccc selected, still aaa,bbb,ccc is picked.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1This is a starter so that at least a case-sensitive matching list is picked if one exists instead of a case-insensitive one that just happens to be encountered before.Further improvements in case handling can be made in follow-up changes.Also, currently there is no differentiation if lists differ by order of entries, e.g. with lists aaa,bbb,ccc and aaa,ccc,bbb and cells aaa,ccc selected, still aaa,bbb,ccc is picked.

text: Patch Set 3:Jan: the summary line is precious...adding solved/fixed and other editorial words isnot very informative.. think of it in the context of someone scouring the log to find a patch related to some situation/bugs'solved' is really not adding any value to the message.2/ referenceing the source is very useful, so it is a good thing to bug the cid number here..but fro grepability is it conventional to use the <prefix>#<number>notation. it make it easier to greap for human and easier to have machine-automated linking to external reference while limiting the false positive.in doubt git log --grep can help to find how other have done it$ git log --grep "^coverity#" --format=oneline | wc -l    5185$ git log --grep "^cid#" --format=oneline | wc -l     271$ git log --grep "^CID#" --format=oneline | wc -l     260$ git log --grep "^CID " --format=oneline | wc -l       2

text: Patch Set 1:To elaborate on how to amend a patch: The trick here is preserving the same Change-Id of the commit message, so that Gerrit recognizes it should be on the same thread. Locally, you do a new commit, then you do `git rebase -i HEAD~2' to squash that with the previous commit. Then you push and Gerrit will detect your updated squashed commit as a new version (or ÔÇ£patch setÔÇØ) without creating a new thread. Hope this helps!
Text: Patch Set 1:To elaborate on how to amend a patch: The trick here is preserving the same Change-Id of the commit message, so that Gerrit recognizes it should be on the same thread. Locally, you do a new commit, then you do `git rebase -i HEAD~2' to squash that with the previous commit. Then you push and Gerrit will detect your updated squashed commit as a new version (or 脭脟拢patch set脭脟脴) without creating a new thread. Hope this helps!

text: Patch Set 1:> To elaborate on how to amend a patch: The trick here is preserving > the same Change-Id of the commit message, so that Gerrit recognizes > it should be on the same thread. Locally, you do a new commit, then > you do `git rebase -i HEAD~2' to squash that with the previous > commit.Git commit --amend is a much easier way to do that.iow checkout your gerrit patchdo the modificationscommit them using --amendgit push origin HEAD:refs/for/master Then you push and Gerrit will detect your updated squashed > commit as a new version (or ÔÇ£patch setÔÇØ) without creating a new > thread. Hope this helps!

Hope this helps!

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2Ashod, std::make_unique is C++14, and o3tl::make_unique is LO-internal API, while lokdocview uses LO's public API only, so it's intentional that this construct is used here.Pranav, here are my numbers, this patch looks like a great improvement to me:- without patch: mem usage of android ODT after load according to top (RES): 254500, after typing 30 "8": 288168- with patch: 257008, after typing 30 "8": 258064So simplifying the situation: typing 30 chars used to result in a mem leak of the 30MB range, while now it is in the 1MB range. :-)If valgrind still points out something, let's deal with that in a follow-up patch.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2Ashod, std::make_unique is C++14, and o3tl::make_unique is LO-internal API, while lokdocview uses LO's public API only, so it's intentional that this construct is used here.Pranav, here are my numbers, this patch looks like a great improvement to me:- without patch: mem usage of android ODT after load according to top (RES): 254500, after typing 30 "8": 288168- with patch: 257008, after typing 30 "8": 258064So simplifying the situation: typing 30 chars used to result in a mem leak of the 30MB range, while now it is in the 1MB range. :-)If valgrind still points out something, let's deal with that in a follow-up patch.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Thanks, works.But, when testing I found (unrelated to this) that an ordinary number string like 123 is converted too, in this case to ─ú, IMHO conversion should only happen for U+ prefixed numbers. Actually I'd expect to see U+0033 when placing the cursor after 123 and hitting Alt-X, which happens for single digits.Additionally, we should prevent conversion of values below 0x20 that would result in control characters, of which some are even used as inline markers by Writer features.If you'd like to follow-up on that?

text: Patch Set 3:Thank you for your review.I think that DECODE_WITH_CHARSET is better than DECODE_TO_IURI.If the file name is "foo%2Fbar", the return value of getUnpackedValueOrDefault() will probably be "foo%252Fbar".Because the return value is url-encoded(percent-encoded).If we use DECODE_TO_IURI, decoded result will be "foo%252Fbar".If we use DECODE_WITH_CHARSET, decoded result will be "foo%2Fbar".
Text: Patch Set 3:Thank you for your review.I think that DECODE_WITH_CHARSET is better than DECODE_TO_IURI.If the file name is "foo%2Fbar", the return value of getUnpackedValueOrDefault() will probably be "foo%252Fbar".Because the return value is url-encoded(percent-encoded).If we use DECODE_TO_IURI, decoded result will be "foo%252Fbar".If we use DECODE_WITH_CHARSET, decoded result will be "foo%2Fbar".

text: Patch Set 1:This bug could be exhibiting multiple problems at higher levels, so I'm considering this fix to be a band-aid.  These problems are way above my expertise to comment on or investigate (see the bug report for background information.)1.)  I'd guess that adding support for some InsertObjectXXX toolbar functions registers a binding for a new textsh, which becomes dirty for every key press.  That seems expensive and buggy.  It is these "outside events" that are affecting the selection.2.)  I can't even guess at the circumstance that requires the popping of a cursor to cancel a selection.  Why is that code even in wrtsh1?  It seems to have been there since day1 and I have no idea how to identify whether it would be safe to remove it now.3.)  I hope there aren't any ÔÇ£necessary consequencesÔÇØ of calling push/pop that I've lost in bypassing them.  I think my proposed change is the least intrusive method of resolving this MAB quickly.4.)  I'm dancing around with cursorÔåÆHasMark(), shellÔåÆHasSelection() somewhere, and shellÔåÆIsSelection() with cursor presently in a selection.  Am I correct in equating HasSelection with HasMark?  Otherwise, the fix could be further limited to IsSelection.

text: Patch Set 2:I don't think that the document will be rendered differently once LibreOffice saves it. I agree that this fix is not ideal, but it would take a lot more effort to solve it correctly.All the labels are treated as strings, not as numbers.  So we could do that we apply the number format on import, and still keep the result (like "Oct-12") as string, which would make them displaying nicely. The drawback is the export / roundtrip, as then the string with the applied number format would get saved.  But I believe will make the situation for export (roundtrip) not much worse than currently, because we are exporting the labels as strings anyway, not as numbers, so now after roundtrip, the user sees 41183 instead of Oct-12 anyway.
Text: Patch Set 2:I don't think that the document will be rendered differently once LibreOffice saves it. I agree that this fix is not ideal, but it would take a lot more effort to solve it correctly.All the labels are treated as strings, not as numbers.  So we could do that we apply the number format on import, and still keep the result (like "Oct-12") as string, which would make them displaying nicely. The drawback is the export / roundtrip, as then the string with the applied number format would get saved.  But I believe will make the situation for export (roundtrip) not much worse than currently, because we are exporting the labels as strings anyway, not as numbers, so now after roundtrip, the user sees 41183 instead of Oct-12 anyway.

text: Patch Set 2:> Also, make sure that if you are changing a name of an argument in a> function body, you should also change it in a declaration, which> often is in a different file.Did you find a place where I did this wrong? text: Patch Set 1:Do we know the exact patchlevel that the parameters for CXXRecordDecl::forallBases were changed? If so, it may be better to use.    #if __clang_major__ == 3 && __clang_minor__ < 7 && __clang_patchlevel < xAs stated in the bug report I could be wrong here, but this is what I got to compile on my computer. Comments or constructive criticism are welcome!
Text: Patch Set 1:Do we know the exact patchlevel that the parameters for CXXRecordDecl::forallBases were changed? If so, it may be better to use.    #if __clang_major__ == 3 && __clang_minor__ < 7 && __clang_patchlevel < xAs stated in the bug report I could be wrong here, but this is what I got to compile on my computer. Comments or constructive criticism are welcome!

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)> Do we know the exact patchlevel that the parameters for > CXXRecordDecl::forallBases were changed? If so, it may be better to > use. >  > #if __clang_major__ == 3 && __clang_minor__ < 7 && > __clang_patchlevel < x >  > As stated in the bug report I could be wrong here, but this is what > I got to compile on my computer. Comments or constructive criticism > are welcome!I routinely build the compilerplugins code against current builds of Clang trunk.  When there is breakage, I add #if blocks using the upcoming __clang_major/minor__ versions, but it may be the case that sometimes these breaking changes will not actually appear in that (then upcoming) version, but will only remain on trunk (towards the next version).  I have never yet seen it necessary to discriminate based on __clang_patchlevel.

When there is breakage, I add #if blocks using the upcoming __clang_major/minor__ versions, but it may be the case that sometimes these breaking changes will not actually appear in that (then upcoming) version, but will only remain on trunk (towards the next version).  I have never yet seen it necessary to discriminate based on __clang_patchlevel.

What OS were you running it under (I only tested under Windows)?

text: Patch Set 6:> What i saw wasnt similar to the original description, as it didnt > ask for left and right page margins to disappear. About the margins > at the top and bottom of each page, the top margin on the first > page and bottom margin on the last page shouldnt disappear. I'm not > sure whenever headers and footers should disappear either, but i'd > have to double check in MSO to know for certain. > I see what you mean now. As I said, I didn't try to replicate MSO exactly or the bug report, just a first hack at the request to reduce/hide whitespace. And, IMHO, I don't see why we should clone the feature as-is from MSO (or any other) instead of deciding what would be best in terms of usability for our users (myself being a heavy user of Writer).I don't have a preference except to make the feature as useful as possible. In that respect, left/right margins can be reduced in book- and multi-page views (and could be left as-is in the single-page view).I would really like to get UI designer and user feedback here, as this is a usability feature, not a technical one per-se.
Text: Patch Set 6:> What i saw wasnt similar to the original description, as it didnt > ask for left and right page margins to disappear. About the margins > at the top and bottom of each page, the top margin on the first > page and bottom margin on the last page shouldnt disappear. I'm not > sure whenever headers and footers should disappear either, but i'd > have to double check in MSO to know for certain. > I see what you mean now. As I said, I didn't try to replicate MSO exactly or the bug report, just a first hack at the request to reduce/hide whitespace. And, IMHO, I don't see why we should clone the feature as-is from MSO (or any other) instead of deciding what would be best in terms of usability for our users (myself being a heavy user of Writer).I don't have a preference except to make the feature as useful as possible. In that respect, left/right margins can be reduced in book- and multi-page views (and could be left as-is in the single-page view).I would really like to get UI designer and user feedback here, as this is a usability feature, not a technical one per-se.

text: Patch Set 4:Also I need to note, that the bugdoc itself is slightly ill-formed. The number of records in its header is reported 21, while it contains 22 records in total (including header and EOF). The [MS-EMF] specifies that ALL records must be counted there (the example EMF there confirms that), but the producer of the bugdoc clearly counts only records following header. LO does nothing special on EOF record (just makes hard reset of number of records left to zero), that's why it's safe reading such files.
Text: Patch Set 4:Also I need to note, that the bugdoc itself is slightly ill-formed. The number of records in its header is reported 21, while it contains 22 records in total (including header and EOF). The [MS-EMF] specifies that ALL records must be counted there (the example EMF there confirms that), but the producer of the bugdoc clearly counts only records following header. LO does nothing special on EOF record (just makes hard reset of number of records left to zero), that's why it's safe reading such files.

text: Patch Set 5:(2 comments)> don't really know what this does :-), but it has a unit test and > the build passesI know this has already been merged but Laurent asked me to look at this (and only now I am getting a chance)As far as I understand it ('cause I am not so familiar with this stuff either and anything I did know I have mostly forgotten) this looks like in general the correct approach.There needs to be a version bump for the binary format, there is already a version bump prepared (that was missed) see http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/s?refs=B_EXT_IMG_VERSION&project=core  E.g. the binary format was supposed to be changed to B_EXT_IMG_VERSION but it never happened, probably it was around the time of openoffice->libreoffice or something I can't remember, I do remember we were waiting for a new release to bump the version.  I think all that is required is to adjust http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/basic/source/classes/sbxmod.cxx#1809 (or get rid of that method and adjust the caller (in scriptcont) to pass the current binary format versionplease see https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=64377needless to say that stuff needs to be retested too (but it would be good to get it in)It is of course possible to juggle the version numbers (and code) in such away to implement just this new update to the binary format (and skip enabling aoo#64377) that's fine too, but... I think a version bump in necessary in anycase
Text: Patch Set 5:(2 comments)> don't really know what this does :-), but it has a unit test and > the build passesI know this has already been merged but Laurent asked me to look at this (and only now I am getting a chance)As far as I understand it ('cause I am not so familiar with this stuff either and anything I did know I have mostly forgotten) this looks like in general the correct approach.There needs to be a version bump for the binary format, there is already a version bump prepared (that was missed) see http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/s?refs=B_EXT_IMG_VERSION&project=core  E.g. the binary format was supposed to be changed to B_EXT_IMG_VERSION but it never happened, probably it was around the time of openoffice->libreoffice or something I can't remember, I do remember we were waiting for a new release to bump the version.  I think all that is required is to adjust http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/basic/source/classes/sbxmod.cxx#1809 (or get rid of that method and adjust the caller (in scriptcont) to pass the current binary format versionplease see https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=64377needless to say that stuff needs to be retested too (but it would be good to get it in)It is of course possible to juggle the version numbers (and code) in such away to implement just this new update to the binary format (and skip enabling aoo#64377) that's fine too, but... I think a version bump in necessary in anycase

text: Patch Set 2:6343754e310a589cb49e2a1da0cd68472571179d "cppcheck:noExplicitConstructor" broke e.g.  m_xCachedProps.reset(      new CachableContentProperties( aResource ) );in Content::open (ucb/source/ucp/webdav/webdavcontent.cxx) by removing the possibility to implicitly convert from aResource of type DAVResource to ContentProperties (as expected as arg to CachableContentProperties ctor) via (non-explicit) ContentProperties ctor.However, this change here effectively elides the original converting ContentProperties ctor call, but that ctor e.g. has special-handling code for a "Title" property.  Are you sure this change is fine?
Text: Patch Set 2:6343754e310a589cb49e2a1da0cd68472571179d "cppcheck:noExplicitConstructor" broke e.g.  m_xCachedProps.reset(      new CachableContentProperties( aResource ) );in Content::open (ucb/source/ucp/webdav/webdavcontent.cxx) by removing the possibility to implicitly convert from aResource of type DAVResource to ContentProperties (as expected as arg to CachableContentProperties ctor) via (non-explicit) ContentProperties ctor.However, this change here effectively elides the original converting ContentProperties ctor call, but that ctor e.g. has special-handling code for a "Title" property.  Are you sure this change is fine?

text: Patch Set 3:Regarding the impact of this patch to existing odf document:a) if text grid in the page style isn't enabled, it is not affected.b) if text grid is enabled, perceived vertical alignment of contents in table cells might change, especially for cells where vertical alignment was set to center or bottom would become effective with the patch.Note that text grid is a feature designed specifically for CJK users. In reality I never seen someone turn it on manually or on purpose. Most of the case users are processing document created by MSWord. I estimate that impact will be minor, and is positive if any.
Text: Patch Set 3:Regarding the impact of this patch to existing odf document:a) if text grid in the page style isn't enabled, it is not affected.b) if text grid is enabled, perceived vertical alignment of contents in table cells might change, especially for cells where vertical alignment was set to center or bottom would become effective with the patch.Note that text grid is a feature designed specifically for CJK users. In reality I never seen someone turn it on manually or on purpose. Most of the case users are processing document created by MSWord. I estimate that impact will be minor, and is positive if any.

text: Patch Set 1:>What is the expected gain here?I was in the process of cleaning up o3tl/compat_functional, as many of the functors are derived from unary_function and binary_function, which are deprecated. This is the only use case of project2nd. As a result, it may not be worthwhile to keep a globally available templated functor for a single use case. I thought it might make more sense to remove the globally available templated funtor and repeat what is done in paletteformats.hxx andpixelformatadapters.hxx.Thanks for the input. I'm still new to this, so constructive criticism is very welcome!
Text: Patch Set 1:>What is the expected gain here?I was in the process of cleaning up o3tl/compat_functional, as many of the functors are derived from unary_function and binary_function, which are deprecated. This is the only use case of project2nd. As a result, it may not be worthwhile to keep a globally available templated functor for a single use case. I thought it might make more sense to remove the globally available templated funtor and repeat what is done in paletteformats.hxx andpixelformatadapters.hxx.Thanks for the input. I'm still new to this, so constructive criticism is very welcome!

text: Patch Set 1:I changed 2 bits:-don't give a suggestion when editing (inserting characters) and the character next to the caret is alphanumeric-don't give a suggestion when editing in conditions where a tip would be shown below (with argument tips)The agressiveness is gone.The only 'drawback' is when you start with=ABS(2)start edit, and remove B and then move caret to the right of S. In this situation, no tip is given.If, starting with =ABS(2), you start edit, remove B and S and type S, you do get the hint.I think this behaviour is fine, but of course I'm interested in your expert opinion.
Text: Patch Set 1:I changed 2 bits:-don't give a suggestion when editing (inserting characters) and the character next to the caret is alphanumeric-don't give a suggestion when editing in conditions where a tip would be shown below (with argument tips)The agressiveness is gone.The only 'drawback' is when you start with=ABS(2)start edit, and remove B and then move caret to the right of S. In this situation, no tip is given.If, starting with =ABS(2), you start edit, remove B and S and type S, you do get the hint.I think this behaviour is fine, but of course I'm interested in your expert opinion.

text: Patch Set 4:Hi,Since this change has been merged, I always get this warning on opening a Writer document (in a --enable-debug build): warn:unotools.config:24194:1:unotools/source/config/historyoptions.cxx:479: Caught unexpected: file:///path/to/myfile.odtAny idea what's that? If it's a bug, it would be great to fix it, if not, then changing that SAL_WARN() to SAL_INFO() would be a good idea to avoid the noise.Thanks!

text: Patch Set 3:- Added license statements- Fixed (hopefully) Windows build by adding missing include for ::std::max- Fixed case that Python assert(pyuno_object) was throwing an exception because we now implement the mp_length method on all objects, but only some of them really have a length; implemented a boolean truth behaviour through PyUNONumberMethods.np_bool that yields false only for empty containers and true for all other objects, mirroring the behaviour of Python for regular lists, dicts and general objects
Text: Patch Set 3:- Added license statements- Fixed (hopefully) Windows build by adding missing include for ::std::max- Fixed case that Python assert(pyuno_object) was throwing an exception because we now implement the mp_length method on all objects, but only some of them really have a length; implemented a boolean truth behaviour through PyUNONumberMethods.np_bool that yields false only for empty containers and true for all other objects, mirroring the behaviour of Python for regular lists, dicts and general objects

text: Patch Set 4:Hi Michael, thanks for commit.Automate the attaching is, i think, not possible.But the start the VS-Debugger with the right parameter, that is possible. For that it give 2 cases to do that:1. The user must set the environment variable CPPUNITTRACE    but it is complicate (and for me to implemetation).2. The better solution is, get from the registry where VS is,    and then start the VS-Debugger.But i have at the moment no time for that, then i have made this quick solution. And in the past, under Windows, it was always the one and only solution for debugging to attach to the soffice.bin.But now the remove of the URE-Directory have solve that problem, and you can start soffice.bin directly in VS-Debugger.
Text: Patch Set 4:Hi Michael, thanks for commit.Automate the attaching is, i think, not possible.But the start the VS-Debugger with the right parameter, that is possible. For that it give 2 cases to do that:1. The user must set the environment variable CPPUNITTRACE    but it is complicate (and for me to implemetation).2. The better solution is, get from the registry where VS is,    and then start the VS-Debugger.But i have at the moment no time for that, then i have made this quick solution. And in the past, under Windows, it was always the one and only solution for debugging to attach to the soffice.bin.But now the remove of the URE-Directory have solve that problem, and you can start soffice.bin directly in VS-Debugger.

Text: Patch Set 2:thanks for working on this; it's looking fine;the only issue is that the commit does add 2 new en-US stringsthe feature as currently implemented should not be in the 4.4 release,inserting fields that cannot be stored is utterly pointless- but adding new strings is not allowed now, not surewhat to do?  can the new strings be avoided for 4.4?also when i try it i get this in the file:<loext:page-name><slide-name></loext:page-name>i think the field text should be the same as in the document display, i.e. the character content should be "Slide 1"

text: Patch Set 2:> thanks for working on this; it's looking fine; > the only issue is that the commit does add 2 new en-US strings It does, I'm well aware of that, also of the fact that the strings aren't going to be translated. However, they're only used as placeholders for export (and in master view, but come on, how many users will see them there?)   > the feature as currently implemented should not be in the 4.4 > release, > inserting fields that cannot be stored is utterly pointlessIt is. Some LibO hackers with commit rights sometimes go around and merge patches to the code they have almost no clue about. And then other LibO hackers advertise such half-baked features in release notes. > - but adding new strings is not allowed now, not sure > what to do?  can the new strings be avoided for 4.4? Either use English strings directly in C++ code (but that doesn't change the user experience, there will English strings either way), or see below: > also when i try it i get this in the file: >  > <loext:page-name><slide-name></loext:page-name> >  > i think the field text should be the same as in the document > display, i.e. the character content should be "Slide 1"<slide-name> is a placeholder and it'll be substituted by real slide name after import, during rendering. I've looked at what other fields do and some (e.g. page number SvxPageField) don't save the real content of the field either, but use a placeholder. So I did the same.For this particular 4.4 backport, we could maybe save the slide name as character content. That would nicely bypass the problem of new (and untranslated) English strings
Text: Patch Set 2:> thanks for working on this; it's looking fine; > the only issue is that the commit does add 2 new en-US strings It does, I'm well aware of that, also of the fact that the strings aren't going to be translated. However, they're only used as placeholders for export (and in master view, but come on, how many users will see them there?)   > the feature as currently implemented should not be in the 4.4 > release, > inserting fields that cannot be stored is utterly pointlessIt is. Some LibO hackers with commit rights sometimes go around and merge patches to the code they have almost no clue about. And then other LibO hackers advertise such half-baked features in release notes. > - but adding new strings is not allowed now, not sure > what to do?  can the new strings be avoided for 4.4? Either use English strings directly in C++ code (but that doesn't change the user experience, there will English strings either way), or see below: > also when i try it i get this in the file: >  > <loext:page-name><slide-name></loext:page-name> >  > i think the field text should be the same as in the document > display, i.e. the character content should be "Slide 1"<slide-name> is a placeholder and it'll be substituted by real slide name after import, during rendering. I've looked at what other fields do and some (e.g. page number SvxPageField) don't save the real content of the field either, but use a placeholder. So I did the same.For this particular 4.4 backport, we could maybe save the slide name as character content. That would nicely bypass the problem of new (and untranslated) English strings

text: Patch Set 2: Verified+1the problem with the placeholder is that it's not only exportedinside a master-page--where i agree it is correct--but alsoinside a plain draw:page element.but it is not a new problem, for the page number field i get the same:<text:page-number><number></text:page-number>also OOo 3.3 exports it this way already, so i guess the issueis that Impress developers never learned how text fields work :)the field should contain the expanded value, so that "dumb"applications that import the file but can't evaluate fieldssee the right text.hmm... ok so the placeholder shows up in the UI only when youedit a master page, which is a notoriously obscure featurethat 99% of users will never find, so it's fine with me.

text: Patch Set 11:Hi,First, thanks for improving the cell border export code, much appreciated.When submitting or reviewing patches that touch OOXML or ODF code, please build with --with-export-validation, otherwise it's easy to overlook validation problems introduced by a patch.With that option, it is required that every PPTX document that's created by a testcase is valid OOXML. This is currently the state, it would be wonderful to keep it like that. :-)I've now fixed the problem this patch exposed (see commit 6a71fc9e48654d80f9545f43066ca56103d0cf65), but it would be even better to catch those issues before the patch hits master.Thanks a lot, and for submitting/reviewing patches,Miklos
Text: Patch Set 11:Hi,First, thanks for improving the cell border export code, much appreciated.When submitting or reviewing patches that touch OOXML or ODF code, please build with --with-export-validation, otherwise it's easy to overlook validation problems introduced by a patch.With that option, it is required that every PPTX document that's created by a testcase is valid OOXML. This is currently the state, it would be wonderful to keep it like that. :-)I've now fixed the problem this patch exposed (see commit 6a71fc9e48654d80f9545f43066ca56103d0cf65), but it would be even better to catch those issues before the patch hits master.Thanks a lot, and for submitting/reviewing patches,Miklos

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2I do not think we want to add support for everyone's favourite compression method... gz is okay, as it is handled by zlib, which we already use. But anything else is highly questionable. Also note that to make this really useful for the majority of users, liblzma would have to be bundled. System liblzma is only useful for Linux distro packages.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2I do not think we want to add support for everyone's favourite compression method... gz is okay, as it is handled by zlib, which we already use. But anything else is highly questionable. Also note that to make this really useful for the majority of users, liblzma would have to be bundled. System liblzma is only useful for Linux distro packages.

text: Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1The import part looks good, and functions very well.  Great job on doing your analysis and coming up with a very well thought-out solution.Now, the only remaining issue is the saving.  Right now, when you open a csv.gz file, edits it, and hits Ctrl-S, it saves it back to the file uncompressed, while the extension is intact.  This is not ideal.I can think of 2 ways to resolve this.  The first way is to support saving it back gz compressed, by somehow storing the information that this file has been uncompressed and using that information and trigger gz compression on saving.  In this scenario, you need to be careful not to compress on save when the user decides to save the file with a different name.  There would be other corner cases you'd have to handle when going this route. Personally I don't like this solution.The 2nd way is to load the file read only when the file is automatically uncompressed during file detection.  This way, when the user wants to edit it and re-save it, she won't be able to overwrite the original file.  I personally like this solution.Here is the gotcha, though.  Forcing a read-only load is as easy as setting the read only flag to true with the media descriptor, which will prompt you that the document has been opened read only, and to edit it, the user will need to click "Edit document" to create a new document instance.  When you do that, Calc will still load the compressed stream into the 2nd document instance, not the uncompressed version.  This needs to be addressed.I hope this will not be too much trouble to solve.  Good luck!
Text: Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1The import part looks good, and functions very well.  Great job on doing your analysis and coming up with a very well thought-out solution.Now, the only remaining issue is the saving.  Right now, when you open a csv.gz file, edits it, and hits Ctrl-S, it saves it back to the file uncompressed, while the extension is intact.  This is not ideal.I can think of 2 ways to resolve this.  The first way is to support saving it back gz compressed, by somehow storing the information that this file has been uncompressed and using that information and trigger gz compression on saving.  In this scenario, you need to be careful not to compress on save when the user decides to save the file with a different name.  There would be other corner cases you'd have to handle when going this route. Personally I don't like this solution.The 2nd way is to load the file read only when the file is automatically uncompressed during file detection.  This way, when the user wants to edit it and re-save it, she won't be able to overwrite the original file.  I personally like this solution.Here is the gotcha, though.  Forcing a read-only load is as easy as setting the read only flag to true with the media descriptor, which will prompt you that the document has been opened read only, and to edit it, the user will need to click "Edit document" to create a new document instance.  When you do that, Calc will still load the compressed stream into the 2nd document instance, not the uncompressed version.  This needs to be addressed.I hope this will not be too much trouble to solve.  Good luck!

text: Patch Set 8:Great analysis!  I personally think that (assuming that it works) your approach 3) is the best approach under the circumstance.  Could you make the change for that and update your patch?  I'd like to give that a spin.One very minor thing I would change is to switch from replaceFirst() to copy() to get a substring of the original URL in order to remove the .gz extension.  Using replaceFirst is fine, but I personally find using the copy() method more "natural" for that sort of use given that you already have the position of the ".gz" string.  You can use nIdx as the "length" of the new substring when using copy().Thanks a lot!
Text: Patch Set 8:Great analysis!  I personally think that (assuming that it works) your approach 3) is the best approach under the circumstance.  Could you make the change for that and update your patch?  I'd like to give that a spin.One very minor thing I would change is to switch from replaceFirst() to copy() to get a substring of the original URL in order to remove the .gz extension.  Using replaceFirst is fine, but I personally find using the copy() method more "natural" for that sort of use given that you already have the position of the ".gz" string.  You can use nIdx as the "length" of the new substring when using copy().Thanks a lot!

text: Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1Thanks. It works quite well. Though I still think that loading it read-only and somehow getting the issue with clicking the 'Edit Document' resolved would be the best approach, getting that to work would probably involve re-using the already loaded input stream rather than loading the content from the file again, which may involve more work than we are willing to invest at the moment.I've found another minor issue though.  When the csv.gz file is set read only i.e. set chmod 0444 on the file, it still loads the compressed stream.  I wonder this is the issue similar to the earlier one we encountered?
Text: Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1Thanks. It works quite well. Though I still think that loading it read-only and somehow getting the issue with clicking the 'Edit Document' resolved would be the best approach, getting that to work would probably involve re-using the already loaded input stream rather than loading the content from the file again, which may involve more work than we are willing to invest at the moment.I've found another minor issue though.  When the csv.gz file is set read only i.e. set chmod 0444 on the file, it still loads the compressed stream.  I wonder this is the issue similar to the earlier one we encountered?

text: Patch Set 10:Yup, it works well. Thanks a lot for your patience!One minor issue, which I think we can ignore for now, is that when opening an read-only csv.gz file, it opens as non-read-only document.  I think ideally we should be loading such file as read-only just to be consistent with how it works with all the other format types, but we can just declare that as a known issue and handle it in the future (if we decide to).I'll push this change shortly.
Text: Patch Set 10:Yup, it works well. Thanks a lot for your patience!One minor issue, which I think we can ignore for now, is that when opening an read-only csv.gz file, it opens as non-read-only document.  I think ideally we should be loading such file as read-only just to be consistent with how it works with all the other format types, but we can just declare that as a known issue and handle it in the future (if we decide to).I'll push this change shortly.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Adolfo, Thanks for looking over this; it's great to get an extra review. The reason for this work, is to ensure that duplicate icons have been compressed equally. The next step in the work is to identify bit identical duplicates (via MD5 check). This patch needs to be integrated first to make the next steps easier. The repeated localised CMD/ icons (Bold, Italic, etc) were a deliberate decision by the icon theme designer, and is due to how we build and pack themes. They must remain but will be fixed in a future patch.  Please could you leave Kendy to Merge this- he is familiar with my work and I'd also like his feedback.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Adolfo, Thanks for looking over this; it's great to get an extra review. The reason for this work, is to ensure that duplicate icons have been compressed equally. The next step in the work is to identify bit identical duplicates (via MD5 check). This patch needs to be integrated first to make the next steps easier. The repeated localised CMD/ icons (Bold, Italic, etc) were a deliberate decision by the icon theme designer, and is due to how we build and pack themes. They must remain but will be fixed in a future patch.  Please could you leave Kendy to Merge this- he is familiar with my work and I'd also like his feedback.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Oh - no need to be pedantic about this change :-)  Andrew is doing great stuff with the optimizations, his tools are better than what I'm using.Also when 2 images end up with the same content, git is smart, and stores the file just once too, so it is not a problem if we get an intermediate state into the repository.So - I hope it is not controversal at all to get his change in :-) - let's just do it.

text: Patch Set 6: -Code-ReviewJust FYI, the newest code change *looks* fine to me, but I still would like to test the change run-time.  Also, I'd like to make sure the new xml name for this attribute is consistent with the rest of the terminology that we use in the ODF.  We do use specific names for various parts of pivot tables, so I'd like for the new name to adhere to that convention.Last thing, we do need a unit test case for this new behavior to ensure that we won't accidentally break this in our future changes to the pivot table code.
Text: Patch Set 6: -Code-ReviewJust FYI, the newest code change *looks* fine to me, but I still would like to test the change run-time.  Also, I'd like to make sure the new xml name for this attribute is consistent with the rest of the terminology that we use in the ODF.  We do use specific names for various parts of pivot tables, so I'd like for the new name to adhere to that convention.Last thing, we do need a unit test case for this new behavior to ensure that we won't accidentally break this in our future changes to the pivot table code.

text: Patch Set 6:I checked the run-time behavior and it works very well.  And I checked the ODF attribute name, and I *think* that, although there are several other names we could re-use for this purpose, repeat-item-labels is probably reasonable.Now, 2 things remain.  One is that we need a new unit test to cover this new feature.  Hopefully you can pick one of the existing test cases in ucalc_pivottable.cxx as a model and add a new test case.  Another one is that, because we are adding a new attribute that's not yet in the ODF standard, we need to use a different namespace other than 'table:', to make sure that when we export the document it will be a valid ODF.  I *think* you can use either XML_NP_CALC_EXT or XML_NP_LO_EXT for this.  Eike, do you have any advice on which namespace to use?That's all I have to say on this.  Great work!
Text: Patch Set 6:I checked the run-time behavior and it works very well.  And I checked the ODF attribute name, and I *think* that, although there are several other names we could re-use for this purpose, repeat-item-labels is probably reasonable.Now, 2 things remain.  One is that we need a new unit test to cover this new feature.  Hopefully you can pick one of the existing test cases in ucalc_pivottable.cxx as a model and add a new test case.  Another one is that, because we are adding a new attribute that's not yet in the ODF standard, we need to use a different namespace other than 'table:', to make sure that when we export the document it will be a valid ODF.  I *think* you can use either XML_NP_CALC_EXT or XML_NP_LO_EXT for this.  Eike, do you have any advice on which namespace to use?That's all I have to say on this.  Great work!

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1This patch still has issues.1) The new option shouldn't be added to the popup window since it's not an action but it's an attribute. The popup window is the wrong place to house this option.  It should go to the Field options dialog which can be reached from the layout dialog by double-clicking on the field name (which is kinda hidden, I know).  Once that dialog is open, you still need to click on the Options button to get to the actual dialog where you need to add this option.2) This should be a field (or dimension as it's called in the code) option. As such, it should be stored in ScDPSaveDimension as a new boolean member, not in ScDPSaveData, which should only store table-wide options.3) ODF export code should also reflect that, and store the new setting as a dimension attribute.  Right now you are saving it as a table attribute, which is wrong.  I didn't check your change in the import code, but I'd guess it has a similar issue.I did check Excel once again. Excel doesn't offer this as a table wide option. Only a field setting option.  What you saw is probably the print option where the user can choose to repeat field names when printing. But that's an entirely different setting.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1This patch still has issues.1) The new option shouldn't be added to the popup window since it's not an action but it's an attribute. The popup window is the wrong place to house this option.  It should go to the Field options dialog which can be reached from the layout dialog by double-clicking on the field name (which is kinda hidden, I know).  Once that dialog is open, you still need to click on the Options button to get to the actual dialog where you need to add this option.2) This should be a field (or dimension as it's called in the code) option. As such, it should be stored in ScDPSaveDimension as a new boolean member, not in ScDPSaveData, which should only store table-wide options.3) ODF export code should also reflect that, and store the new setting as a dimension attribute.  Right now you are saving it as a table attribute, which is wrong.  I didn't check your change in the import code, but I'd guess it has a similar issue.I did check Excel once again. Excel doesn't offer this as a table wide option. Only a field setting option.  What you saw is probably the print option where the user can choose to repeat field names when printing. But that's an entirely different setting.

text: Patch Set 1:This change has one side effect when searching in selections, I'm not yet sure whether that is a positive or negative change, but I lean towards negative ;-)The anchors ^ and $ now anchor at the selection boundary because the only text the regex matcher gets passed is the selected text. This in two paragraphs aaa bbb aaa bbb aaa bbb aaa bbbwhen the selection spans from the second aaa to the third bbb, for ^aaa finds the second aaa, where previously it found the third aaa at the real paragraph start.This may not be expected by the user, because the behavior of ^ is described as "Match at the beginning of a line" (or paragraph in our case), which the previous implementation did.On the other hand one may argue that the selection is the only text considered and thus logically starts a line.I'm undecided.
Text: Patch Set 1:This change has one side effect when searching in selections, I'm not yet sure whether that is a positive or negative change, but I lean towards negative ;-)The anchors ^ and $ now anchor at the selection boundary because the only text the regex matcher gets passed is the selected text. This in two paragraphs aaa bbb aaa bbb aaa bbb aaa bbbwhen the selection spans from the second aaa to the third bbb, for ^aaa finds the second aaa, where previously it found the third aaa at the real paragraph start.This may not be expected by the user, because the behavior of ^ is described as "Match at the beginning of a line" (or paragraph in our case), which the previous implementation did.On the other hand one may argue that the selection is the only text considered and thus logically starts a line.I'm undecided.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi,Sounds sane -- please push it yourself if you want.One suggestion: would it be possible to add a unit test for this? See sw/qa/extras/README for the details, hopefully it's easy to construct an assert that checks if there is a custom.xml in the stream. I mean e.g. parseExportInternal() should serve as a good example, XNameAccess has not only getByName() but also hasByName() you could assert that.Thanks!

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1The basic idea is a good one here. Clearly the ScHorizontalAttrIter is used in a ton of places across the code-base, particularly in filters, and making it ~instant for all the common big-data cases is very helpful.The basic approach looks good too - the nMinNextEnd looks sensible to detect large runs of identical formatting.What doesn't convince me that much is the initialization and management of the pPrevColEnd array. It looks like that is not initialized initially [sic] ;-) and then there is an assumption that:                if ( bRepeatedRow )                    nCol = pPrevColEnd[nCol];-but- (AFAICS) there is no guarentee that pPrevColEnd[nCol] is setup correctly - it rather depends on the value of nCol that was used last time - which (in turn) depends on the shape of the data.So - I would suggest adopting a different approach for generating and managing that - along with some nicer data structure for this case. IIWY I'd detect the case where there is a large run of identical styles - and in that case do more work to analyze them into a complete structure - that can be re-used for several subsequent rows; eg. if there are > 2x rows with the same thing - then allocate & fill that structure in (eg.).Is that do-able ? hopefully it'll make the code flow more pleasant too =)I'd also like to see a unit test created for the case that looks like it should fail in the above =) where we have constant patterns down a run - but a random layout of cell content.Thanks !
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1The basic idea is a good one here. Clearly the ScHorizontalAttrIter is used in a ton of places across the code-base, particularly in filters, and making it ~instant for all the common big-data cases is very helpful.The basic approach looks good too - the nMinNextEnd looks sensible to detect large runs of identical formatting.What doesn't convince me that much is the initialization and management of the pPrevColEnd array. It looks like that is not initialized initially [sic] ;-) and then there is an assumption that:                if ( bRepeatedRow )                    nCol = pPrevColEnd[nCol];-but- (AFAICS) there is no guarentee that pPrevColEnd[nCol] is setup correctly - it rather depends on the value of nCol that was used last time - which (in turn) depends on the shape of the data.So - I would suggest adopting a different approach for generating and managing that - along with some nicer data structure for this case. IIWY I'd detect the case where there is a large run of identical styles - and in that case do more work to analyze them into a complete structure - that can be re-used for several subsequent rows; eg. if there are > 2x rows with the same thing - then allocate & fill that structure in (eg.).Is that do-able ? hopefully it'll make the code flow more pleasant too =)I'd also like to see a unit test created for the case that looks like it should fail in the above =) where we have constant patterns down a run - but a random layout of cell content.Thanks !

text: Patch Set 3:My fix is to make sure the scaling function is double. The end result must be a valid pixed index within the bitmap, so a 32-bit int is good for 4 GPixels on a side!My patch is really to change the nWidth and nHeight to double, thereby forcing the muldiv operation of scaling to be done fully in double before casting/truncating into long (which should fit nicely without overflow).The more important question is why are we creating a border/shadow bitmap as long as the page? That's just not efficient, but probably much simpler to code.
Text: Patch Set 3:My fix is to make sure the scaling function is double. The end result must be a valid pixed index within the bitmap, so a 32-bit int is good for 4 GPixels on a side!My patch is really to change the nWidth and nHeight to double, thereby forcing the muldiv operation of scaling to be done fully in double before casting/truncating into long (which should fit nicely without overflow).The more important question is why are we creating a border/shadow bitmap as long as the page? That's just not efficient, but probably much simpler to code.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Chris - thanks for this! :-)* forms/source/misc/services.cxx should be killed completely I think.* related to that - you've left out com.sun.star.form.XForms from being converted to constructor - was there a reason for that, please?* It's not necessary to copy the "since SRC568 both OFormattedModel and OEditModel use FRM_COMPONENT_EDIT for persistence" comment to the .component file, it it bitrotten - SRC568 and "version <= 5.1" have no meaning these days I guess, so it only adds confusionAlso please move the *_get_implementation's to the bottom of the files, that's the usual place for them :-)We also talked about killing the DECLARE_DEFAULT_LEAF_XTOR macro - feel free to add it to this commit too, or leave as separate cleanup commit...
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Chris - thanks for this! :-)* forms/source/misc/services.cxx should be killed completely I think.* related to that - you've left out com.sun.star.form.XForms from being converted to constructor - was there a reason for that, please?* It's not necessary to copy the "since SRC568 both OFormattedModel and OEditModel use FRM_COMPONENT_EDIT for persistence" comment to the .component file, it it bitrotten - SRC568 and "version <= 5.1" have no meaning these days I guess, so it only adds confusionAlso please move the *_get_implementation's to the bottom of the files, that's the usual place for them :-)We also talked about killing the DECLARE_DEFAULT_LEAF_XTOR macro - feel free to add it to this commit too, or leave as separate cleanup commit...

text: Patch Set 1:Hi,Could you move the asserts from ooxmlimport to ooxmlexport, so that you need to add the test document only once to the repo? Text: Patch Set 1:Hi,Could you move the asserts from ooxmlimport to ooxmlexport, so that you need to add the test document only once to the repo?
