text: Patch Set 1:Thank you very much for your feedback and your hints!I have thought about how to best implement this and would appreciate your feedback on my ideas.The possibilities I am currently thinking about are as follows:1) Add two new functions (e.g. "jfw_plugin_getJavaInfoFromJavaHome", "jfw_plugin_getJavaInfosFromPath") to vendorplugin.hxx and sunjavaplugin.cxx to obtain information about Java installations referred to by JAVA_HOME and PATH environment variables (similar to jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos). The two functions use the functions in util.cxx to get the information.jfw_findAndSelectJRE uses the two new functions to check for such Java installations and uses them if there are any, otherwise uses the algorithm that is currently used.This would avoid duplicate code in jfw_findAndSelectJRE and getAllJREInfos.2) Add additional (out) parameters to getAllJREInfos and jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos that hold the JavaInfos that have been found using JAVA_HOME or PATH.possible new signature:javaPluginError jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos(    rtl_uString *sVendor,    rtl_uString *sMinVersion,    rtl_uString *sMaxVersion,    rtl_uString * * arExcludeList,    sal_Int32  nSizeExcludeList,    JavaInfo*** parJavaInfo,    sal_Int32 *nSizeJavaInfo,    JavaInfo** parJavaInfoFromJavaHome,    JavaInfo*** parJavaInfosFromPath,    sal_Int32 *nSizeJavaInfosFromPath);If JAVA_HOME points to a suitable Java installation, parJavaInfoFromJavaHome points to it.If suitable Java installations are on the PATH, parJavaInfosFromPath holds the respective JavaInfos and nSizeJavaInfosFromPath is the number of JavaInfos found on the PATH.The additional parameters would be unused for "normal" calls to the method and only be used in jfw_findAndSelectJRE (which is possibly no good design?).3) Add an additional field to the _JavaInfo struct that tells how the Java installation has been found. I currently don't have a reasonable idea how to actually implement that field - which should be able to tell e.g. that the Java installation is referred to by JAVA_HOME, and/or is the 1st Java on the PATH, the 2nd Java on the PATH,..., or has been found in a different way.As far as I understand, the struct is defined in include/jvmfwk/framework.h and the new field would thus also be visible from outside the "jvmfwk" module.I personally consider solution 1) to be the best of those three, but would appreciate your feedback. Of course, a totally different solution is welcome, too.
Text: Patch Set 1:Thank you very much for your feedback and your hints!I have thought about how to best implement this and would appreciate your feedback on my ideas.The possibilities I am currently thinking about are as follows:1) Add two new functions (e.g. "jfw_plugin_getJavaInfoFromJavaHome", "jfw_plugin_getJavaInfosFromPath") to vendorplugin.hxx and sunjavaplugin.cxx to obtain information about Java installations referred to by JAVA_HOME and PATH environment variables (similar to jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos). The two functions use the functions in util.cxx to get the information.jfw_findAndSelectJRE uses the two new functions to check for such Java installations and uses them if there are any, otherwise uses the algorithm that is currently used.This would avoid duplicate code in jfw_findAndSelectJRE and getAllJREInfos.2) Add additional (out) parameters to getAllJREInfos and jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos that hold the JavaInfos that have been found using JAVA_HOME or PATH.possible new signature:javaPluginError jfw_plugin_getAllJavaInfos(    rtl_uString *sVendor,    rtl_uString *sMinVersion,    rtl_uString *sMaxVersion,    rtl_uString * * arExcludeList,    sal_Int32  nSizeExcludeList,    JavaInfo*** parJavaInfo,    sal_Int32 *nSizeJavaInfo,    JavaInfo** parJavaInfoFromJavaHome,    JavaInfo*** parJavaInfosFromPath,    sal_Int32 *nSizeJavaInfosFromPath);If JAVA_HOME points to a suitable Java installation, parJavaInfoFromJavaHome points to it.If suitable Java installations are on the PATH, parJavaInfosFromPath holds the respective JavaInfos and nSizeJavaInfosFromPath is the number of JavaInfos found on the PATH.The additional parameters would be unused for "normal" calls to the method and only be used in jfw_findAndSelectJRE (which is possibly no good design?).3) Add an additional field to the _JavaInfo struct that tells how the Java installation has been found. I currently don't have a reasonable idea how to actually implement that field - which should be able to tell e.g. that the Java installation is referred to by JAVA_HOME, and/or is the 1st Java on the PATH, the 2nd Java on the PATH,..., or has been found in a different way.As far as I understand, the struct is defined in include/jvmfwk/framework.h and the new field would thus also be visible from outside the "jvmfwk" module.I personally consider solution 1) to be the best of those three, but would appreciate your feedback. Of course, a totally different solution is welcome, too.

text: Patch Set 2:I sure hope this will affect Linux (and possibly Windows) only. We hopefully don't want to support random user-installed Java builds on OS X. On Linux, well, "Linux is all about choice", so yeah, the user must have the opportunity to screw stuff up beyond recognition, and we must support that.
Text: Patch Set 2:I sure hope this will affect Linux (and possibly Windows) only. We hopefully don't want to support random user-installed Java builds on OS X. On Linux, well, "Linux is all about choice", so yeah, the user must have the opportunity to screw stuff up beyond recognition, and we must support that.

text: Patch Set 2:At least, this is possible on Linux. I don't know whether this is different on OS X.

text: Patch Set 3:sorry forgot to answer your question...you can simply apply a character style like "emphpasis" to some text and then apply an automatic style by clicking e.g. on the "bold" icon, since "emphasis" sets italic you should then see bold+italic text.(it's evey possible to have multiple character styles on the same text if you ctrl+click (or was it shift+click? i forgot) a second style in the navigator)the new size pool-items you insert will always be set as an automatic style (AUTOFMT) overriding any size that is already set at the same postion; so if there are multiple hints the last one for which you increment and set a new size will override all previous ones.iirc it should work fine with char-fmt + auto-fmt because the auto-fmt should be sorted "later" so it will override; but for the hyperlinks there is no fixed ordering wrt the other ones so it's possible to set the increased font size of the hyperlink when it should be the size of the existing autofmt.
Text: Patch Set 3:sorry forgot to answer your question...you can simply apply a character style like "emphpasis" to some text and then apply an automatic style by clicking e.g. on the "bold" icon, since "emphasis" sets italic you should then see bold+italic text.(it's evey possible to have multiple character styles on the same text if you ctrl+click (or was it shift+click? i forgot) a second style in the navigator)the new size pool-items you insert will always be set as an automatic style (AUTOFMT) overriding any size that is already set at the same postion; so if there are multiple hints the last one for which you increment and set a new size will override all previous ones.iirc it should work fine with char-fmt + auto-fmt because the auto-fmt should be sorted "later" so it will override; but for the hyperlinks there is no fixed ordering wrt the other ones so it's possible to set the increased font size of the hyperlink when it should be the size of the existing autofmt.

text: Patch Set 1:Hello, Brij: thank you very much for your patches!In order to get your patches automatically linked to the relevant bug reports, please use the ÔÇ£fdo#12345ÔÇØ notation in your commit message. That way, a bot will pick it up and notify the bug subscribers that a commit has been made. So, in this case it would be ÔÇ£fdo#85432ÔÇØ.We use this notation because LibreOffice has many bug trackers ÔÇô not just the one hosted at freedesktop.org. See https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/FAQ#What_are_those_.23iXXXX.23.2Ffdo.23XXXX.2Fetc._comments.3F

text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for your comments Takeshi!About the cbegin()/cend() methods, since C++11 (http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/container/map/begin) the map container adds cbegin()/cend() to make explicit the const result.Maybe is more clear use cbegin()/cend() instead of begin()/end() and infer if the result is of type iterator or const_iterator. What do you think? Is good reason for you?
Text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for your comments Takeshi!About the cbegin()/cend() methods, since C++11 (http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/container/map/begin) the map container adds cbegin()/cend() to make explicit the const result.Maybe is more clear use cbegin()/cend() instead of begin()/end() and infer if the result is of type iterator or const_iterator. What do you think? Is good reason for you?

text: Patch Set 1:Mikos Vajna,I can only save my inline comment as draft, hence I reply here directly:1. Regarding test cases: I have test files but I'm not able to write cpp unit test code. I don't know how to submit those test files.2. Regarding numeric tokens: Those numeric tokens exists before my patch ( ex, 5=ARABIC ). You found mixing of numeric tokens and NS_ooxml:LN_something because RTF import filter share dmapper with OOXML import filte and RTF import filter implementation didn't define constants or enumeration for it.
Text: Patch Set 1:Mikos Vajna,I can only save my inline comment as draft, hence I reply here directly:1. Regarding test cases: I have test files but I'm not able to write cpp unit test code. I don't know how to submit those test files.2. Regarding numeric tokens: Those numeric tokens exists before my patch ( ex, 5=ARABIC ). You found mixing of numeric tokens and NS_ooxml:LN_something because RTF import filter share dmapper with OOXML import filte and RTF import filter implementation didn't define constants or enumeration for it.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi,Once you're ready with your inline comments, you can just push the reply + send button (without filling the textarea), and then your comments will be published.About numeric tokens: would it be possible to adjust rtftok to emit the necessary NS_ooxml::LN_something tokens instead? The idea is that RTF is a no longer developed format, while OOXML still introduces new features, so RTF is a subset of OOXML. Based on that, dmapper should in general handle OOXML, and rtftok should just emit those ooxml tokens, not its own ones. So there should be as minimal RTF-specific code in dmapper as possible.About unit tests, see here for documentation: http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/qa/extras/READMEOne RTF, one DOC and one DOCX export test would be the optimal.Thanks! :-)
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi,Once you're ready with your inline comments, you can just push the reply + send button (without filling the textarea), and then your comments will be published.About numeric tokens: would it be possible to adjust rtftok to emit the necessary NS_ooxml::LN_something tokens instead? The idea is that RTF is a no longer developed format, while OOXML still introduces new features, so RTF is a subset of OOXML. Based on that, dmapper should in general handle OOXML, and rtftok should just emit those ooxml tokens, not its own ones. So there should be as minimal RTF-specific code in dmapper as possible.About unit tests, see here for documentation: http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/qa/extras/READMEOne RTF, one DOC and one DOCX export test would be the optimal.Thanks! :-)

text: Patch Set 1:If you're on Linux, the easiest way is to install 'git-review', then all you have to do is typing 'git review' every time you want to upload a new version of your patch. :-)Other than that, feel free to upload a new version when you would like to have feedback. I'm happy that someone who knows something about CJK lists (I don't know much) is improving the situation here, so I'm happy to provide feedback & looking forward to merge it once it's in a reasonable shape. ;-)
Text: Patch Set 1:If you're on Linux, the easiest way is to install 'git-review', then all you have to do is typing 'git review' every time you want to upload a new version of your patch. :-)Other than that, feel free to upload a new version when you would like to have feedback. I'm happy that someone who knows something about CJK lists (I don't know much) is improving the situation here, so I'm happy to provide feedback & looking forward to merge it once it's in a reasonable shape. ;-)

text: Patch Set 4:Looks much better, I took over at this point. I've fixed the following remaining nitpicks before merging:- style issues (surrounding code puts { at the start of the next line, so be consistent with that)- prefer prefix increment instead of postfix increment (there is a perf difference in case of real iterators)- use SAL_N_ELEMENTS- moved the tests to the CppunitTest_sw_rtfexport, so changes in rtfattributeoutput get tested as wellOne remaining thing: as a follow-up (separate) patch, could you please add at least one .doc and one .docx export test as well, so someone else in the future won't break your fixes to e.g. docxattributeoutput and ww8par*? Thanks! :-)
Text: Patch Set 4:Looks much better, I took over at this point. I've fixed the following remaining nitpicks before merging:- style issues (surrounding code puts { at the start of the next line, so be consistent with that)- prefer prefix increment instead of postfix increment (there is a perf difference in case of real iterators)- use SAL_N_ELEMENTS- moved the tests to the CppunitTest_sw_rtfexport, so changes in rtfattributeoutput get tested as wellOne remaining thing: as a follow-up (separate) patch, could you please add at least one .doc and one .docx export test as well, so someone else in the future won't break your fixes to e.g. docxattributeoutput and ww8par*? Thanks! :-)

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2I love this - as/when it compiles & works - lets get it in; it'd be great to iterate on this.In general though - to avoid changing eg. window.hxx too much, I'd put a more verbose comment on 'virtual void dispose();':/// Release all references to other ref-counted resources, and backing graphical resources; may be called more than once safely.and then put the dispose() method out of line.Ultimately, I think a chunk of ~Window prolly needs to move into dispose too.Otherwise this is really sexy =) I look forward to seeing it ~everywhere.

text: Patch Set 3: Verified-1When I open a file in Impress 4.2 that has been saved with a password to modify, the document is opened read-only, without a notice about the password protection.Then you can toggle the edit mode and edit the document without entering a password. text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1I think that is more convenient and expressive, delegate the cause to the constructor instead of use a helper class that calls the initCause method, a new constructor could take the cause and another one the detail message and the cause. In any case, this proposal offers a great improvement.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1I think that is more convenient and expressive, delegate the cause to the constructor instead of use a helper class that calls the initCause method, a new constructor could take the cause and another one the detail message and the cause. In any case, this proposal offers a great improvement.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(7 comments)For each UNO exception type E we currently generate three ctors in Java:  public E() { super(); }  public E(String Message) { super(Message); }  public E(String Message, Object Context, T1 m1, ..., Tn mn) {    super(Message);    this.Context = Context;    this.m1 = m1;    ...    this.mn = mn;  }I would suggest to generate an additional three ctors that each take a first argument  Throwable causeand call the corresponding super ctor that passes the cause along.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(7 comments)For each UNO exception type E we currently generate three ctors in Java:  public E() { super(); }  public E(String Message) { super(Message); }  public E(String Message, Object Context, T1 m1, ..., Tn mn) {    super(Message);    this.Context = Context;    this.m1 = m1;    ...    this.mn = mn;  }I would suggest to generate an additional three ctors that each take a first argument  Throwable causeand call the corresponding super ctor that passes the cause along.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Maxim,1. Well the tooltip needs to be simple and descriptive and the standard single word tooltips like 'Undo' are soon to be replaced by long descriptive tooltips like 'Undo Last Action', so we would ideally want a useful tooltip that we wont have to go back to later on and change. So 'Zoom & Pan Tool' or 'Zoom and Pan Tool' are both good in my book.2. GIMP has the zoom tooltip as 'Zoom Tool: Adjust the zoom level'. The word tool simply identifies that its not a one click action button like 'Zoom In', which is why i believe the old behaviour was so not understood.3. Yes i think that button should be renamed, as i've never seen the word 'shift' used for pan in any app.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Maxim,1. Well the tooltip needs to be simple and descriptive and the standard single word tooltips like 'Undo' are soon to be replaced by long descriptive tooltips like 'Undo Last Action', so we would ideally want a useful tooltip that we wont have to go back to later on and change. So 'Zoom & Pan Tool' or 'Zoom and Pan Tool' are both good in my book.2. GIMP has the zoom tooltip as 'Zoom Tool: Adjust the zoom level'. The word tool simply identifies that its not a one click action button like 'Zoom In', which is why i believe the old behaviour was so not understood.3. Yes i think that button should be renamed, as i've never seen the word 'shift' used for pan in any app.

text: Patch Set 1:I don't think it is necessary to lock it, as it is only advisory there, the real synchronization happens via the posting and taking the mutex in the Emit... function.  Ie. I am using it there only to assure we are not flooding the system with messages when we are still handling the previous ones, it is not a real issue if the value changes between the if and the Post.But for good measure, can change the bool to a osl mutex, and only do tryToAcquire it in the timer's callback - any opinions? :-)
Text: Patch Set 1:I don't think it is necessary to lock it, as it is only advisory there, the real synchronization happens via the posting and taking the mutex in the Emit... function.  Ie. I am using it there only to assure we are not flooding the system with messages when we are still handling the previous ones, it is not a real issue if the value changes between the if and the Post.But for good measure, can change the bool to a osl mutex, and only do tryToAcquire it in the timer's callback - any opinions? :-)

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Jennifer, you have been almost there. :) FileAccess.getFolderTitles takes the translation dictonary as an optional parameter. Actual translations will come from .po files from translations/ module, when translators translate the newly available strings from this patch. For now we are done, strings are pulled from resource files not from ODF files, this is what we wanted.
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Jennifer, you have been almost there. :) FileAccess.getFolderTitles takes the translation dictonary as an optional parameter. Actual translations will come from .po files from translations/ module, when translators translate the newly available strings from this patch. For now we are done, strings are pulled from resource files not from ODF files, this is what we wanted.

text: Patch Set 1:No no, your questions are fully reasonable! You switch to the 4-3 branch and do git cherry-pick -x commit-id there. The commit-id of your commit in the master branch is unique inside the whole git tree. So this works this easy.You don't need to abandon this change. If your new patch has the same "Change-Id" as this one gerrit will notice it as second version of this patchset. So you do git cherry-pick -x and after that change the "Change-Id" to Ibd04cf5329b4d226aac102d214a45e45811982e7 . That should be enough :)
Text: Patch Set 1:No no, your questions are fully reasonable! You switch to the 4-3 branch and do git cherry-pick -x commit-id there. The commit-id of your commit in the master branch is unique inside the whole git tree. So this works this easy.You don't need to abandon this change. If your new patch has the same "Change-Id" as this one gerrit will notice it as second version of this patchset. So you do git cherry-pick -x and after that change the "Change-Id" to Ibd04cf5329b4d226aac102d214a45e45811982e7 . That should be enough :)

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Accepted, however David Tardon is right, all translations are managed by an external tool (pootle), so updating the .po files does not really solve anything--they will be broken again the next time they are exported from pootle. But if translators don't update pootle, there will be no export, so this patch has some value. Thanks!
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Accepted, however David Tardon is right, all translations are managed by an external tool (pootle), so updating the .po files does not really solve anything--they will be broken again the next time they are exported from pootle. But if translators don't update pootle, there will be no export, so this patch has some value. Thanks!

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So - I love the idea of having this in a header.However - it should not be in the main header [!]I'd expect that to be in a separate - init header or somesuch.Also - defines such as 'LINUX' are not standard at all; nor 'AIX' so ... ;-) we need a better way to handle that.OTOH - this is an improvement in some ways; I'd be happy to see it split out to another header with a better set of define guards etc.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So - I love the idea of having this in a header.However - it should not be in the main header [!]I'd expect that to be in a separate - init header or somesuch.Also - defines such as 'LINUX' are not standard at all; nor 'AIX' so ... ;-) we need a better way to handle that.OTOH - this is an improvement in some ways; I'd be happy to see it split out to another header with a better set of define guards etc.

text: Patch Set 1:> this is only used in practice to remove ".." components, right?Yes, this is only for to remove the inner ".." parts of the absolute paths. (Interestingly,  _wfopen() implementation of MinGW has no problems with the relative subparts of the absolute path, but it seems, that is not WIN32 compatible.) From the Linux and Windows tests, the external linguistic libraries get absolute paths for the installed extensions, too, eg. "/home/laci/m/libreoffice-4-2/instdir/program/../program/../user/uno_packages/cache/uno_packages/luqm9pc0.tmp_/dict-de.oxt/de_DE_frami.aff".
Text: Patch Set 1:> this is only used in practice to remove ".." components, right?Yes, this is only for to remove the inner ".." parts of the absolute paths. (Interestingly,  _wfopen() implementation of MinGW has no problems with the relative subparts of the absolute path, but it seems, that is not WIN32 compatible.) From the Linux and Windows tests, the external linguistic libraries get absolute paths for the installed extensions, too, eg. "/home/laci/m/libreoffice-4-2/instdir/program/../program/../user/uno_packages/cache/uno_packages/luqm9pc0.tmp_/dict-de.oxt/de_DE_frami.aff".

text: Patch Set 6:The previous files are based in the mozilla build system and now we don't use it for building. From my point of view those files had several issues which have been fixed by the ÔÇÿconfigÔÇÖ project at http://savannah.gnu.org/, for that reason the best is use the last version:curl -o config.guess 'http://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=config.git;a=blob_plain;f=config.guess;hb=HEAD'curl -o config.sub 'http://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=config.git;a=blob_plain;f=config.sub;hb=HEAD'

Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1this is good but still incomplete: getResourceType returns a reference to a member that can only be accessed when then corresponding mutex is locked; the original commit changed that to return a value, which makes more sense.

text: Patch Set 1:My concern is that tweaking the DOCX export is fine, but you should not change how a field is expanded as that would change the layout of existing documents, which is a no-go (it would also affect e.g. ODF documents).SwAuthorityField::Expand() uses ConditionalExpand(AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER), so if you change anything in ConditionalExpand(), you have to be sure that existing documents are not changed. If possible, best to not touch it at all.
Text: Patch Set 1:My concern is that tweaking the DOCX export is fine, but you should not change how a field is expanded as that would change the layout of existing documents, which is a no-go (it would also affect e.g. ODF documents).SwAuthorityField::Expand() uses ConditionalExpand(AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER), so if you change anything in ConditionalExpand(), you have to be sure that existing documents are not changed. If possible, best to not touch it at all.

text: Patch Set 1:So if this is a new situation, wouldn't it be better to add it as a new method, instead of squashing it into an existing one, which has different purpose already? (That one is used by layout.)May I suggest to handle your situation in a new ExpandCitation() or similar method, that's clearly used only during export? So next time you need to touch it, you won't have to review all cases manually again, but it'll be clear that it doesn't affect the layout.Thanks!
Text: Patch Set 1:So if this is a new situation, wouldn't it be better to add it as a new method, instead of squashing it into an existing one, which has different purpose already? (That one is used by layout.)May I suggest to handle your situation in a new ExpandCitation() or similar method, that's clearly used only during export? So next time you need to touch it, you won't have to review all cases manually again, but it'll be clear that it doesn't affect the layout.Thanks!

text: Patch Set 2:Hi Jens,if you are on Linux, you could run:bin/fixincludeguards.sh FILENAMEThis will automatically correct possible misspelled header guards(but there has to be one in the file). You could probably add FOO_HXX and the script will automatically correct it.Good work! :)
Text: Patch Set 2:Hi Jens,if you are on Linux, you could run:bin/fixincludeguards.sh FILENAMEThis will automatically correct possible misspelled header guards(but there has to be one in the file). You could probably add FOO_HXX and the script will automatically correct it.Good work! :)

text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Actually, there is one problem.  This mbFormulaChar may cause buffer overflow.  sizeof(sal_Unicode) is 2, which means mbFormulaChar is an array of size 2.  When you assign value to this with a character value as its index, the index will most likely be greater than 2.  Can you double-check that?
Text: Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1Actually, there is one problem.  This mbFormulaChar may cause buffer overflow.  sizeof(sal_Unicode) is 2, which means mbFormulaChar is an array of size 2. text: Patch Set 2:Note: it is okay to return false here, because it's stated that recently introduced DrawTextSpecial "return true if it was able to handle the drawing, false if not". And we haveif(! ImplDrawTextDirect( rSalLayout, mbTextLines, DRAWTEXT_F_OUTLINE))<then use "vintage" outlining implementation>inside vcl/source/gdi/outdev3.cxx, and it's great to keep it.By the way, 45b0c12a021fb0eb896faf4f0de9026586407012 is Norbert's patch, so adding him.

ImplDrawTextDirect( rSalLayout, mbTextLines, DRAWTEXT_F_OUTLINE))<then use "vintage" outlining implementation>inside vcl/source/gdi/outdev3.cxx, and it's great to keep it.By the way, 45b0c12a021fb0eb896faf4f0de9026586407012 is Norbert's patch, so adding him.

text: Patch Set 2:the vintage implementation did not work with coretext since it rely on changing the text color _after_ the layout occured so bassically that had no effectand yes this was just to restore the support or outline for now it is not meant to be the answer yet to everything...Bold is handled at the font attribute level.. and indeed outline + bold 'emulation' does not work... it can't really since the emulation of outline and bold use the same attribute but one with negative value the other with a positive value... you can't have both.The whole layout object is poorly designed... and rewriting it is on my to-do list.. but there are plenty of special case and a variety of use cases in different platform to take into account.. so that will take time...
Text: Patch Set 2:the vintage implementation did not work with coretext since it rely on changing the text color _after_ the layout occured so bassically that had no effectand yes this was just to restore the support or outline for now it is not meant to be the answer yet to everything...Bold is handled at the font attribute level.. and indeed outline + bold 'emulation' does not work... it can't really since the emulation of outline and bold use the same attribute but one with negative value the other with a positive value... you can't have both.The whole layout object is poorly designed... and rewriting it is on my to-do list.. but there are plenty of special case and a variety of use cases in different platform to take into account.. so that will take time...

Message: warn:sw.uno:29229:1:sw/source/core/unocore/unotext.cxx:2270: Exception when setting property: VerticalBorder. Message: In DomainMapperTableHandler.cxx, while setting these table properties it is throuwing exception.Exact point where exception is reported:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unotbl.cxx#3080Since 'pEntry' is empty, the exception is thrown.These table properties[for which exception is thrown] are being mapped in unomap.cxxAs a workaround I removed my fix and UT. The issue is reported as above without my fix.Kindly suggest.Thanks.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Looks good, thanks.Nitpick: see how ooxmlimport's testFdo65090 can test the column separators using the UNO API, without looking into the XML directly. Using the UNO API has the advantage that the test can be executed right after import as well, so in case the test fails, it's easier to debug to find out if the problem is on the import or the export side.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Looks good, thanks.Nitpick: see how ooxmlimport's testFdo65090 can test the column separators using the UNO API, without looking into the XML directly. Using the UNO API has the advantage that the test can be executed right after import as well, so in case the test fails, it's easier to debug to find out if the problem is on the import or the export side.

text: Patch Set 9:``1/ do not break other platform code'' Agree with this, I don't like to break working code.``2/ do no shift the burden on maintenance back onto other platforms'' Disagree here, becasue it is related to SAL (software abstraction layer), which purpose is to provide independency from any particular platform.``3/ keep it clear that whatever hack is needed is for that purpose, so that we can clean it up easily later'' Thanks for telling fairly that my work can be easily removed.

text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Verified+1ok, this is great stuff. The catch for us though is that we don't have C++11 everywhere yet, so we can't use the auto and lambda features. I've (hopefully) poked them around sufficiently to build on non-C++11 now.Otherwise, generally following the style of surrounding code is the way to go re variable naming and brace placement and so on.
Text: Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Verified+1ok, this is great stuff. The catch for us though is that we don't have C++11 everywhere yet, so we can't use the auto and lambda features. I've (hopefully) poked them around sufficiently to build on non-C++11 now.Otherwise, generally following the style of surrounding code is the way to go re variable naming and brace placement and so on.

text: Patch Set 1:If you plan to add layout support, UI, ODF filter, etc for this feature, then adding this in the API is OK. On the other hand, if you just want to preserve this, and you don't plan to implement this as a proper feature, then I would suggest adding an InteropGrabBag to SwXCell, and then you can roundtrip the DOCX-specific cell with type without polluting our API.To sum up, yes, if you could post a patch that adds InteropGrabBag as a supported property of SwXCell, I would definitely merge that.Thanks!
Text: Patch Set 1:If you plan to add layout support, UI, ODF filter, etc for this feature, then adding this in the API is OK. On the other hand, if you just want to preserve this, and you don't plan to implement this as a proper feature, then I would suggest adding an InteropGrabBag to SwXCell, and then you can roundtrip the DOCX-specific cell with type without polluting our API.To sum up, yes, if you could post a patch that adds InteropGrabBag as a supported property of SwXCell, I would definitely merge that.Thanks!

text: Patch Set 2:You've done the first part right - cherry-pick the commit to a clean master (without your changes).Then do the changes you need, git add them, then 'git commit --amend' - this will modify the existing commit instead of creating a new one.When you are happy (look at the git log -p output), do 'git push origin master:refs/for/master' again - it will go again here.
Text: Patch Set 2:You've done the first part right - cherry-pick the commit to a clean master (without your changes).Then do the changes you need, git add them, then 'git commit --amend' - this will modify the existing commit instead of creating a new one.When you are happy (look at the git log -p output), do 'git push origin master:refs/for/master' again - it will go again here.

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Thank you for the patch!  I wonder - do we have to introduce a new flag?  Isn't it enough to re-use the GETFOCUS_TAB here too?Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing?  Or is that unrelated?The rest is nitpicking :-) - if we really need GETFOCUS_F6, it should be 0x0800, not 0x1000.  PreNotify() should return true's, not 1's.Thanks so much - and sorry the review took so long; -1's for now, hope that's OK, please set back to 0 when you upload a new patch at some stage.
Text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Thank you for the patch!  I wonder - do we have to introduce a new flag?  Isn't it enough to re-use the GETFOCUS_TAB here too?Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing?  Or is that unrelated?The rest is nitpicking :-) - if we really need GETFOCUS_F6, it should be 0x0800, not 0x1000.  PreNotify() should return true's, not 1's.Thanks so much - and sorry the review took so long; -1's for now, hope that's OK, please set back to 0 when you upload a new patch at some stage.

text: Patch Set 3:> maybe somewhere these flags are used in a special way I don't think they are (and git grep does not suggest anything like that) - I believe it was more a kind of grouping things together (TAB/CURSOR/MNEMONIC - one group, FORWARD/BACKWARD/AROUND another, etc.)
Text: Patch Set 3:> maybe somewhere these flags are used in a special way I don't think they are (and git grep does not suggest anything like that) - I believe it was more a kind of grouping things together (TAB/CURSOR/MNEMONIC - one group, FORWARD/BACKWARD/AROUND another, etc.)

text: Patch Set 1:@Kohei: Currently the actual HTML detection is at svtools as HTMLParser::IsHTMLFormat. But instead of re-using it, I wrote my own function in form of isHTMLStream. The difference is that the former detects even if the file doesn't start with HTML tag right from the beginning, which may be good for a browser, but not for us because there can be documents that mention HTML tags. What do you think?
Text: Patch Set 1:@Kohei: Currently the actual HTML detection is at svtools as HTMLParser::IsHTMLFormat. But instead of re-using it, I wrote my own function in form of isHTMLStream. The difference is that the former detects even if the file doesn't start with HTML tag right from the beginning, which may be good for a browser, but not for us because there can be documents that mention HTML tags. What do you think?

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Regarding isHTMLStream, I think what you did is perfectly reasonable, so I'm happy with it.  Good work there. :-)Let me verify the build, and we can merge this one.BTW, I just sniffed around the code a bit, and discovered yet another isHTMLFormat() inside vcl (!).  Maybe at some point we can merge some of these duplicate codes in some way.Another point worth mentioning is that, if we can find a way to merge this shared library with the one for the CSV detector, we could save some cost of loading these small libraries.  But that's for a future project.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Regarding isHTMLStream, I think what you did is perfectly reasonable, so I'm happy with it.  Good work there. :-)Let me verify the build, and we can merge this one.BTW, I just sniffed around the code a bit, and discovered yet another isHTMLFormat() inside vcl (!).  Maybe at some point we can merge some of these duplicate codes in some way.Another point worth mentioning is that, if we can find a way to merge this shared library with the one for the CSV detector, we could save some cost of loading these small libraries.  But that's for a future project.

text: Patch Set 1:(1 comment)Besides a minor (and I mean doesn't even matter) nitpick the change itself looks fine (I guess this bug was introduced by some String->OUString conversion). But... I would really love if this patch set would include some testing around this function, do you think you could create some new tests for Mid? Note: creating basic tests is extremely simple, see http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/tree/basic/qa/basic_coverage/uno_struct_assign.vb as an example ( all you need to do is drop in .vb file(s) each with an entry point function called doUnitTest which returns 1/0 for pass/fail)

text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, I'm not entirely 100% sure about this, but:getDefaultAdapter still exists and should work according to the API (it's not marked as deprecated, the methods docs haven't changed), and hence should work for us for all supported Android versions. Moreover there are no reports of it breaking with 4.3 that I can find (I imagine there'd be quite some uproar if existing apps were suddenly broken by Android 4.3)...It seems the getSystemService way of getting the adapter was added for consistency (as that's how the Wifi adapter is usually retrieved) -- and it's use is obviously encouraged for new apps, but we specifically want to support 2.3+ for now, so still need to at least have getDefaultAdapter.So, unless there is specific evidence that getDefaultAdapter has been broken we only need to support getDefaultAdapter and can ignore the getSystemService way of doing things, in which case the wrapper is unnecessary. (And in future once we no longer need to support < 4.3 we can migrate to whatever the wonderful new consistent API is.)
Text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, I'm not entirely 100% sure about this, but:getDefaultAdapter still exists and should work according to the API (it's not marked as deprecated, the methods docs haven't changed), and hence should work for us for all supported Android versions. Moreover there are no reports of it breaking with 4.3 that I can find (I imagine there'd be quite some uproar if existing apps were suddenly broken by Android 4.3)...It seems the getSystemService way of getting the adapter was added for consistency (as that's how the Wifi adapter is usually retrieved) -- and it's use is obviously encouraged for new apps, but we specifically want to support 2.3+ for now, so still need to at least have getDefaultAdapter.So, unless there is specific evidence that getDefaultAdapter has been broken we only need to support getDefaultAdapter and can ignore the getSystemService way of doing things, in which case the wrapper is unnecessary. (And in future once we no longer need to support < 4.3 we can migrate to whatever the wonderful new consistent API is.)

text: Patch Set 2:While I appreciate that you took your time to comment on my patches, I cannot take your comments seriously.In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.
Text: Patch Set 2:While I appreciate that you took your time to comment on my patches, I cannot take your comments seriously.In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.

text: Patch Set 2:> In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).I see this as a visual design and UX. The visual design is defined. If Android has the Roboto font developers should consider using it instead of Comic Sans. If the whole platform uses uppercase headers developers should consider to implement it as well. On other hand the UX of Bluetooth interaction has a kind of broken state ÔÇö┬áyes, in perfect world users should enable it themselves, but why there are no dialog for disabling it themselves? Does it make sense to force user to use dialog every time one launches the app? Why user should even care about enabling or disabling Bluetooth at all? IÔÇÖm not trying to reject things I donÔÇÖt want to see or use ÔÇö┬áI try to think about better implementations which cause pleasant experience and not emotions like ÔÇ£oh this dialog againÔÇØ, ÔÇ£again this app causes battery drainÔÇØ.> You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.1. It is easier to translate strings when you see simple words instead of WORDS. 2. If in the future the platform remove this headers style we can just tweak the style for the text and not the text for the style.
Text: Patch Set 2:> In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).I see this as a visual design and UX. The visual design is defined. If Android has the Roboto font developers should consider using it instead of Comic Sans. If the whole platform uses uppercase headers developers should consider to implement it as well. On other hand the UX of Bluetooth interaction has a kind of broken state 脭脟枚鈹es, in perfect world users should enable it themselves, but why there are no dialog for disabling it themselves? Does it make sense to force user to use dialog every time one launches the app? Why user should even care about enabling or disabling Bluetooth at all? I脭脟脰m not trying to reject things I don脭脟脰t want to see or use 脭脟枚鈹 try to think about better implementations which cause pleasant experience and not emotions like 脭脟拢oh this dialog again脭脟脴, 脭脟拢again this app causes battery drain脭脟脴.> You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.1. It is easier to translate strings when you see simple words instead of WORDS. 2. If in the future the platform remove this headers style we can just tweak the style for the text and not the text for the style.

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks good to me!Whilst phones are the primary audience, I still think having specific tablet support is useful, as a tablet is still a lot easier to place in a convenient location than a laptop (or even more so a desktop) is. I think that it might be worth adding a tablet specific landscape UI where the notes get more space (with a smaller preview -- due to the resolution a huge preview makes little sense there as mentioned), but that would be a completely separate topic to this patch in any case.

text: Patch Set 1:I chose the mingw mailing list entry, because there's a nice compilation of old WINVER defines, which the Microsoft documentation doesn't offer :)And at the moment we need to set WINVER because it has everywhere different values. Or we have hacks like adefd564d07a6e70cc1d9fad8febe5b434511e83 or a9fd489834b63e423d4745f0d71cf15396e3e3eb. At least for fpicker it's relevant because with 0x0501 you wouldn't get the window previews in the taskbar with Vista/7. So we need 0x0600 there, but we can't set it global to the project if we still want to support Windows XP.But you're right, after that commit many of them could be simply dropped.
Text: Patch Set 1:I chose the mingw mailing list entry, because there's a nice compilation of old WINVER defines, which the Microsoft documentation doesn't offer :)And at the moment we need to set WINVER because it has everywhere different values. Or we have hacks like adefd564d07a6e70cc1d9fad8febe5b434511e83 or a9fd489834b63e423d4745f0d71cf15396e3e3eb. At least for fpicker it's relevant because with 0x0501 you wouldn't get the window previews in the taskbar with Vista/7. So we need 0x0600 there, but we can't set it global to the project if we still want to support Windows XP.But you're right, after that commit many of them could be simply dropped.

text: Patch Set 6:Sorry, I didn't mention it, but yes this does need a make clean. The patch was indeed finished.I didn't wonder about the WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN redefinition, because this is how it's done in some other makefiles. Thanks for fixing this.Nice that this finally got into core :)
Text: Patch Set 6:Sorry, I didn't mention it, but yes this does need a make clean. The patch was indeed finished.I didn't wonder about the WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN redefinition, because this is how it's done in some other makefiles. Thanks for fixing this.Nice that this finally got into core :)

text: Patch Set 2:Now the settings are applied globally.And I found out how to use the macros:_WIN32_WINNT sets NTDDI_VERSION and WINVER automatically to the same version.But setting NTDDI_VERSION or WINVER sets only the macro itself.If we want to target Windows XP we need to set _WIN32_WINNT, because otherwise other SDK stuff is still included under Windows 7. But this brings us some kind of dilemma: How do we add features which are added in Windows 7 (like 9a4a84df5406cdcde1f4d23a1cea2b109998f35b)? If we set WINVER globally those features are never activated.One solution could be to check:#ifdef NTDDI_WIN7Works fine, but checks only what is supported by the Windows API (what if Win8 SDK is installed on Win7?).Maybe we should move this to the mailing list.
Text: Patch Set 2:Now the settings are applied globally.And I found out how to use the macros:_WIN32_WINNT sets NTDDI_VERSION and WINVER automatically to the same version.But setting NTDDI_VERSION or WINVER sets only the macro itself.If we want to target Windows XP we need to set _WIN32_WINNT, because otherwise other SDK stuff is still included under Windows 7. But this brings us some kind of dilemma: How do we add features which are added in Windows 7 (like 9a4a84df5406cdcde1f4d23a1cea2b109998f35b)? If we set WINVER globally those features are never activated.One solution could be to check:#ifdef NTDDI_WIN7Works fine, but checks only what is supported by the Windows API (what if Win8 SDK is installed on Win7?).Maybe we should move this to the mailing list.

text: Patch Set 1:Here is how I would do it:You want to make sure that a given XML element exists. You take the XPath of it, then:assertXPath(pXmlStyles, "blabla", 1);makes sure that there is exactly one node matching that XPath. If it was missing previously, that was 0.In the ooxmlexport suite, testStyleInheritance has plenty of such examples, also e.g. testBnc834035 shows how to assert an XPath in document.xml.Does that help? :-)Sorry for the nitpicking, but in the past I at least remember two cases already when we fixed hyperlink/redline/field end problems, so this is an area where we really want unit tests. Thanks!
Text: Patch Set 1:Here is how I would do it:You want to make sure that a given XML element exists. You take the XPath of it, then:assertXPath(pXmlStyles, "blabla", 1);makes sure that there is exactly one node matching that XPath. If it was missing previously, that was 0.In the ooxmlexport suite, testStyleInheritance has plenty of such examples, also e.g. testBnc834035 shows how to assert an XPath in document.xml.Does that help? :-)Sorry for the nitpicking, but in the past I at least remember two cases already when we fixed hyperlink/redline/field end problems, so this is an area where we really want unit tests. Thanks!

Did you by chance do a chmod -R +x or some such?
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is merged(2 inline comments)Nitpicks available, see inline comments ;-)Furthermore, this patch oddly changes the file permissions, cherry-picking it results in mode change 100644 => 100755 sc/source/core/tool/interpr3.cxxso sets the executable bit for all, which doesn't make sense. Did you by chance do a chmod -R +x or some such?

Text: Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)New patch set coming up.No I did not chmod files. Ichecked before and after cherry-picking and the filesettings changed from rw-r--r-- to rwxr-xr-x, just as with you.I did a chmod -x on the file before amending the patch.Perhaps it will help (?)

text: Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is mergedCorrect place in general, but I think we should be more specific. Text: Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is mergedCorrect place in general, but I think we should be more specific. As is, the change now also doesn't use ordinals anymore for example for "2nd-order". It would be good if we could check explicitly for the letter 'e' or 'E' at rTxt[nInsPos-1]

text: Patch Set 2:I expect _xResultSet is null because it is passed as null as argument to that function; the root cause is higher in the call stack (that is in the function that calls StringsFromResultSet, or in the function that calls this one, or etc).I expect the root cause is "just" some unimplemented interface / part of the firebird driver.However, I find that independently of the above, your patch seems to increase the robustness of the StringsFromResultSet function, and that's a good thing. I'd just wish we identified the root cause.Does the table wizard actually fully work after applying your patch?
Text: Patch Set 2:I expect _xResultSet is null because it is passed as null as argument to that function; the root cause is higher in the call stack (that is in the function that calls StringsFromResultSet, or in the function that calls this one, or etc).I expect the root cause is "just" some unimplemented interface / part of the firebird driver.However, I find that independently of the above, your patch seems to increase the robustness of the StringsFromResultSet function, and that's a good thing. I'd just wish we identified the root cause.Does the table wizard actually fully work after applying your patch?

text: Patch Set 3:> vmiklos: I have updated all the relevant places to now use 'optional'.Great, thanks!> In 'sw/source/ui/utlui/uitool.cxx' the 'SfxUInt16Item aPageNum' is set in the function 'SwToSfxPageDescAttr'. Question is - now that 'GetNumOffset' *could* return NULL - what should be done if it *is* null ? should we set '0' to the 'SfxUInt16Item' (like I've done) ?If we're speaking about SwToSfxPageDescAttr(), what about just not putting the SfxPoolItem to the item set? Of course, then the consumer of that item set (insert->manual break dialog?) should handle the lack of the pool item in the set, but I guess that's logical: item missing -> "change page number" checkbox is false, item there -> "change page number" checkbox is true and the value can be even 0, if you need it.> In 'sw/source/ui/table/tabledlg.cxx' the code *used* to set the 'NumericField' with the value from the 'GetNumOffset()' function, but now it returns an optional value. so if the value is NULL - should it *not* set the NumericValue or it *should* set it, but with 0 (like I've done) ?This is the UI I was mentioning above. :) I guess null should be "checkbox false, numeric field empty", while 0 should be "checbox true, numeric field 0". Hopefully that's intuitive enough.
Text: Patch Set 3:> vmiklos: I have updated all the relevant places to now use 'optional'.Great, thanks!> In 'sw/source/ui/utlui/uitool.cxx' the 'SfxUInt16Item aPageNum' is set in the function 'SwToSfxPageDescAttr'. Question is - now that 'GetNumOffset' *could* return NULL - what should be done if it *is* null ? should we set '0' to the 'SfxUInt16Item' (like I've done) ?If we're speaking about SwToSfxPageDescAttr(), what about just not putting the SfxPoolItem to the item set? Of course, then the consumer of that item set (insert->manual break dialog?) should handle the lack of the pool item in the set, but I guess that's logical: item missing -> "change page number" checkbox is false, item there -> "change page number" checkbox is true and the value can be even 0, if you need it.> In 'sw/source/ui/table/tabledlg.cxx' the code *used* to set the 'NumericField' with the value from the 'GetNumOffset()' function, but now it returns an optional value. so if the value is NULL - should it *not* set the NumericValue or it *should* set it, but with 0 (like I've done) ?This is the UI I was mentioning above. :) I guess null should be "checkbox false, numeric field empty", while 0 should be "checbox true, numeric field 0". Hopefully that's intuitive enough.

text: Patch Set 1:We are always very good in finding justifications why we don't write/extend unit tests:* that module (Base in this case) doesn't have tests* that method is not get tested in existing unit test class* we are in hurry to hot fix our stable branch and don't going to spend time to writing/extending unit testsIMHO we should stop that praxis and start writing/extending unit tests.
Text: Patch Set 1:We are always very good in finding justifications why we don't write/extend unit tests:* that module (Base in this case) doesn't have tests* that method is not get tested in existing unit test class* we are in hurry to hot fix our stable branch and don't going to spend time to writing/extending unit testsIMHO we should stop that praxis and start writing/extending unit tests.

text: Patch Set 1:As it was stated in the commit log:"The aim is calling to the "renderDiagramToGraphic" method when theuser has chosen to keep the Smart-Art as it is when importing througha question dialog or similar mechanism. Hence, calling to the methodis disabled by now until we have such mechanism in place."So, yes, I understand your point and we were already thinking in the follow-up patch.Makes sense to wait for it before integrating. We have moved the discussion about the proper UX for defining the behavior. I was already thinking on adding something in "Options" but thought it would be simpler with a request dialog. Checking now the code it seems that the new item in options may be even simpler :)Thanks for the review, will come back with a new patch soon!
Text: Patch Set 1:As it was stated in the commit log:"The aim is calling to the "renderDiagramToGraphic" method when theuser has chosen to keep the Smart-Art as it is when importing througha question dialog or similar mechanism. Hence, calling to the methodis disabled by now until we have such mechanism in place."So, yes, I understand your point and we were already thinking in the follow-up patch.Makes sense to wait for it before integrating. We have moved the discussion about the proper UX for defining the behavior. I was already thinking on adding something in "Options" but thought it would be simpler with a request dialog. Checking now the code it seems that the new item in options may be even simpler :)Thanks for the review, will come back with a new patch soon!

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedBit of a head scratcher over the endianness issues. I think we need to remember to swap if the endianness of the platform we are on doesn't match the endianness of the jpeg. i.e. the old code is probably wrong for LibreOffice on ppc for example. Either way, this is pretty snazzy, thanks!
Text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedBit of a head scratcher over the endianness issues. I think we need to remember to swap if the endianness of the platform we are on doesn't match the endianness of the jpeg. i.e. the old code is probably wrong for LibreOffice on ppc for example. Either way, this is pretty snazzy, thanks!

text: Patch Set 8:Great work David, thanks so much for working on this!  I agree with the move to sd from sdext BTW, only if you can rename the uno command to '.uno:PresentationMinimizer' (without the menu) :-) - but that is just nitpicking.So if you can fix the settings as Stephan pointed out, we are good to push from my point of view ;-)
Text: Patch Set 8:Great work David, thanks so much for working on this!  I agree with the move to sd from sdext BTW, only if you can rename the uno command to '.uno:PresentationMinimizer' (without the menu) :-) - but that is just nitpicking.So if you can fix the settings as Stephan pointed out, we are good to push from my point of view ;-)

text: Patch Set 1:Sorry, that the patch is big. Important bits are Gallery.mk and CppunitTest.mk, where 'xcsxcu' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS is changed and 'module' is no more used.I hope something like this is possible.. patches to remove $(OUTDIR)/xml are almost done ;-)btw: 'xcsxcu' and 'res' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS in instsetoo_native/CustomTarget_setup.mk have the same value, is it right ?Otherwise only 'xcsxcu' is now used AFAICS, so possibly also configmgr can be simplified ?
Text: Patch Set 1:Sorry, that the patch is big. Important bits are Gallery.mk and CppunitTest.mk, where 'xcsxcu' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS is changed and 'module' is no more used.I hope something like this is possible.. patches to remove $(OUTDIR)/xml are almost done ;-)btw: 'xcsxcu' and 'res' in CONFIGURATION_LAYERS in instsetoo_native/CustomTarget_setup.mk have the same value, is it right ?Otherwise only 'xcsxcu' is now used AFAICS, so possibly also configmgr can be simplified ?

text: Patch Set 6:Great work - thank you for that! :-)Before pushing, I did a small modification; instead of if() for checking the max size, I changed that to a min() function which will ensure that we set the maximal size in case the mouse pointer was moved very far away.
Text: Patch Set 6:Great work - thank you for that! :-)Before pushing, I did a small modification; instead of if() for checking the max size, I changed that to a min() function which will ensure that we set the maximal size in case the mouse pointer was moved very far away.

text: Patch Set 6:Okay, thank you! :-)
Text: Patch Set 6:Okay, thank you! :-)

text: Patch Set 3:Hi Kendy,We have 2 cases here, when the sidebar is attached towards the  lhs/rhs of screen. Under each case, we need to track whether the mouse is been dragged towards left or right, because of which the track of 'nDelta' is important.Moreover, I think the absolute values would not work perfectly for each desktop because mnMaxSize stores the container width of the current working desktop. For me, this value is 1366 which may differ for desktop to desktop, that is why I preferred using this value instead of working directly with absolute values.
Text: Patch Set 3:Hi Kendy,We have 2 cases here, when the sidebar is attached towards the  lhs/rhs of screen. Under each case, we need to track whether the mouse is been dragged towards left or right, because of which the track of 'nDelta' is important.Moreover, I think the absolute values would not work perfectly for each desktop because mnMaxSize stores the container width of the current working desktop. For me, this value is 1366 which may differ for desktop to desktop, that is why I preferred using this value instead of working directly with absolute values.

text: Patch Set 3:Thanks for your comment!At first I did this only in StartCenter, but it bugged me that the regular recent file menus kept deleted items. I asked Kendy if I should try putting this directly in SvtHistoryOptions, and he said that I should try doing it.Looking at it, I think remote docs should never be removed from recent, since:1.) checking them might take long,2.) they might be removed if the user starts LO while offline,3.) they might go down temporarily.So I think I should check if the protocol is file://, and if  it is, check if the file exists, and otherwise just leave it.
Text: Patch Set 3:Thanks for your comment!At first I did this only in StartCenter, but it bugged me that the regular recent file menus kept deleted items. I asked Kendy if I should try putting this directly in SvtHistoryOptions, and he said that I should try doing it.Looking at it, I think remote docs should never be removed from recent, since:1.) checking them might take long,2.) they might be removed if the user starts LO while offline,3.) they might go down temporarily.So I think I should check if the protocol is file://, and if  it is, check if the file exists, and otherwise just leave it.

text: Patch Set 1:removing commented sections is usually rather safe -- cherry-picking is somewhat robust against that. For blank lines, there is no convention on how many we should have were, so this might easily lead to a fight over that (and we shouldnt bother with that then). And brace-only changes are even more tricky: The might successfully merge -- but still be wrong.So as long as there are still germanisms in the codebase it would be awesome, if you stick to those! ;)
Text: Patch Set 1:removing commented sections is usually rather safe -- cherry-picking is somewhat robust against that. For blank lines, there is no convention on how many we should have were, so this might easily lead to a fight over that (and we shouldnt bother with that then). And brace-only changes are even more tricky: The might successfully merge -- but still be wrong.So as long as there are still germanisms in the codebase it would be awesome, if you stick to those! ;)

text: Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is merged1) Is the helpcontent2 hunk of the patch intentional?2) It seems the patch mixes two ways: on one hand, it adds a support for restart being 0 (and using -1 for "not set"), but it also adds a boolean flag to "avoid" changing unsigned membes to signed ones. I think adding a new boolean member is fine, but then please check for that boolean everywhere, and don't do the 0 -> 1 change.3) Seems most of the heavy-lifting in core is about allowing a restart with value == 0, but the testcase doesn't check this, only a normal restart.I would suggest either adding a section with such a "zero restart" as well, of just do the fixes in two separate commits: one commit adding just the restart support, and an other fixing the zero restart corner case.
Text: Patch Set 5: This need some tweaks before it is merged1) Is the helpcontent2 hunk of the patch intentional?2) It seems the patch mixes two ways: on one hand, it adds a support for restart being 0 (and using -1 for "not set"), but it also adds a boolean flag to "avoid" changing unsigned membes to signed ones. I think adding a new boolean member is fine, but then please check for that boolean everywhere, and don't do the 0 -> 1 change.3) Seems most of the heavy-lifting in core is about allowing a restart with value == 0, but the testcase doesn't check this, only a normal restart.I would suggest either adding a section with such a "zero restart" as well, of just do the fixes in two separate commits: one commit adding just the restart support, and an other fixing the zero restart corner case.

text: Patch Set 5:I mean, my understanding is:Previously, the page number offset was a single unsigned integer, where 0 meant "no restart", other values meant a restart with a positive value. This is obviously a problem if you want to have a restart with a zero value.The patch introduces bNumOffsetIsSet to signal if the page number offset is valid, this is a good move. However at other places it also starts to use -1 to signal that the page number offset is valid or not, so now we have two places storing the same info (bNumOffsetIsSet == true or page number offset == -1), which looks redundant.
Text: Patch Set 5:I mean, my understanding is:Previously, the page number offset was a single unsigned integer, where 0 meant "no restart", other values meant a restart with a positive value. This is obviously a problem if you want to have a restart with a zero value.The patch introduces bNumOffsetIsSet to signal if the page number offset is valid, this is a good move. However at other places it also starts to use -1 to signal that the page number offset is valid or not, so now we have two places storing the same info (bNumOffsetIsSet == true or page number offset == -1), which looks redundant.

text: Patch Set 2:Also, code like  sal_Int64 i;  any >>= i;  o << i;has the problem that, in general, >>= can return false and not write a value into i, so "o << i" could read an uninitialized i.  Some compilers warn about that.  We do know that >>= will not fail in this case, so the best is probably  sal_Int64 i = sal_Int64(); // avoid uninitialized warnings
Text: Patch Set 2:Also, code like  sal_Int64 i;  any >>= i;  o << i;has the problem that, in general, >>= can return false and not write a value into i, so "o << i" could read an uninitialized i.  Some compilers warn about that.  We do know that >>= will not fail in this case, so the best is probably  sal_Int64 i = sal_Int64(); // avoid uninitialized warnings

text: Patch Set 3:> Lionel, any response to Michael's review?So, in general terms, the situation is that I stumbledupon broken code while doing something else and Ifixed it. Details:>> possibly this could be replaced by sax::ConverterYes, that seems desirable in the middle-to-long term.However, the name of the function referred to anotherstandard than what sax::Converter aims at, so I consideredit more prudent to fix the code "locally", referring to thestandard it purposes to implement, rather than replaceby a call to sax::Converter::parseISO8601 (or some such).Especially since I meant for this to go into our release branch(es).If someone wants to invest the time to merge this withsax::Converter, I agree it would enhance the code qualityof LibreOffice: one (hopefully not buggy) implementationof parsing date/time (that is well-tested because used much,tested by unittests, etc) instead of multiple implementationswith different bugs that possibly show up only in corner cases(and thus linger for a long time before being found).However, that someone is not me, at least not in the shortterm. > I had a look at "ECMA-376 Part 1 3rd edition" > (is this the relevant reference?)Dunno. Not my area of expertise. Looks plausible to me. > ST_DateTime (...) W3C XML Schema dateTime datatype > Dates and Time (...) SpreadsheetML (...) ISO 8601-formatted > string > Date (...) SpreadsheetML (...) stored in the ISO 8601 format > however can't find any reference to > http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime in there > where did the idea come from that that was relevant?The function is called GetDateTimeFromW3CDTF. Duckduckgoing(or Googling) for W3CDTF makes it clear that "W3CDTF" usuallymeans http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, so I assumed thatthis was the format the function was supposed to parse. 1) Was the W3CDTF in the function name meant as a reference     to that note? Dunno, ask its author. 2) In that case, was the reference itself an error? Michael's     research seems to indicate this would be the case.IRC (or mailing list?) discussion also basically said that as faras we know, the timezone component of this fix may not mattermuch since Microsoft Office always writes UTC (Zulu) time,so the bug would never get triggered. I think that it is stillpreferable to fix the bug to avoid that other code calls thisfunction in situations where the bug happens.So, my opinion would be:1) As proactive safety, apply this patch to master & 4-1.    (possibly an adapted part of it to 4-0; adapted because    sub-second stuff is different in 4-0: centiseconds instead    of nanoseconds) 2) In master, provided we have a volunteer to unravel that     quagmire (that knows about OOXML or willing to find out     about it), merge with sax::Converter date/time-parsing     if appropriate... If not appropriate, maybe migrate this     function to sax::Converter (along with documentation-by-     comment explaining why we need different parsers for     different formats and the difference between them), so     that our date/time-parsing code is all in one place.Since nobody clearly vetoed this patch, I'm going to push "1)" to master soon, unless someone vetoes.

Duckduckgoing(or Googling) for W3CDTF makes it clear that "W3CDTF" usuallymeans http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, so I assumed thatthis was the format the function was supposed to parse. 1) Was the W3CDTF in the function name meant as a reference     to that note? Dunno, ask its author. 2) In that case, was the reference itself an error? (possibly an adapted part of it to 4-0; adapted because    sub-second stuff is different in 4-0: centiseconds instead    of nanoseconds) 2) In master, provided we have a volunteer to unravel that     quagmire (that knows about OOXML or willing to find out     about it), merge with sax::Converter date/time-parsing     if appropriate... text: Patch Set 1:Kohei, since the origin of the "problem" is commit ac7acb0ab1329913b0cec79790adcde0263960be Author: Kohei Yoshida <kohei.yoshida@gmail.com> Date:   Thu Oct 11 16:13:12 2012 -0400    Merged SvTreeListBox and SvLBox.I'd appreciate if you took a look at this:Is there any nasty side-effect that I didn't think of in making Select() virtual?In other words: the virtual -> non-virtual change was not on purpose, right?Other classes that have an override (and thus impacted by this):SfxOrganizeListBox_Impl (sfx2/inc/docvor.hxx now renamed to include/sfx2/docvor.hxx)FmFilterNavigator (svx/source/inc/filtnav.hxx)NavigatorTree (svx/source/inc/fmexpl.hxx)
Text: Patch Set 1:Kohei, since the origin of the "problem" is commit ac7acb0ab1329913b0cec79790adcde0263960be Author: Kohei Yoshida <kohei.yoshida@gmail.com> Date:   Thu Oct 11 16:13:12 2012 -0400    Merged SvTreeListBox and SvLBox.I'd appreciate if you took a look at this:Is there any nasty side-effect that I didn't think of in making Select() virtual?In other words: the virtual -> non-virtual change was not on purpose, right?Other classes that have an override (and thus impacted by this):SfxOrganizeListBox_Impl (sfx2/inc/docvor.hxx now renamed to include/sfx2/docvor.hxx)FmFilterNavigator (svx/source/inc/filtnav.hxx)NavigatorTree (svx/source/inc/fmexpl.hxx)

text: Patch Set 1:Well, since we clearly have four classes that try to override this particular method, to me it looks like the safest (for our release branches) to make it virtual so that the four derived classes "work as they did before".If we want to make Select() non-virtual, we can do that later in master, changing the four derived classes to achieve the same effect than they intend by overriding Select() in some other way.Does that sound reasonable? In other words, do you agree to this change for 4-0 and 4-1?
Text: Patch Set 1:Well, since we clearly have four classes that try to override this particular method, to me it looks like the safest (for our release branches) to make it virtual so that the four derived classes "work as they did before".If we want to make Select() non-virtual, we can do that later in master, changing the four derived classes to achieve the same effect than they intend by overriding Select() in some other way.Does that sound reasonable? In other words, do you agree to this change for 4-0 and 4-1?

Cursor is not blinking in edit view.I checked the behavior before this change and there was no blinking cursor either.Please, try to verify if this behavior was newly introduced by this change. Otherwise, this change might be merged as is and fixes fdo#32059. If so, blinking cursor is another issue.Thanks in advance.
Text: Patch Set 3:Dear Marcos,I clearly see your point. Cursor is not blinking in edit view.I checked the behavior before this change and there was no blinking cursor either.Please, try to verify if this behavior was newly introduced by this change. Otherwise, this change might be merged as is and fixes fdo#32059. If so, blinking cursor is another issue.Thanks in advance.

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedRight now the "right way" is whatever is currently used before it gets converted :-)Button ordering is super-emotive and people get very excited when they get changed. Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedRight now the "right way" is whatever is currently used before it gets converted :-)Button ordering is super-emotive and people get very excited when they get changed. text: Patch Set 1:I still don't get it.. merging the logic from SvxShape::getPropertyState() and that now changed loop it results in    for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )    {        if( mpImpl->mpMaster )        {            pState[nIdx] = mpImpl->mpMaster->getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );        }        else        {            pState[nIdx] = _getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );        }    }which to me is not different from the current code except that it determines the condition inside the loop instead of outside. Note the leading underscore for the !mpImpl->mpMaster case in both versions, it is not the same method called.
Text: Patch Set 1:I still don't get it.. merging the logic from SvxShape::getPropertyState() and that now changed loop it results in    for( sal_Int32 nIdx = 0; nIdx < nCount; nIdx++ )    {        if( mpImpl->mpMaster )        {            pState[nIdx] = mpImpl->mpMaster->getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );        }        else        {            pState[nIdx] = _getPropertyState( pNames[nIdx] );        }    }which to me is not different from the current code except that it determines the condition inside the loop instead of outside. text: Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approvedI clearly and significantly prefer this (store in UTC) rather than the alternative (https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/4833/ , store in timezone-that-was-localtime-at-startup).Here's how I understand other people's positions:Michael Stahl: unsure which one preferred. Or have your thoughts evolved since that comment?Eike Rathke: isUTC/isTimezoned flag makes no sense anyway. But since we are going to have it, UTC variant better than timezone-that-was-localtime-at-startup.*Very* minor bikeshed point: TimeZone vs Timezone. Unless Michael Stahl objects, let's change it to Timezone.
Text: Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, approvedI clearly and significantly prefer this (store in UTC) rather than the alternative (https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/4833/ , store in timezone-that-was-localtime-at-startup).Here's how I understand other people's positions:Michael Stahl: unsure which one preferred. But since we are going to have it, UTC variant better than timezone-that-was-localtime-at-startup.*Very* minor bikeshed point: TimeZone vs Timezone. Unless Michael Stahl objects, let's change it to Timezone.

text: Patch Set 2:The memory corruption I was seeing during testing wasn't related to this patch. It happens (with or without the patch) when libreoffice runs out of file descriptors. That needs to be investigated separately (working with some ppt documents seems to open hundreds of temporary files).I did change the code to use boost::scoped_ptr, but must say that is a bit of an acquired taste. I personally liked the simple patch 1 better.
Text: Patch Set 2:The memory corruption I was seeing during testing wasn't related to this patch. It happens (with or without the patch) when libreoffice runs out of file descriptors. That needs to be investigated separately (working with some ppt documents seems to open hundreds of temporary files).I did change the code to use boost::scoped_ptr, but must say that is a bit of an acquired taste. I personally liked the simple patch 1 better.

text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedfully agreed, that looks strange indeed; thanks for the cleanup.> I hope you can cherry pick my patch for LO 4.1the release branch libreoffice-4-1 already exists, and usually we pick only user-visible bug or build-fixing patches to release branches, while (at first glance) this patch looks like it "just" cleans up the code, or am i missing something?you can propose the patch yourself for the release branch by first "git checkout libreoffice-4-1" then "git cherry-pick -x <commit-hash>" and then send the result to gerrit again (it's smart enough to track the "same" patch on multiple branches).
Text: Patch Set 2: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedfully agreed, that looks strange indeed; thanks for the cleanup.> I hope you can cherry pick my patch for LO 4.1the release branch libreoffice-4-1 already exists, and usually we pick only user-visible bug or build-fixing patches to release branches, while (at first glance) this patch looks like it "just" cleans up the code, or am i missing something?you can propose the patch yourself for the release branch by first "git checkout libreoffice-4-1" then "git cherry-pick -x <commit-hash>" and then send the result to gerrit again (it's smart enough to track the "same" patch on multiple branches).
