text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approveMikl├│s, thanks for your review. The simplicity of the patch is conscious. Using the character sequence "\t" is an artificial problem in footnote numbering, but you can specify it using standard Unicode methods, adding a zero width non joiner between "\" and "t" (U+200C).This patch fixes a real problem (*bug of the user interface* distorts the document, prohibits the stable work of a fine workaround for a long-term problem). It is not the *ideal* solution, but there were more than 10 years to fix the original problem, the missing right aligned footnote numbering, without any known result (only my Graphite solution with Linux Libertine G and Biolinum G a few years ago). I was very glad to find a general workaround not depending my particular font enhancements a few days ago, fixing it with this patch, but if you will be able to fix the original problem in a more proper way (eg. adding a check box for right alignment) for LibreOffice 4.1, I won't want to force this patch. This is only a temporary UI fix to keep stable document format. More about this problem (in Hungarian): http://libreoffice.hu/2013/06/13/jobbra-zart-labjegyzetszamozas/Thanks again. Laci
Text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, but someone else must approveMikl鈹溾攤s, thanks for your review. The simplicity of the patch is conscious. Using the character sequence "\t" is an artificial problem in footnote numbering, but you can specify it using standard Unicode methods, adding a zero width non joiner between "\" and "t" (U+200C).This patch fixes a real problem (*bug of the user interface* distorts the document, prohibits the stable work of a fine workaround for a long-term problem). It is not the *ideal* solution, but there were more than 10 years to fix the original problem, the missing right aligned footnote numbering, without any known result (only my Graphite solution with Linux Libertine G and Biolinum G a few years ago). I was very glad to find a general workaround not depending my particular font enhancements a few days ago, fixing it with this patch, but if you will be able to fix the original problem in a more proper way (eg. adding a check box for right alignment) for LibreOffice 4.1, I won't want to force this patch. This is only a temporary UI fix to keep stable document format. More about this problem (in Hungarian): http://libreoffice.hu/2013/06/13/jobbra-zart-labjegyzetszamozas/Thanks again. Laci

text: Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThe root of the problem, that vcl's Edit control does not handle TAB character for some reason. Maybe it makes sense, maybe not. This patch can be accepted as a temporary solution to the specific problem. Of course "temporary" may mean yet another 10 years. :) I'll extend the help to document this great improvement.

Text: Patch Set 1:I prefer to review this patch because:1) it doesn't solve the problem (blank page), just fixes the crash2) is it the good way to fix this?a) If yes, does it mean we should propagate this into the whole file? (at least)b) If no, how to deal with this in a clean/efficient way?

text: Patch Set 1:The root cause is that this is not a normal docx file, it's under the http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/wordprocessingml/2006/2/main namespace, which was used by some beta version of Word. I think for now all we want to do is just not crashing on this input. Even if later support for this old namespace is added, it's always a good idea not to crash on unexpected namespaces.
Text: Patch Set 1:The root cause is that this is not a normal docx file, it's under the http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/wordprocessingml/2006/2/main namespace, which was used by some beta version of Word. I think for now all we want to do is just not crashing on this input. Even if later support for this old namespace is added, it's always a good idea not to crash on unexpected namespaces.

text: Patch Set 2:Done. Note that you can submit review of the same patch to more branches at once. (Well, probably not _the same patch_, because the Change-Id would clash. What I do is to cherry-pick the patch to branch libreoffice-X-Y and then run "git review libreoffice-X-Y").
Text: Patch Set 2:Done. Note that you can submit review of the same patch to more branches at once. (Well, probably not _the same patch_, because the Change-Id would clash. What I do is to cherry-pick the patch to branch libreoffice-X-Y and then run "git review libreoffice-X-Y").

text: Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveThis is unclear to me - it appears to work as expected; though if you're loading and re-saving an old file with these it doesn't prune the empty directories.Given that the feature which this is supposed to support doesn't function, and that at least one of the streams is still written (the accelerators) I'd be ok with putting this in as-is; but if we can have a better explanation of the thinking that'd be great too cf. the bug :-)
Text: Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveThis is unclear to me - it appears to work as expected; though if you're loading and re-saving an old file with these it doesn't prune the empty directories.Given that the feature which this is supposed to support doesn't function, and that at least one of the streams is still written (the accelerators) I'd be ok with putting this in as-is; but if we can have a better explanation of the thinking that'd be great too cf. the bug :-)

text: Patch Set 4:It does find the ICU, but there is then a call of pkg-config again to get CXXFLAGS. I am not sure whether they are really useful. Now in libcdr, we check whether the pkgconfig flags are set from outside and if they are, we simply don't call the pkg-config at all in that case. In this case a patching out of that call in configure itself could work
Text: Patch Set 4:It does find the ICU, but there is then a call of pkg-config again to get CXXFLAGS. I am not sure whether they are really useful. Now in libcdr, we check whether the pkgconfig flags are set from outside and if they are, we simply don't call the pkg-config at all in that case. In this case a patching out of that call in configure itself could work

Text: Patch Set 2:It would be nice if someone could try this on MSVC 2008 or/and 2012 to be 100% sure. I only assumed they are the same warnings based on MSDN documentation.But no doubt about C4242, C4255, C4265, C4626, C4640 - they are "disabled by default".

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI would be fine with that too, but thought it might cause a lengthy bikeshed discussion.http://nabble.documentfoundation.org/template/NamlServlet.jtp?macro=search_page&node=1621684&query=RTL_LOGFILE_CONTEXT_AUTHOR shows that these macros have at least not been completely ignored. Lets discuss on the ESC.Giving myself a -1 CR as RTL_LOGFILE_FORWARD_VIA_SAL_LOG should probably evaluate to ((void)0) in the non-debug-build case.
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI would be fine with that too, but thought it might cause a lengthy bikeshed discussion.http://nabble.documentfoundation.org/template/NamlServlet.jtp?macro=search_page&node=1621684&query=RTL_LOGFILE_CONTEXT_AUTHOR shows that these macros have at least not been completely ignored. Lets discuss on the ESC.Giving myself a -1 CR as RTL_LOGFILE_FORWARD_VIA_SAL_LOG should probably evaluate to ((void)0) in the non-debug-build case.

text: Patch Set 1:Eike, I put your name there as reviewer as I am very much interested in your opinion regarding my toDO-comment.When nDaysinYear should be a double, the number can represent th enumber of days in a year in proportion to the number of days in the leap year and the number of days in the non-leap year.That seems to me the most 'exact' YEARFRAC-result that is possible.
Text: Patch Set 1:Eike, I put your name there as reviewer as I am very much interested in your opinion regarding my toDO-comment.When nDaysinYear should be a double, the number can represent th enumber of days in a year in proportion to the number of days in the leap year and the number of days in the non-leap year.That seems to me the most 'exact' YEARFRAC-result that is possible.

text: Patch Set 1:This is already a step into the right direction. However, when already at it to really solve the YEARFRAC calculation the algorithms lined out in ODFF could be implemented, see http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/cs01/OpenDocument-v1.2-cs01-part2.html#YEARFRAC and http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/cs01/OpenDocument-v1.2-cs01-part2.html#Basis that for each mode gives the procedure to obtain day count and year count.Are you willing to do so? :-)
Text: Patch Set 1:This is already a step into the right direction. However, when already at it to really solve the YEARFRAC calculation the algorithms lined out in ODFF could be implemented, see http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/cs01/OpenDocument-v1.2-cs01-part2.html#YEARFRAC and http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/cs01/OpenDocument-v1.2-cs01-part2.html#Basis that for each mode gives the procedure to obtain day count and year count.Are you willing to do so? :-)

text: Patch Set 1:The patch looks promissing but I am unable to get it working. I did the following:   1. opened ODT document with several pages   2. set "Format/Page/Columns/Columns" to "3"   3. tried "File/Save As" as "HTML Document"   Result: Firefox shows only one columnt. I do NOT see             "column-count" in the html file   4. tried "File/Export" as XHTML document    Result: Same as above.   5. Opened the above exported HTML document in LO =>       in the "HTML document" mode   6. Set "Format/Columns/Columns" to "2"   7. Tried "File/Save As" as "HTML Document"    Result: Same as above.Did I anything wrong or the patch is incomplete, please?Is there any related bug number where I could find more details or a test document?Otherwise, I would be really happy to integrate it because it sounds very promissing.
Text: Patch Set 1:The patch looks promissing but I am unable to get it working. I did the following:   1. opened ODT document with several pages   2. set "Format/Page/Columns/Columns" to "3"   3. tried "File/Save As" as "HTML Document"   Result: Firefox shows only one columnt. I do NOT see             "column-count" in the html file   4. tried "File/Export" as XHTML document    Result: Same as above.   5. Opened the above exported HTML document in LO =>       in the "HTML document" mode   6. Set "Format/Columns/Columns" to "2"   7. Tried "File/Save As" as "HTML Document"    Result: Same as above.Did I anything wrong or the patch is incomplete, please?Is there any related bug number where I could find more details or a test document?Otherwise, I would be really happy to integrate it because it sounds very promissing.

text: Patch Set 1:This change is related to columns in text sections, not columns for pages. I guess page columns are not exported to HTML because there is really no generally applicable way of doing that; HTML pages do not have fixed height like pages in Writer do.To test this you need to- Open a new empty Writer document- Choose Insert -> Section- Go to Columns tab and type in a number, 3 for example, click Insert.- now you can see the little grey section markers, paste some long text inside those.- save as HTML, you should end up with a HTML document that has a MULTICOL element that contains the column count both in the old non-standard COLS-attribute and in the new css column-count attribute.PS. I hope this is the right way to respond to the review comment. I'm just trying to learn how to use this Gerrit tool.
Text: Patch Set 1:This change is related to columns in text sections, not columns for pages. I guess page columns are not exported to HTML because there is really no generally applicable way of doing that; HTML pages do not have fixed height like pages in Writer do.To test this you need to- Open a new empty Writer document- Choose Insert -> Section- Go to Columns tab and type in a number, 3 for example, click Insert.- now you can see the little grey section markers, paste some long text inside those.- save as HTML, you should end up with a HTML document that has a MULTICOL element that contains the column count both in the old non-standard COLS-attribute and in the new css column-count attribute.PS. I hope this is the right way to respond to the review comment. I'm just trying to learn how to use this Gerrit tool.

text: Patch Set 4:Thanks for your review.As far I tested, there is no need to distinguish the Footnotes from the Footers. This because the Footnotes are stored before the Footers, so the anchors are determined correctly. The only thing I improved in this patch is to check the anchor is placed in Footer or Footnote (by FindFootnoteStartNode() and FindFooterStartNode(). If this isn't the right way, please feel free to say so, but it works (please also see my test document in the commit comment and bug report).Kind regards,Joren
Text: Patch Set 4:Thanks for your review.As far I tested, there is no need to distinguish the Footnotes from the Footers. This because the Footnotes are stored before the Footers, so the anchors are determined correctly. The only thing I improved in this patch is to check the anchor is placed in Footer or Footnote (by FindFootnoteStartNode() and FindFooterStartNode(). If this isn't the right way, please feel free to say so, but it works (please also see my test document in the commit comment and bug report).Kind regards,Joren

text: Patch Set 1: Do not mergeHi there - thanks so much for this work; I assume you used a script for this ? :-) if so it's prolly better to discuss / review the script.A couple of things - the newly introduced trialing newlines at the end of files may cause some grief so prolly best to drop those. Otherwise the only issue I saw was of these horrible UTF-8 pre-characters; cf:--- a/xmlsecurity/source/dialogs/macrosecurity.src+++ b/xmlsecurity/source/dialogs/macrosecurity.src@@ -1,3 +1,4 @@+/* -*- Mode: C++; tab-width: 4; indent-tabs-mode: nil; c-basic-offset: 4 -*- */ <U+FEFF>/*That U+FEFF is a double-byte character that goes as the first char; and (in this case) we now have it in the middle of the file ;-) If you're using a perl-script something like this:    while (<$in>) {	my $line = $_;	# we sometimes get some mis-guided utf-8 flagging chars at the top	if ($line_count == 0 && defined ($fmt->{bin_utf8})) {	    $line =~ s/^\xef\xbb\xbf//;	}will detect & fix that up I guess. Inspired by:http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/contrib/dev-tools/tree/scripts/headerize.plAnyhow - thanks again for working on this - it'd be great to get your change in with those things tweaked !
Text: }will detect & fix that up I guess. Inspired by:http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/contrib/dev-tools/tree/scripts/headerize.plAnyhow - thanks again for working on this - it'd be great to get your change in with those things tweaked !"

text: Patch Set 4:See http://www.informit.com/guides/content.aspx?g=cplusplus&seqNum=463 , http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4726570/deprecation-of-the-static-keyword-no-more etc. It seems this is just a matter of taste. There is no technical reason why anonymous namespaces would be "better" than static, and the "deprecation" of static was commonly seen as meaningless (because no way were they going to actually remove that feature from the language and break tons of existing, perfectly fine, code), and was later withdrawn.
Text: Patch Set 4:See http://www.informit.com/guides/content.aspx?g=cplusplus&seqNum=463 , http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4726570/deprecation-of-the-static-keyword-no-more etc. It seems this is just a matter of taste. There is no technical reason why anonymous namespaces would be "better" than static, and the "deprecation" of static was commonly seen as meaningless (because no way were they going to actually remove that feature from the language and break tons of existing, perfectly fine, code), and was later withdrawn.

text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveThe patch looks good but I am not sure about the test results.I would like if a Calc expert looks at it.I tried the test from  https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=60306#c0 .The result is that the cell I28 has blue border, so it looks bad.On the other hand, the condional formula is "$Tabelle1.$T28>$Tabelle1.$C$10" instead of the strange"$Tabelle1.$T#REF!>$Tabelle1.$C$10". So, it looks like a step forward.So, I do +1 but do not want to put it :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveThe patch looks good but I am not sure about the test results.I would like if a Calc expert looks at it.I tried the test from  https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=60306#c0 .The result is that the cell I28 has blue border, so it looks bad.On the other hand, the condional formula is "$Tabelle1.$T28>$Tabelle1.$C$10" instead of the strange"$Tabelle1.$T#REF!>$Tabelle1.$C$10". So, it looks like a step forward.So, I do +1 but do not want to put it :-)

text: Patch Set 1:1. m_sLimit - a stringI choose string because	1. Can avoid some unneccessary cast	2. Don't have to deal with overflow\underflow. The LimitBox(ComboBox) and the SQLParser also use OUString so I suppose they pay attention for such problems.2. Hindi numbersYes, It will be good to get some advice to solve this checking generally.3. grabFocusFromLimitBoxLimitBox sends data to OQueryController just when it loose its focus. So to have recent data for SQL run for example, we have to grab focus from LimitBox.In what situations appears it? For example when a new LibreOffice user try out this feature. He\She is adding new limit values and running to see the result. In this casethere is no effect of adding limit, because with clicking on the run toolbar item the focus is stayed on the LimitBox, so its data is not sent to the right place and not used in the running SQL statment.
Text: 2. Don't have to deal with overflow\underflow. The LimitBox(ComboBox) and the SQLParser also use OUString so I suppose they pay attention for such problems.2. Hindi numbersYes, It will be good to get some advice to solve this checking generally.3. grabFocusFromLimitBoxLimitBox sends data to OQueryController just when it loose its focus. So to have recent data for SQL run for example, we have to grab focus from LimitBox.In what situations appears it? For example when a new LibreOffice user try out this feature. He\She is adding new limit values and running to see the result. In this casethere is no effect of adding limit, because with clicking on the run toolbar item the focus is stayed on the LimitBox, so its data is not sent to the right place and not used in the running SQL statment."

Anyway think we are there with this patch and we should be able to push your next update

text: Patch Set 1:I did it on first assignmentvoluntarily.'size' can be modified by the call to 'RegQueryValueEx'. It is reseted to sizeof(value) before each of these calls within the function.I wanted to be consistent with this behavior. So IMO it is better to remove first assignment.
Text: Patch Set 1:I did it on first assignmentvoluntarily.'size' can be modified by the call to 'RegQueryValueEx'. It is reseted to sizeof(value) before each of these calls within the function.I wanted to be consistent with this behavior. So IMO it is better to remove first assignment.

text: Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThe initial patches are somewhat misleading, what makes this work is not skipping setting a width of 1 on empty buttons, but skipping the "retval=true" in RTL mode.So boiling that out as "we don't support figuring out the position of RTL left/right scrollbar buttons from the gtk theme, use our own built-in logic for that".Returning false here for RTL is probably reasonable in the sense that we clearly aren't supportting it right.
Text: Patch Set 3: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedThe initial patches are somewhat misleading, what makes this work is not skipping setting a width of 1 on empty buttons, but skipping the "retval=true" in RTL mode.So boiling that out as "we don't support figuring out the position of RTL left/right scrollbar buttons from the gtk theme, use our own built-in logic for that".Returning false here for RTL is probably reasonable in the sense that we clearly aren't supportting it right.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this* "if S1 exits before dialog establishment":  Are you concerned about S1 exiting cleanly while the connection protocol is running?  In that case, the logic to not allow S1 to terminate while the protocol is running should be fixed (in case it is broken).  If you are rather concerned about S1 crashing midway through the connection protocol, then (a) the comment "the other instance may have already terminated" is misleading (should talk about "crash" rather than "termination"), and (b) it is unclear to me whether one wants to really (re-)do all the actions specified on the command line -- e.g., the command line might contain a print request, and from the crash of S1 S2 cannot tell whether or not that had already succeeded or not.* addArgument returning false is a permanent error, it does not make sense to retry establishing a connection in that case.
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this* "if S1 exits before dialog establishment":  Are you concerned about S1 exiting cleanly while the connection protocol is running?  In that case, the logic to not allow S1 to terminate while the protocol is running should be fixed (in case it is broken).  If you are rather concerned about S1 crashing midway through the connection protocol, then (a) the comment "the other instance may have already terminated" is misleading (should talk about "crash" rather than "termination"), and (b) it is unclear to me whether one wants to really (re-)do all the actions specified on the command line -- e.g., the command line might contain a print request, and from the crash of S1 S2 cannot tell whether or not that had already succeeded or not.* addArgument returning false is a permanent error, it does not make sense to retry establishing a connection in that case.

text: Patch Set 2:Yes, I intend to do it (btw, it seems another place in Windows startup code implements this protocol, but I believe it's unused: see desktop/win32/source/officeloader/officeloader.cxx).But I'm also fixing a related Windows only issue #33484.I hope to get both patches ready soon (what's the deadline for 4.0 ?)
Text: Patch Set 2:Yes, I intend to do it (btw, it seems another place in Windows startup code implements this protocol, but I believe it's unused: see desktop/win32/source/officeloader/officeloader.cxx).But I'm also fixing a related Windows only issue #33484.I hope to get both patches ready soon (what's the deadline for 4.0 ?)

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitNice patch, only few things:- the point why _TARBALL variables are in configure is that we can use them in ooo.lst.in- what is wps and wpd doing in StaticLibrary_jpeg.mk ?- also you don't need to set cxx suffix for c files- gdk-pixbuf needs jpeg's headers, so you need to use ExternalPackage or maybe somehow fix modules which depend on jpegThanks for more gbuild work. Encouraging.
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitNice patch, only few things:- the point why _TARBALL variables are in configure is that we can use them in ooo.lst.in- what is wps and wpd doing in StaticLibrary_jpeg.mk ?- also you don't need to set cxx suffix for c files- gdk-pixbuf needs jpeg's headers, so you need to use ExternalPackage or maybe somehow fix modules which depend on jpegThanks for more gbuild work. Encouraging.

text: Patch Set 1:I tried to use UNO API as in sw/ unittest, but my skill isn't enough to accomplish it. ;) So, for a record, the BASIC script to run is:  xray ThisComponent.DrawPages(0).getByIndex(i).getSize().Heightfor i = 0 to 3. All result should be 1. This obviously means it shouldn't be any negative number (the bug is that it is negative for i = 0).Anyway, now we have 2 (and this is the third) pptx in sd/qa/unit/data/. Would it better to have it in a folder? If yes, which folder?Thanks!
Text: Patch Set 1:I tried to use UNO API as in sw/ unittest, but my skill isn't enough to accomplish it. ;) So, for a record, the BASIC script to run is:  xray ThisComponent.DrawPages(0).getByIndex(i).getSize().Heightfor i = 0 to 3. All result should be 1. This obviously means it shouldn't be any negative number (the bug is that it is negative for i = 0).Anyway, now we have 2 (and this is the third) pptx in sd/qa/unit/data/. Would it better to have it in a folder? If yes, which folder?Thanks!

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitHi Korrawit,Its really nice to have unit tests created. Thank you so much. But, I believe this is incomplete as yet?To test this pptx: (one of the methods)a) Get SdrPageconst SdrPage *pPage = pDoc->GetPage (1);b) Get Objects:sal_uIntPtr nObjs = pPage->GetObjCount();c) iterate on the object to find the object you are looking for - in this case arrows/lines.d) Test the height of it.[This is directly using sd classes]The other method is to use UNO calls like its done in testStuff() - testStuff() is an example though - you would have to do the test/uno calls yourself in testFdo47434() e.g.Regarding the directory: I was thinking of something specific to pptx - not much idea there, though :(It would be really nice if you could complete this patch, though.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Noel,Thank you for your review.I agree your observation, anyway the point is when the entered value reflects on new Characters per line's range.It is not just after entering "10" or "5" for max base text size, but further after the focus leaved (e.g. typing tab key) to indicate end of editing.That timing is same as the existing synchronization of Lines per page's range following max base text size.Note also that the reflection occurs immediately after spinning the value by clicking up or down arrow.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Noel,Thank you for your review.I agree your observation, anyway the point is when the entered value reflects on new Characters per line's range.It is not just after entering "10" or "5" for max base text size, but further after the focus leaved (e.g. typing tab key) to indicate end of editing.That timing is same as the existing synchronization of Lines per page's range following max base text size.Note also that the reflection occurs immediately after spinning the value by clicking up or down arrow.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this(3 inline comments)Please check the memory leaks and try to fix them.Returning the reference to the memory that you just allocated with new will not release the memory. We either need an empty static string (which I personally don't like) or check all callers and think about just returning by value and hope that it will optimized.
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this(3 inline comments)Please check the memory leaks and try to fix them.Returning the reference to the memory that you just allocated with new will not release the memory. We either need an empty static string (which I personally don't like) or check all callers and think about just returning by value and hope that it will optimized.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitRegarding memory leaks when replacing EMPTY_STRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyString() with new'ed instances of OUString:The empty String used so far is a refcounted instance to avoid creation of additional instances for every empty string. We should have a similar mechanism for OUString, e.g EMPTY_OUSTRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyOUString(). So if you could just add such mechanism it would be fine.
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitRegarding memory leaks when replacing EMPTY_STRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyString() with new'ed instances of OUString:The empty String used so far is a refcounted instance to avoid creation of additional instances for every empty string. We should have a similar mechanism for OUString, e.g EMPTY_OUSTRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyOUString(). So if you could just add such mechanism it would be fine.

text: Patch Set 2:I followed Eike's suggestion and added EMPTY_OUSTRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyOUString() and changed the returns of empty strings to use these. That should remove the memleak. Thanks for the reviews
Text: Patch Set 2:I followed Eike's suggestion and added EMPTY_OUSTRING and ScGlobal::GetEmptyOUString() and changed the returns of empty strings to use these. That should remove the memleak. Thanks for the reviews

text: Patch Set 1:> If we now *know* that we will never want to use the Python 2.7 that > macOS presumably is stuck with as system Python, why does the > configure.ac even have code like: >  > PYTHON_CFLAGS="-I$FRAMEWORKSHOME/Python.framework/Versions/${python_version}/include/python${python_version}"we have hoped that one day Apple will upgrade its 5 year old system python to something current.  it looks like we may have to hope a little longer. > instead, if it notices that it thinks it should use a system Python > on macOS, it should AC_MSG_ERROR.that's a good idea, the python 2.7 support is really only supposed to be used in old enterprise distros that don't have python 3 and don't allow us to bundle python 3.

text: Patch Set 1:Called functions: probably setFloat / setDouble / setInt / setLong / ... or updateFloat / updateDouble / updateInt / updateLong / ...From the point of view of the driver, it should provide all of those, and the calling code chooses which one to call. Calling code can not only be LibreOffice C++ code, but also user macros, so it cannot be predicted what choice is made.When you create a table and select a DECIMAL or NUMERIC field type, don't you have the following field properties, including "Decimal places"?Entry requires: Length: Decimal places:Default value:Format example:The rounding may be because the driver tells the rest of LibreOffice that 0 decimal places are allowed. Or it may be in the configuration of the UI element. Create a form, and edit the properties of the form control: do you use a formatted field or a numeric field? In a numeric field you can set the decimal accuracy. Check what is put there.When all else fails, I single-step in a debugger from the control's "write to the database calls" into the different layers. But that is a bit heavy-weight :)
Text: Patch Set 1:Called functions: probably setFloat / setDouble / setInt / setLong / ... or updateFloat / updateDouble / updateInt / updateLong / ...From the point of view of the driver, it should provide all of those, and the calling code chooses which one to call. Calling code can not only be LibreOffice C++ code, but also user macros, so it cannot be predicted what choice is made.When you create a table and select a DECIMAL or NUMERIC field type, don't you have the following field properties, including "Decimal places"?Entry requires: Length: Decimal places:Default value:Format example:The rounding may be because the driver tells the rest of LibreOffice that 0 decimal places are allowed. Or it may be in the configuration of the UI element. Create a form, and edit the properties of the form control: do you use a formatted field or a numeric field? In a numeric field you can set the decimal accuracy. Check what is put there.When all else fails, I single-step in a debugger from the control's "write to the database calls" into the different layers. But that is a bit heavy-weight :)

text: Patch Set 6:> Very likely it conflicts with a patch of the same bug I submitted > some time ago: >  > https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/28817/ >  > and has not been reviewed / merged.Outstanding patches does not conflict with each other, gerrit always compares with master. Problem is normally that people forget to do "git pull -r" in their local repo, before submitting the patch, which is then based on an old version of master.Apart from that, yes it seems we now have 2 patches with very similar content, oliver@ you are the requestor of the patches, please abandon one of them.
Text: Patch Set 6:> Very likely it conflicts with a patch of the same bug I submitted > some time ago: >  > https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/28817/ >  > and has not been reviewed / merged.Outstanding patches does not conflict with each other, gerrit always compares with master. text: Patch Set 1:@Regina - your views on this matter (what htietze has pointed out) please..The same thing seems to happen with what YanP has suggested in the comments of tdf#92152.. One direction - seems fine, rotate it, there's a slight offset.. I wonder how to go about setting that right.. Three things come to mind 1) Tweaking the viewBox and in turn the d= parameters. I don't think this would do it though.2) See the code for how the svg is actually processed (I don't quite know where to look) ..3) Ignore it coz it's visible only when one zooms in really considerably. At the moment, the half arrow is exactly half the size of the full arrow and everything else seems pretty alright.The issue is that all the other arrows are symmetric and there is no precedent to look at for this case of half arrow.
Text: Patch Set 1:@Regina - your views on this matter (what htietze has pointed out) please..The same thing seems to happen with what YanP has suggested in the comments of tdf#92152.. One direction - seems fine, rotate it, there's a slight offset.. I wonder how to go about setting that right.. Three things come to mind 1) Tweaking the viewBox and in turn the d= parameters. I don't think this would do it though.2) See the code for how the svg is actually processed (I don't quite know where to look) ..3) Ignore it coz it's visible only when one zooms in really considerably. At the moment, the half arrow is exactly half the size of the full arrow and everything else seems pretty alright.The issue is that all the other arrows are symmetric and there is no precedent to look at for this case of half arrow.

text: Patch Set 1:Wrt. the starvation - actually that was due to the logging; we have so much debugging stuff that it was blocking considerably when writing to the console, making the queue grow.  Without that, all works fine even with the unmodified TileQueue :-)But I worked on the TileQueue too - it seems unnecessary to do all the priority shuffling when inserting, when the prioritization changes with every view switch, and instead do it only when the tile is requested - which seems to work nicely.Wrt. an own queue for tiles - that is exactly the thing that makes the synchronzation hard, as then it is necessary to synchronize between those 2 queues; which in turn kills all the advantage of 2 queues :-)Wrt. PNG compression; if we want to thread it, then let's thread just the compression - that'll make it local, more maintainable, and we can go with as many threads there as we wish (for just the PNG compression piece of code).Wrt. the 342125b8ea - thanks for that!  Unfortunately that again just adds code :-(Either way, please check https://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/online/log/?h=private/kendy/tilesandcallbacks , I'd really like to get that in...  I've tested it with several people in a session, and it performed pretty well thanks to all your work I was able to build on.
Text: Patch Set 1:Wrt. the starvation - actually that was due to the logging; we have so much debugging stuff that it was blocking considerably when writing to the console, making the queue grow.  Without that, all works fine even with the unmodified TileQueue :-)But I worked on the TileQueue too - it seems unnecessary to do all the priority shuffling when inserting, when the prioritization changes with every view switch, and instead do it only when the tile is requested - which seems to work nicely.Wrt. an own queue for tiles - that is exactly the thing that makes the synchronzation hard, as then it is necessary to synchronize between those 2 queues; which in turn kills all the advantage of 2 queues :-)Wrt. PNG compression; if we want to thread it, then let's thread just the compression - that'll make it local, more maintainable, and we can go with as many threads there as we wish (for just the PNG compression piece of code).Wrt. the 342125b8ea - thanks for that!  Unfortunately that again just adds code :-(Either way, please check https://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/online/log/?h=private/kendy/tilesandcallbacks , I'd really like to get that in...  I've tested it with several people in a session, and it performed pretty well thanks to all your work I was able to build on.

text: Patch Set 3:Thanks Eike and Markus for your comments !I had some time to look at it yesterday and it seems this line in viewfun3.cxx:1166 doesn┬┤t check all ranges in the first place.ScEditableTester aTester( pDoc, nStartTab, nStartCol,nStartRow, nUndoEndCol,nUndoEndRow );So - correct if I am wrong - in order to fix the issue with pasting into protected cells, I should remove all protected cells from the destination range if there are multiple tabs selected.
Text: Patch Set 3:Thanks Eike and Markus for your comments !I had some time to look at it yesterday and it seems this line in viewfun3.cxx:1166 doesn鈹敜t check all ranges in the first place.ScEditableTester aTester( pDoc, nStartTab, nStartCol,nStartRow, nUndoEndCol,nUndoEndRow );So - correct if I am wrong - in order to fix the issue with pasting into protected cells, I should remove all protected cells from the destination range if there are multiple tabs selected.

text: Patch Set 1:This string isn't actually used for anything except the customization dialog, as the toolbar strips the '...' anyway, and the menu label is replaced at runtime with the one from http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sfx2/source/doc/doc.src#27Since we're changing the menu label at runtime anyway, maybe it would be better to add the '...' dynamically when in unsaved document, and hide it otherwise? (Most of the time people deal with already saved docs, so showing the '...' always is a bit odd IMHO.)

(Most of the time people deal with already saved docs, so showing the '...' always is a bit odd IMHO.)

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Thanks for the patch. Good start indeed. Let's improve it a bit.1) Please insert a section "To access this function" and indicate the many ways to get to the tab page. See for example http://vm173.documentfoundation.org/text/shared/01/05210100.xhp. To insert this section, use the helpauthoring extension.2) Since we have a new tab, the old bitmap help page must be corrected. Bookmarks related to "pattern" and "editor" must now point to your new page.3) Please check the contents because I read gradients in Modify section.4) you may want to insert a section "Related topics" and point to the bipmap tab page.that's it for the time being.

text: Patch Set 6:Oliver, I forgot to mention that, while this fix makes "Further comments on page <pagefield + n>." *possible*, it would require the user to go into that particular page number field and set the offset. That matches Microsoft Word's offset behavior. Offset is never globally applied across fields. It is applied manually to individual fields. A footer is just the most common instance (at which point, the one instance of the page number is offset on all footers because of the footer's functionality, not the page number's functionality).Whether we eventually abandon this or not (see immediately prior comment), I'll address your inline comment. Good catch!
Text: Patch Set 6:Oliver, I forgot to mention that, while this fix makes "Further comments on page <pagefield + n>." *possible*, it would require the user to go into that particular page number field and set the offset. That matches Microsoft Word's offset behavior. Offset is never globally applied across fields. It is applied manually to individual fields. A footer is just the most common instance (at which point, the one instance of the page number is offset on all footers because of the footer's functionality, not the page number's functionality).Whether we eventually abandon this or not (see immediately prior comment), I'll address your inline comment. Good catch!

text: Patch Set 4:This will commit every transaction the user started manually as soon as a statement is executed successfully. Not a good idea, since then the user cannot rollback the transaction should he choose to.Taking a look at Connection.cxx, I see that there is already the whole infrastructure to enable autocommit. So I suggest that the code (probably in dbaccess/) that creates a Firebird connection to an embedded database enable autocommit (by calling setAutoCommit(sal_True) on the connection) and that's it.
Text: Patch Set 4:This will commit every transaction the user started manually as soon as a statement is executed successfully. Not a good idea, since then the user cannot rollback the transaction should he choose to.Taking a look at Connection.cxx, I see that there is already the whole infrastructure to enable autocommit. So I suggest that the code (probably in dbaccess/) that creates a Firebird connection to an embedded database enable autocommit (by calling setAutoCommit(sal_True) on the connection) and that's it.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Caolan,this can be done (and should, on-demand for gif/animated is a good move - a candidate for runtime-removable data anyways), but I would do it different. I would keep BitmapPrimitive2D as base primitive, alone for the name. The animated one is the specialization from my POV, so that one should be created for gif/animated, be derived from BitmapPirimitive2D and do special needed things for animated stuff.Just my 2ct...
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Caolan,this can be done (and should, on-demand for gif/animated is a good move - a candidate for runtime-removable data anyways), but I would do it different. I would keep BitmapPrimitive2D as base primitive, alone for the name. The animated one is the specialization from my POV, so that one should be created for gif/animated, be derived from BitmapPirimitive2D and do special needed things for animated stuff.Just my 2ct...

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1this is a bit of a special case. If you see us calling acquire() in the constructor and then calling release() in the destructor, and there is no call to delete in the destructor, then it is safe to say that we should rather be using uno::Reference to manage this object.(Or at least, some kind of Reference<> smart pointer - there are other kinds besides uno::Reference, but uno::Reference is the one you need here)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1this is a bit of a special case. If you see us calling acquire() in the constructor and then calling release() in the destructor, and there is no call to delete in the destructor, then it is safe to say that we should rather be using uno::Reference to manage this object.(Or at least, some kind of Reference<> smart pointer - there are other kinds besides uno::Reference, but uno::Reference is the one you need here)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I don't think this is a good idea for the following reasons:The basic number formatter codes follow the ones Excel uses. The new 'MIMI' upon Excel export would have to be mapped to 'mm', re-reading such file the information would be lost.If there are ambiguous corner cases, those would have to be handled anyway as importing an Excel file could expose them as well, for example the code mentioned in the bug "yymmdd-ssmm" can be assigned in Excel.Adding "minutes-unambiguous" to ODF from a standard's view is suboptimal, from an ODF view the <number:minutes> element is not ambiguous. Likely a <number:minutes-unambiguous> element will not make it into the standard.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I don't think this is a good idea for the following reasons:The basic number formatter codes follow the ones Excel uses. The new 'MIMI' upon Excel export would have to be mapped to 'mm', re-reading such file the information would be lost.If there are ambiguous corner cases, those would have to be handled anyway as importing an Excel file could expose them as well, for example the code mentioned in the bug "yymmdd-ssmm" can be assigned in Excel.Adding "minutes-unambiguous" to ODF from a standard's view is suboptimal, from an ODF view the <number:minutes> element is not ambiguous. Likely a <number:minutes-unambiguous> element will not make it into the standard.

Text: Patch Set 2:The macro looks good, it should be just "TableStyles" (plural).

text: Patch Set 2:Hi,> this would need to return a http://api.libreoffice.org/docs/idl/ref/interfacecom_1_1sun_1_1star_1_1style_1_1XStyle.htmlAgreed.> there isnt anything like a XTableStyle interface in UNO so farRight. Though Impress already has something like a table style, so that's the pattern I suggest to follow in Writer. If the same UNO API is implemented, then most of the table style import/export code can be shared between Writer and Impress in xmloff.> there is no separation between a table and its style in writer core so farThe "style" is the autoformat, SwTable::maTableStyleName stores the autoformat of the table, if it has any.> what should this actually return? Even the members in the existing basic XStyle interface like "isInUse()" cant be doneI guess it's fairly straightforward to implement it: need to iterate over SwTables, and see if any of them has the autoformat set to the given autoformat.So yes, I agree that table style is different to paragraph/character styles, but given that we have autoformats, it's reasonable to build on top of that, and I think it's fairly possible to provide UNO API, filters, UI building on top of this. But let me know if you see issues with that -- the more input from experienced devs, the better. :-)
Text: Patch Set 2:Hi,> this would need to return a http://api.libreoffice.org/docs/idl/ref/interfacecom_1_1sun_1_1star_1_1style_1_1XStyle.htmlAgreed.> there isnt anything like a XTableStyle interface in UNO so farRight. Though Impress already has something like a table style, so that's the pattern I suggest to follow in Writer. If the same UNO API is implemented, then most of the table style import/export code can be shared between Writer and Impress in xmloff.> there is no separation between a table and its style in writer core so farThe "style" is the autoformat, SwTable::maTableStyleName stores the autoformat of the table, if it has any.> what should this actually return? Even the members in the existing basic XStyle interface like "isInUse()" cant be doneI guess it's fairly straightforward to implement it: need to iterate over SwTables, and see if any of them has the autoformat set to the given autoformat.So yes, I agree that table style is different to paragraph/character styles, but given that we have autoformats, it's reasonable to build on top of that, and I think it's fairly possible to provide UNO API, filters, UI building on top of this. But let me know if you see issues with that -- the more input from experienced devs, the better. :-)

text: Patch Set 1:1) This does not compile2) I don't see how this will achieve anything, much less what is requested in tdf#67647. The most glaring, but not only thing, is that it calls a getNormalizedFilter that does not exist.tdf#67647 has "two levels":1) first level: take the actual implementation of getStructuredFilter and fix it to not include the operator in the value member, AND FIX ALL CALLERS to not expect it anymore.2) Design a completely new API that is better than "StructuredFilter" and replaces it and implement said new API.I'm totally fine with doing (only) the first level (the second level is beyond a EasyHack), but it has to be done...

text: Patch Set 1:Hi Kendy,Please look into this and tell me if it is the right way to proceed.This throws the Unknown Property Exception as indicated below.I think we may need to call this setPropertyValue() <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/editeng/source/uno/unofield.cxx#675> instead of the one currently being called <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2152> which is throwing up an Unknown Property Exception at <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2165> One is sw's implementation while the other is editeng's implementation. Moggi was of the opinion that the setPropertyValue() from editeng couldn't be called here. But the current one is unable to support that property (UNO_TC_PROP_TEXTFIELD_TYPE). How would it be possible to proceed?I'm influenced by this comment <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl#19> when I say the above.Also, I did a '#define UNO_NAME_TEXT_FIELD_TYPE "TextFieldType"' in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/inc/unoprnms.hxx> taking other properties from here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/editeng/unonames.hxx> as an example. But I'm unsure if this is the right way to proceed.Since I've mentioned '[optional, property]long TextFieldType;' as optional in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/ExtendedUser.idl>, I might need a boolean to indicate when 'setPropertyValue()' must be called for each of the fields from <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl> in here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/xmloff/source/text/txtfldi.cxx#706>. I don't think we need to call it for all 15 properties all the time. How do I use the boolean variable - like for example - how do I use it to indicate when to set EXTENDED_TIME and when not to..?Regarding the comment thread on the bug page - you'd asked what happens when I run it without removing certain stuff from content.xml . The exact same exceptions are thrown in the order of Comment 13 first and then Comment 14.On a side note, I would like to say that I'm doing this coz you'd asked me to work on LO code (with respect to GSoC) and this was a bug reported by you. Since you didn't remember filing this bug, if there is something else that you'd want me to work on, please do tell.I would have loved to work on creating MAR files (from onlineupdate module), and still do think that's the best thing to do as it would mean I would get a headstart when it comes to the actual coding period begin dates, and had sent a mail to you regarding that. But on not receivng a reply, I'd assumed you didn't want me to work on that. Please do indicate what you think I should be working on.Thanks :-)
Text: Patch Set 1:Hi Kendy,Please look into this and tell me if it is the right way to proceed.This throws the Unknown Property Exception as indicated below.I think we may need to call this setPropertyValue() <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/editeng/source/uno/unofield.cxx#675> instead of the one currently being called <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2152> which is throwing up an Unknown Property Exception at <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2165> One is sw's implementation while the other is editeng's implementation. Moggi was of the opinion that the setPropertyValue() from editeng couldn't be called here. But the current one is unable to support that property (UNO_TC_PROP_TEXTFIELD_TYPE). How would it be possible to proceed?I'm influenced by this comment <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl#19> when I say the above.Also, I did a '#define UNO_NAME_TEXT_FIELD_TYPE "TextFieldType"' in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/inc/unoprnms.hxx> taking other properties from here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/editeng/unonames.hxx> as an example. But I'm unsure if this is the right way to proceed.Since I've mentioned '[optional, property]long TextFieldType;' as optional in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/ExtendedUser.idl>, I might need a boolean to indicate when 'setPropertyValue()' must be called for each of the fields from <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl> in here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/xmloff/source/text/txtfldi.cxx#706>. I don't think we need to call it for all 15 properties all the time. How do I use the boolean variable - like for example - how do I use it to indicate when to set EXTENDED_TIME and when not to..?Regarding the comment thread on the bug page - you'd asked what happens when I run it without removing certain stuff from content.xml . The exact same exceptions are thrown in the order of Comment 13 first and then Comment 14.On a side note, I would like to say that I'm doing this coz you'd asked me to work on LO code (with respect to GSoC) and this was a bug reported by you. Since you didn't remember filing this bug, if there is something else that you'd want me to work on, please do tell.I would have loved to work on creating MAR files (from onlineupdate module), and still do think that's the best thing to do as it would mean I would get a headstart when it comes to the actual coding period begin dates, and had sent a mail to you regarding that. But on not receivng a reply, I'd assumed you didn't want me to work on that. Please do indicate what you think I should be working on.Thanks :-)

text: Patch Set 2:Agreed - so I imagine that the idea is that the intermediate created VclPtr<> is converted to a reference_type * by an operator - and then the VclPtr<> is then unreffed - before the reset() completes. I hope that's unlikely - surely the intermediate VclPtr should stick around not just for the scope of operator, but the nested parent function call too ?
Text: Patch Set 2:Agreed - so I imagine that the idea is that the intermediate created VclPtr<> is converted to a reference_type * by an operator - and then the VclPtr<> is then unreffed - before the reset() completes. I hope that's unlikely - surely the intermediate VclPtr should stick around not just for the scope of operator, but the nested parent function call too ?

text: Patch Set 2:> Agreed - so I imagine that the idea is that the intermediate > created VclPtr<> is converted to a reference_type * by an operator > - and then the VclPtr<> is then unreffed - before the reset() > completes. I hope that's unlikely - surely the intermediate VclPtr > should stick around not just for the scope of operator, but the > nested parent function call too ?Given that its an inline method, possibly the compiler is hoisting the deref above the call? Would have to disassemble to know for sure.We could fix this in a generic fashion by adding a   void reset(VclPtr<T>)overload to VclPtr

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hi N├®meth,thanks a lot for this, good to see the Slide Pane being improved.As you can see in #89668, we wanted to add a toolbar at the bottom of the slide pane anyway. Maybe you can replace the fixed button with a toolbar?That way, the design team can also modify the toolbar afterwards (given the toolbar is defined in an .ui file).About the "Presentation" button: I feel that one toolbar with actions for the slide pane is enough - two would use too much height. So I would remove that button.Could you implement these changes? Or, if you have other suggestions, we might discuss it in our design meeting on Friday.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hi N鈹溌甿eth,thanks a lot for this, good to see the Slide Pane being improved.As you can see in #89668, we wanted to add a toolbar at the bottom of the slide pane anyway. Maybe you can replace the fixed button with a toolbar?That way, the design team can also modify the toolbar afterwards (given the toolbar is defined in an .ui file).About the "Presentation" button: I feel that one toolbar with actions for the slide pane is enough - two would use too much height. So I would remove that button.Could you implement these changes? Or, if you have other suggestions, we might discuss it in our design meeting on Friday.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2@Noel: Urgh, indeed.FWIW, the whole mpAntiImpl think is a mess. SvtFileView_Impl creates mpAntiImpl (a VclPtr) from the naked this ptr of SvtFileView, which I assume is ref-counted and hold by whatever created it.So the SvtFileView is owned by the VclPtr in SvtFileView_Impl _and_ by the VclPtr of whatever created the SvtFileView. This cant end well.Sooo -- mpAntiImpl should probably be a plain reference as:- the wrapper should always live longer than the impl anyway- the impl doesnt have any business at all in messing with ownership of its wrapper.
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2@Noel: Urgh, indeed.FWIW, the whole mpAntiImpl think is a mess. SvtFileView_Impl creates mpAntiImpl (a VclPtr) from the naked this ptr of SvtFileView, which I assume is ref-counted and hold by whatever created it.So the SvtFileView is owned by the VclPtr in SvtFileView_Impl _and_ by the VclPtr of whatever created the SvtFileView. This cant end well.Sooo -- mpAntiImpl should probably be a plain reference as:- the wrapper should always live longer than the impl anyway- the impl doesnt have any business at all in messing with ownership of its wrapper.

text: Patch Set 1:things seem to go overboard here with the abandoning of stuff.The individual patches are fine - just  because you cannot merge one before the other  doesn't make it a bad thing to have incremental approaches, as it's easier to go through smaller patches that by themselves are self-contained, than through one huge dump.So if you can review stuff individually, one after the other, then having a series of patches is perfectly fine.

text: Patch Set 1:Checked deeper. There is only a single call to BlendBitmap with that many parameters in DrawDeviceAlphaBitmapSlowPath. It uses a helper class called TradScaleContext to create the mappings. That class already tries to use mirroring:        const bool bHMirr = aOutSize.Width() < 0;        const bool bVMirr = aOutSize.Height() < 0;Sidenote: Metric values like Width/Height can be negaitve, currently allowed by the definition of Rectangle. this is by itself not good - better use B2IRange and transformations.Thus, this already applies mirroring to the array (as suggested in last coment). Since bHMirr, bVMirr are calculated the same way this should happen.Thus mirroring gets already applied in the index arrays (as suggested in the last comment). So this patch is more about the 'alignment' of the to-be-blended part relative to the target bitmap. In that case all may be as intended.Still not sure about the indices and if nMapY, nMapX are safe in the call to pA->GetPixelIndex to be in bounds. If not, LO will crash
Text: Patch Set 1:Checked deeper. There is only a single call to BlendBitmap with that many parameters in DrawDeviceAlphaBitmapSlowPath. It uses a helper class called TradScaleContext to create the mappings. That class already tries to use mirroring:        const bool bHMirr = aOutSize.Width() < 0;        const bool bVMirr = aOutSize.Height() < 0;Sidenote: Metric values like Width/Height can be negaitve, currently allowed by the definition of Rectangle. this is by itself not good - better use B2IRange and transformations.Thus, this already applies mirroring to the array (as suggested in last coment). Since bHMirr, bVMirr are calculated the same way this should happen.Thus mirroring gets already applied in the index arrays (as suggested in the last comment). So this patch is more about the 'alignment' of the to-be-blended part relative to the target bitmap. In that case all may be as intended.Still not sure about the indices and if nMapY, nMapX are safe in the call to pA->GetPixelIndex to be in bounds. If not, LO will crash

text: Patch Set 1:Sorry for the hassle - tried to debug now. On current Linux master  with attachment from comment8 from bugzilla task, no OpenGL. LinearScaleContext also takes care of mirroring.@Toma┼¥: Can you have a look at DrawDeviceAlphaBitmapSlowPath in the aspect of mirroring?

text: Patch Set 1:Code looks good.  However, pushing it now would break builds that have the Clang plugins enabled.  So please use the plugin to find and fix all places it warns about.  If it is just a handful, you can do one patch including all fixes.  If it is significantly many (which I assume), better split it into manageable chunks, like one patch per module (plus accompanying include files under top-level include/ dir, if any)."stinnspace" is a somewhat incomprehensible tag.  Maybe renaming (all of tag, class, filename) to something like "staticanonymous" would be better.  (Technically, it's called an unnamed namespace, not an anonymous one, but it's probably OK to be imprecise as "staticunnamed" sounds less clear.)Some of the first plugins that got written (and which you apparently took as blueprint) use a somewhat odd coding style.  It's OK to leave things as they are, but you can also change it if you feel more comfortable with any of the alternatives:* The standard license header from TEMPLATE.SOURCECODE.HEADER.* Putting everything into a single .cxx file (and into an unnamed namespace).* Not indenting a block's enclosing curly braces the same as the enclosed content.
Text: Patch Set 1:Code looks good.  However, pushing it now would break builds that have the Clang plugins enabled.  So please use the plugin to find and fix all places it warns about.  If it is just a handful, you can do one patch including all fixes.  If it is significantly many (which I assume), better split it into manageable chunks, like one patch per module (plus accompanying include files under top-level include/ dir, if any)."stinnspace" is a somewhat incomprehensible tag.  Maybe renaming (all of tag, class, filename) to something like "staticanonymous" would be better.  (Technically, it's called an unnamed namespace, not an anonymous one, but it's probably OK to be imprecise as "staticunnamed" sounds less clear.)Some of the first plugins that got written (and which you apparently took as blueprint) use a somewhat odd coding style.  It's OK to leave things as they are, but you can also change it if you feel more comfortable with any of the alternatives:* The standard license header from TEMPLATE.SOURCECODE.HEADER.* Putting everything into a single .cxx file (and into an unnamed namespace).* Not indenting a block's enclosing curly braces the same as the enclosed content.

text: Patch Set 1:> Sorry for the onslaught of questions, I really want to> understand the things that I am about to do.sal/ is a small, self-contained library. Please use 'git grep' and or ls -R (or browse in a file explorer) to answer your own questions. In terms of finding a good place for a header to share those declarations - again, see what other modules do; and if there is nothing doing something similar, then create a new header at the location of your choice.Thanks.

text: Patch Set 2:Apologies for my late response on this issue. The following is my rationale for reverting strdup back into PL_strdup:--https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSPR/About_NSPR"Memory managementNSPR provides API to perform the basic malloc, calloc, realloc and free functions. Depending on the platform, the functions may be implemented almost entirely in the NSPR runtime or simply shims that call immediately into the host operating system's offerings."-> thus replacing PL_strdup with strdup may cause different results on different platforms--https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSPR/Reference/PL_strdup"Returns a pointer to a new memory node in the NSPR heap containing a copy of a specified string.Syntax#include <plstr.h>char *PL_strdup(const char *s);NotesThe memory allocated by PL_strdup should be freed with PL_strfree."--http://linux.die.net/man/3/strdup"DescriptionThe strdup() function returns a pointer to a new string which is a duplicate of the string s. Memory for the new string is obtained with malloc(3), and can be freed with free(3)."-> there is no guarantee that memory on the heap used by strdup (i.e. the heap used by malloc) can be freed using PL_strfree.--Due to these concerns, I would like to request for this change be reopened and re-evaluated. Thank you for your patience on this issue.
Text: Patch Set 2:Apologies for my late response on this issue. The following is my rationale for reverting strdup back into PL_strdup:--https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSPR/About_NSPR"Memory managementNSPR provides API to perform the basic malloc, calloc, realloc and free functions. Depending on the platform, the functions may be implemented almost entirely in the NSPR runtime or simply shims that call immediately into the host operating system's offerings."-> thus replacing PL_strdup with strdup may cause different results on different platforms--https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSPR/Reference/PL_strdup"Returns a pointer to a new memory node in the NSPR heap containing a copy of a specified string.Syntax#include <plstr.h>char *PL_strdup(const char *s);NotesThe memory allocated by PL_strdup should be freed with PL_strfree."--http://linux.die.net/man/3/strdup"DescriptionThe strdup() function returns a pointer to a new string which is a duplicate of the string s. Memory for the new string is obtained with malloc(3), and can be freed with free(3)."-> there is no guarantee that memory on the heap used by strdup (i.e. the heap used by malloc) can be freed using PL_strfree.--Due to these concerns, I would like to request for this change be reopened and re-evaluated. Thank you for your patience on this issue.

text: Patch Set 5:On Wed, Jan 27, 2016 at 02:57:30PM +0300, Justin Luth <justin_luth@sil.org> wrote:> I'm working on page-level vertical centring and think that I have a> fairly workable solution for displaying existing documents.  How> feature-complete does a new enhancement need to be in order to be merged> into master?I think the question is if you plan to improve the situationincrementally on top of this in master before 5.2 or not. If so, thenit's fine to push something half-baked into master, as it's good toavoid huge commits that do everything.For Writer features, I added a checklist to the wiki:https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Writer#Adding_a_new_featureIf the doc model and the UNO API is ready, then adding layout support(without UI and so on) is I think acceptable temporarily.
Text: Patch Set 5:On Wed, Jan 27, 2016 at 02:57:30PM +0300, Justin Luth <justin_luth@sil.org> wrote:> I'm working on page-level vertical centring and think that I have a> fairly workable solution for displaying existing documents.  How> feature-complete does a new enhancement need to be in order to be merged> into master?I think the question is if you plan to improve the situationincrementally on top of this in master before 5.2 or not. If so, thenit's fine to push something half-baked into master, as it's good toavoid huge commits that do everything.For Writer features, I added a checklist to the wiki:https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Writer#Adding_a_new_featureIf the doc model and the UNO API is ready, then adding layout support(without UI and so on) is I think acceptable temporarily.

text: Patch Set 5:Hi KoheiYou were right my builds were not clean and i had some debug code. Sorry for that. I did a full rebuild of the libreoffice project with ./autogen.sh --without-java --without-help --without-myspell-dicts no more --enable-dbgutil  and i hope it is sufficient for enabling optimizations. I made more tests, and the code is still slightly faster (1 to 2%), but i think it is in the error tolerance, and anyways things are really more important than percent... i was talking about saving three seconds over a ten minutes computation. Not really worth it ;)So i will revert to the original code and the functor.Now my question is, do you you have a prefered way to send information between ScColumn::StartListeners and class StartListenersHandler ?My first idea is to add an extra parameters to the constructor, a reference to the column, so it could set the FomulaFlag? How about this ?

How about this ?

text: Patch Set 5:HiSince yesterdays afternoon i have processed my original test files (about 100,000 lines) on a box faster than the one i used this summer with two different builds. Release builds. The first one was build from yesterdays master branch, the other with this patch set.The processing time was 5.80 hours with the current version of LO, and 3.29 hours with the patched version. That is close to a 1.75 ratio, and it saved two hours and a half of processing time. Most of the time was spent into the pDocument->InsertRow calls (from table3.cxx ScTable::DoSubTotals). During this night runs, the time spent in this method was ranging from 85.177 to 1089.3 ms with the current code, and from 81.755 to 394.771 ms with the patched code. The second most time consuming method is the call to SetString, with execution time varying from 0.01 to 147ms.
Text: Patch Set 5:HiSince yesterdays afternoon i have processed my original test files (about 100,000 lines) on a box faster than the one i used this summer with two different builds. Release builds. The first one was build from yesterdays master branch, the other with this patch set.The processing time was 5.80 hours with the current version of LO, and 3.29 hours with the patched version. That is close to a 1.75 ratio, and it saved two hours and a half of processing time. Most of the time was spent into the pDocument->InsertRow calls (from table3.cxx ScTable::DoSubTotals). During this night runs, the time spent in this method was ranging from 85.177 to 1089.3 ms with the current code, and from 81.755 to 394.771 ms with the patched code. The second most time consuming method is the call to SetString, with execution time varying from 0.01 to 147ms.

text: Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1> > Why would you want to link all these libraries into libmerged? > The hope is to start faster. e.g. if it runs as conversion server.And does it help?The point of libmerged was to merge libraries which are always loaded on start.You can get them with something like similar script:for app in 'writer' 'calc' 'draw' 'impress' 'base'do    LD_DEBUG=files OOO_EXIT_POST_STARTUP=1 ./instdir/program/soffice "--${app}" 2> temp_${app}.txt    cat temp_${app}.txt  | grep "calling init"  | cut -f 2 | cut -d " " -f 3 | sort  | uniq > libs_${app}.txtdonecat libs_* | sort | grep home | uniq -c | sort -r > libraries.txtFrom these, only acc should be merged.If it really will be useful for some scenario,maybe try resurrecting --enable-mergelibs=allor somehow enable to define specific set of libs on configure or...(See also fa8aaaadc38372185d6d29d8d91391907e95b689)
Text: Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1> > Why would you want to link all these libraries into libmerged? > The hope is to start faster. e.g. if it runs as conversion server.And does it help?The point of libmerged was to merge libraries which are always loaded on start.You can get them with something like similar script:for app in 'writer' 'calc' 'draw' 'impress' 'base'do    LD_DEBUG=files OOO_EXIT_POST_STARTUP=1 ./instdir/program/soffice "--${app}" 2> temp_${app}.txt    cat temp_${app}.txt  | grep "calling init"  | cut -f 2 | cut -d " " -f 3 | sort  | uniq > libs_${app}.txtdonecat libs_* | sort | grep home | uniq -c | sort -r > libraries.txtFrom these, only acc should be merged.If it really will be useful for some scenario,maybe try resurrecting --enable-mergelibs=allor somehow enable to define specific set of libs on configure or...(See also fa8aaaadc38372185d6d29d8d91391907e95b689)

text: Patch Set 4:Some functions seems in need to handle both. I guess we can't change the VBA interface ;-)Now there is INetURLObject(OUString const & rFSysPath, FSysStyle eStyle), so probably we can get rid of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, if we set eStyle according to the system settings?I also missed the smart parsing functionality. I had a look now, but didn't find code which would just accept system specific local paths, as there seems to be no system setting for FSYS_*, as FSYS_DETECT will - as far as my fast gimplse at the code told me - happily accept file URLs in any system notation, if you pass FSYS_DETECT.And there are a lot more users of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, which expect a local path right from the start. Some expect to use the input path, if it's correct, while others want the GetMainURL(). But I just found one with a different decoding then NO_DECODE.I can convert everything to smart URL and run make check, but I can't verify all places. We just need to define a FSYS_SYSTEM value somewhere, so we won't accept other system file encodings.
Text: Patch Set 4:Some functions seems in need to handle both. I guess we can't change the VBA interface ;-)Now there is INetURLObject(OUString const & rFSysPath, FSysStyle eStyle), so probably we can get rid of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, if we set eStyle according to the system settings?I also missed the smart parsing functionality. I had a look now, but didn't find code which would just accept system specific local paths, as there seems to be no system setting for FSYS_*, as FSYS_DETECT will - as far as my fast gimplse at the code told me - happily accept file URLs in any system notation, if you pass FSYS_DETECT.And there are a lot more users of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, which expect a local path right from the start. Some expect to use the input path, if it's correct, while others want the GetMainURL(). But I just found one with a different decoding then NO_DECODE.I can convert everything to smart URL and run make check, but I can't verify all places. We just need to define a FSYS_SYSTEM value somewhere, so we won't accept other system file encodings.

text: Patch Set 1:Hint:To _update_ a patch in gerrit (instead of creating a new one), you need to send a patch to gerrit with the same Change-Id as the original one. see:https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/gerrit/SubmitPatch#Submitting_a_new_versionfor the details.However, the more important part is to (re-)base your commit on a more recent master! This one is still based on:https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/gitweb?p=core.git;a=commitdiff;h=217a22188274221035aec988eccea5e5c9768921from Sept 2015 and since the files you changed where modified on the master branch in the meantime too, we cannot merge this as-is.Dont hesitate to ask for help when you cant get the rebase or other git/gerrit stuff done. We'll help you out!

text: Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Is this a correct version of the patch?Because I see the same problem with wrong constructor as in https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/19792/It needs to be created asXMLMetaExportComponent(context, "XMLMetaExportComponent", SvXMLExportFlags::META|SvXMLExportFlags::OASIS)And sorry for not being clear also with header removing.It's better to not remove header file *and not* move code from header to source file.Finally, please don't create new gerrit changes for the same patch like this.Use 'git commit --amend' and write correct ID. For this patch it should contain line "Change-Id: I3edde1291e9dec21420238edb5a05f25849ebfff"Oh - and also make sure 'make check' succeeds.Thanks

text: Patch Set 1:> The reason it was done that way (by me) is that the toolbar button > is a split button (i.e. it can be clicked on the button *or* on the > dropdown part), so it's possible to apply the last used color > easily. So the toolbar button shouldn't update with the current > color, but instead show the last used one.Uhm, I get the split button part (and I kept it in place), but I'm slightly challenged with what's the desirable behaviour supposed to be otherwise1. Sidebar and toolbar colour buttons don't update each other and at any time, they can contain totally disjunct sets of colours (status quo, almost)2. Sidebar and toolbar colour buttons are in sync, any time colour in sidebar changes, corresponding toolbar button is updated and vice versa3. Sidebar updates toolbar but not the other way round4. Toolbar updates sidebar but not the other way roundI don't want to step over conscious better design decisions, so the new text background colour button needs to follow the same path, whichever of the above it is
Text: Patch Set 1:> The reason it was done that way (by me) is that the toolbar button > is a split button (i.e. it can be clicked on the button *or* on the > dropdown part), so it's possible to apply the last used color > easily. Sidebar and toolbar colour buttons don't update each other and at any time, they can contain totally disjunct sets of colours (status quo, almost)2. Sidebar and toolbar colour buttons are in sync, any time colour in sidebar changes, corresponding toolbar button is updated and vice versa3. Sidebar updates toolbar but not the other way round4. Toolbar updates sidebar but not the other way roundI don't want to step over conscious better design decisions, so the new text background colour button needs to follow the same path, whichever of the above it is

text: Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1(6 comments)So, chatted with vin today, and browsed through the changes.There are two larger open questions: - what's the story for odf? implementation for native saving is    needed (for simple gradients, that works by using the svg gradient   definition, for complex gradients, probably an odf extension is   needed)   I would not block this patch b/c of that, but some   perspective/commitment on who and when this gets implemented would   be great - simply replacing gradient with gradient2 is not enough. at least the   implementation in vcl/source/gdi/gradient.cxx is missing,   but likely also fallbacks in metafile import and export, graphic   filters, and slideshow.My irc comment on testing - for the reviewer waving this through, isthere a set of test documents, or some more verbose bug report on whatexactly this does, and what will work once the patch is in?
Text: Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1(6 comments)So, chatted with vin today, and browsed through the changes.There are two larger open questions: - what's the story for odf? implementation for native saving is    needed (for simple gradients, that works by using the svg gradient   definition, for complex gradients, probably an odf extension is   needed)   I would not block this patch b/c of that, but some   perspective/commitment on who and when this gets implemented would   be great - simply replacing gradient with gradient2 is not enough. at least the   implementation in vcl/source/gdi/gradient.cxx is missing,   but likely also fallbacks in metafile import and export, graphic   filters, and slideshow.My irc comment on testing - for the reviewer waving this through, isthere a set of test documents, or some more verbose bug report on whatexactly this does, and what will work once the patch is in?
