text: Patch Set 6:Comment regarding GradientStop.RelativePosition: As it is relative, data type "long" makes no sense to me. Common values for a relative value are from the range 0 to 1 or in percentage syntax from 0% to 100%. ODF1.2 allows the element <svg:linearGradient> which has a child element <svg:stop>. This has the corresponding attribute svg:offset. It has data type double.Comment regarding color: ODF1.2 allowes <svg:linearGradien>. This has in its <svg:stop> child element the attribute svg:stop-opacity. com::sun::star::util::Color (in GradientStop.idl) can carry this information because it has an alpha channel. But basegfx::BColor is a B3DTuple and has only rgb. Opacity might not be necessary for OOXML but I think, that the design should be made in view of ODF1.2 too and therefore consider opacity in the internal maGradientStops vector.
Text: Patch Set 6:Comment regarding GradientStop.RelativePosition: As it is relative, data type "long" makes no sense to me. Common values for a relative value are from the range 0 to 1 or in percentage syntax from 0% to 100%. ODF1.2 allows the element <svg:linearGradient> which has a child element <svg:stop>. This has the corresponding attribute svg:offset. It has data type double.Comment regarding color: ODF1.2 allowes <svg:linearGradien>. This has in its <svg:stop> child element the attribute svg:stop-opacity. com::sun::star::util::Color (in GradientStop.idl) can carry this information because it has an alpha channel. But basegfx::BColor is a B3DTuple and has only rgb. Opacity might not be necessary for OOXML but I think, that the design should be made in view of ODF1.2 too and therefore consider opacity in the internal maGradientStops vector.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1Looks like a really useful approach to me.One slight note of caution though - by holding all these extra references - we need to check each one of these to make sure not just that it compiles - but also that we understood the lifecycle, and that the object holding the new VclPtr<> does indeed get explicitly dispose'd (particularly when the holder is not a Window sub-class).Did you do that ? otherwise this will just add leaks left & right.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1Looks like a really useful approach to me.One slight note of caution though - by holding all these extra references - we need to check each one of these to make sure not just that it compiles - but also that we understood the lifecycle, and that the object holding the new VclPtr<> does indeed get explicitly dispose'd (particularly when the holder is not a Window sub-class).Did you do that ? otherwise this will just add leaks left & right.

text: Patch Set 1:Heh - so, you're right it is a great cleanup in principle - but we need to watch the lifecycle rather carefully. I'd say for those that are in classes where we already have a dispose we can add a 'clear' to - it's a slam-dunk - should get those in ASAP; the others need more careful thought I think (prolly worth splitting into smaller commits for bisection too). Thanks !
Text: Patch Set 1:Heh - so, you're right it is a great cleanup in principle - but we need to watch the lifecycle rather carefully. I'd say for those that are in classes where we already have a dispose we can add a 'clear' to - it's a slam-dunk - should get those in ASAP; the others need more careful thought I think (prolly worth splitting into smaller commits for bisection too). text: Patch Set 3:> It is still confusing, what the purpose of this changes is. In the > current linear gradient implementation a gradient exists > independent of a shape. Therefore "diagonal" makes no sense.To get > the same behavior as the gradient in MS, where a "45┬░" linear > gradient is indeed diagonal for every rectangle, a new kind of > gradient is needed. This can be the svg:linearGradient as used inNo! 45 degrees is only for square - for rectangles the angle changes with reference to length and width of the object. So, "diagonal" is more like a floating angle with the condition that the fill needs to happen from one corner to another.Hope that helps, please?Thanks!Muthu Subramanian > ODF1.2. That would not need any private attribute. > If this is only about a restriction in the UI, I think it should be > discussed with the design-group. If the UI gives similar buttons as > MS, this will arouse expectations, which currently cannot be hold.
Text: Patch Set 3:> It is still confusing, what the purpose of this changes is. In the > current linear gradient implementation a gradient exists > independent of a shape. Therefore "diagonal" makes no sense.To get > the same behavior as the gradient in MS, where a "45鈹枒" linear > gradient is indeed diagonal for every rectangle, a new kind of > gradient is needed. This can be the svg:linearGradient as used inNo! 45 degrees is only for square - for rectangles the angle changes with reference to length and width of the object. So, "diagonal" is more like a floating angle with the condition that the fill needs to happen from one corner to another.Hope that helps, please?Thanks!Muthu Subramanian > ODF1.2. That would not need any private attribute. > If this is only about a restriction in the UI, I think it should be > discussed with the design-group. If the UI gives similar buttons as > MS, this will arouse expectations, which currently cannot be hold.

text: Patch Set 2:Hi Keigo, thanks for the updated patch.You can reply to any comments with the "Reply" button here in Gerrit.When you are asked to update your patch, please follow the instructions at https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/gerrit/SubmitPatch#Submitting_a_new_version . That will prevent creating a new patch, but create a new patch version instead.It would be great if you could write a bug report at bugs.documentfoundation.org describing the enhancement request. Then reference that bug in your first commit line (tdf#12345). Also the first commit line should be a short description of your change.Thanks for your work, looks like a nice improvement :)If you keep working on it, we might get it in before the 5.1 feature freeze (end of this week).

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1You will need to re-write a bit of history in order to remove your dependency on your previous commit. The following should work.    git rebase -i HEAD~2You will see something like the following in your favorite text editor    pick 13fdbbf tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr    pick 89645c3 tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptrchange the above to the following (the key part being "squash")    pick 13fdbbf tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr    squash 89645c3 tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptrSave and close, and then you will see something like the following in your favorite text editor.    # This is a combination of 2 commits.    # The first commit's message is:        tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr        Change-Id: I7141eea0fe7f72408da0d2a5ebe4a5e2893b6b7d        # This is the 2nd commit message:        tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr        Change-Id: Iff01d31792a13a14ea720c477417297af0c01642In your case you need to keep the 2nd commit, so convert the above to something like the following    tdf#93240: replace boost::ptr_container with std::unique_ptr        Change-Id: Iff01d31792a13a14ea720c477417297af0c01642Then resubmit to gerrit to remove your dependency on your previous commit.

text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, is this only a nice-to-have patch or it makes life really hard on the g-d side if this is not accepted?I'm asking as up to today, we could freely add as many new signals as we wanted to the widget without breaking ABI. However, with your patch, the list of signals become part of the ABI and we limit the number of new signals ever to be added.In other words it's a large cost to support these function pointers -- if possible, it would be really nice to avoid this. The larger the interface we promise to be stable, the harder to make future changes.
Text: Patch Set 1:Hmm, is this only a nice-to-have patch or it makes life really hard on the g-d side if this is not accepted?I'm asking as up to today, we could freely add as many new signals as we wanted to the widget without breaking ABI. However, with your patch, the list of signals become part of the ABI and we limit the number of new signals ever to be added.In other words it's a large cost to support these function pointers -- if possible, it would be really nice to avoid this. The larger the interface we promise to be stable, the harder to make future changes.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Let's -1 it before we have the answer, based on the comment :-) - hope that's fine.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Let's -1 it before we have the answer, based on the comment :-) - hope that's fine.

text: Patch Set 1:> Hmm, is this only a nice-to-have patch or it makes life really hard > on the g-d side if this is not accepted?This is only a nice-to-have patch. It doesn't make life hard on the g-d side. >  > I'm asking as up to today, we could freely add as many new signals > as we wanted to the widget without breaking ABI. However, with your > patch, the list of signals become part of the ABI and we limit the > number of new signals ever to be added. >  > In other words it's a large cost to support these function pointers > -- if possible, it would be really nice to avoid this. The larger > the interface we promise to be stable, the harder to make future > changes.As there are two ways to connect to signals -- First is to connect via g_signal_connect, and the other one would be via these function pointers. We can always use the former, but I think later approach is better and cleaner way of doing things. We can sort-of know the order when the handlers would be called. With function pointers, we can precisely control the point at which the default handlers will be emitted; we can chain up to the parent in our default handler. This is similar to as we have done in lok_doc_view_class_init function for the widget class overriding their key_press_event, key_release_event etc.See: https://developer.gnome.org/gobject/unstable/gobject-Signals.htmlWith g_signal_connect-ed handlers, we would be having no idea which one would be called first.Currently this is not a huge problem; I can always make it work with g_signal_connect in g-d, but it would be cleaner otherwise, and in the long run.Regarding the ABI, yes we can add up as many new signals as up to today, but that leaves us with only one option of connecting to signals i.e g_signal_connect. The `gpointer padding[8]` should be enough and help us to preclude the ABI change.
Text: Patch Set 1:> Hmm, is this only a nice-to-have patch or it makes life really hard > on the g-d side if this is not accepted?This is only a nice-to-have patch. It doesn't make life hard on the g-d side. >  > I'm asking as up to today, we could freely add as many new signals > as we wanted to the widget without breaking ABI. However, with your > patch, the list of signals become part of the ABI and we limit the > number of new signals ever to be added. >  > In other words it's a large cost to support these function pointers > -- if possible, it would be really nice to avoid this. The larger > the interface we promise to be stable, the harder to make future > changes.As there are two ways to connect to signals -- First is to connect via g_signal_connect, and the other one would be via these function pointers. We can always use the former, but I think later approach is better and cleaner way of doing things. We can sort-of know the order when the handlers would be called. With function pointers, we can precisely control the point at which the default handlers will be emitted; we can chain up to the parent in our default handler. This is similar to as we have done in lok_doc_view_class_init function for the widget class overriding their key_press_event, key_release_event etc.See: https://developer.gnome.org/gobject/unstable/gobject-Signals.htmlWith g_signal_connect-ed handlers, we would be having no idea which one would be called first.Currently this is not a huge problem; I can always make it work with g_signal_connect in g-d, but it would be cleaner otherwise, and in the long run.Regarding the ABI, yes we can add up as many new signals as up to today, but that leaves us with only one option of connecting to signals i.e g_signal_connect. The `gpointer padding[8]` should be enough and help us to preclude the ABI change.

text: Patch Set 5:abandoning this change commit.  It was requested by Samuel Mehrbrodt when reviewing the "identify/create a unicode character as you type" version of calc support for alt-x.  This patch could have been useful for someone wanting to easily create a table of unicode characters if they are already familiar with alt-x's functionality.  However, as mentioned in IRC the same could be accomplished with some formulas like unichar().
Text: Patch Set 5:abandoning this change commit.  It was requested by Samuel Mehrbrodt when reviewing the "identify/create a unicode character as you type" version of calc support for alt-x.  This patch could have been useful for someone wanting to easily create a table of unicode characters if they are already familiar with alt-x's functionality.  However, as mentioned in IRC the same could be accomplished with some formulas like unichar().

text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for the quick review Markus.GetString() / EnterData() just working with the "visual contents" should be fine for the intention of alt-X.  It wouldn't make much sense to "Unicode toggle" the last characters of a formula (there is a separate patch that handles Unicode Toggle AS YOU ARE ENTERING DATA in case you are trying to generate a single Unicode character).  Because I use the value, this allows someone to quickly generate a table of numbers using a formula, and then simply convert that table into the Unicode equivalent characters.  Yes, that would "lose" the formula.  I think that would be the expected result for anyone using this feature.
Text: Patch Set 2:Thanks for the quick review Markus.GetString() / EnterData() just working with the "visual contents" should be fine for the intention of alt-X. Because I use the value, this allows someone to quickly generate a table of numbers using a formula, and then simply convert that table into the Unicode equivalent characters.  Yes, that would "lose" the formula.  I think that would be the expected result for anyone using this feature.

text: Patch Set 1:Stephen: thanks for the suggestion of full-cell alt-x support.  This could be a really nice addition for people easily creating Unicode-related documentation tables.  Please be the official reviewer for this patch.Markus: I'd appreciate confirmation that my coding style/choice of functions is appropriate for calc.  I didn't find example code to copy related to acting on each cell of a multi-range selection.  Undo has been a reviewers concern of late.  Perhaps if it is simple to group all the changes into a single undo that would be a good addition.  Currently each cell can be individually ÔÇ£undoneÔÇØ, which is fine with me.  I don't think it is worth extra effort if the code is complicated, or if it involves a translation effort.  Finally, there are already alt-x unit-tests for Writer, so I didn't think it was necessary to add one for calc as well.  Since this isn't a bug fix, I'm sure that should be fine.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2AddGraphicObjectReference() is used for adding references of an existing graphic object. When there is no graphic object in the cache with the corresponding graphic ID, then no reason to add a reference (create a new cache entry instead).Next to that, AddGraphicObjectReference() fills its second parameter (rSubstitute) with the existing graphic object attributes, but if there is no such object this not make sense.Summary the code seems good to me as it was. No reason to use AddGraphicObjectReference() method here.
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2AddGraphicObjectReference() is used for adding references of an existing graphic object. When there is no graphic object in the cache with the corresponding graphic ID, then no reason to add a reference (create a new cache entry instead).Next to that, AddGraphicObjectReference() fills its second parameter (rSubstitute) with the existing graphic object attributes, but if there is no such object this not make sense.Summary the code seems good to me as it was. No reason to use AddGraphicObjectReference() method here.

text: Patch Set 1:This patch does not repair the add-in function, but removes the add-in function from the UI and redirects old uses (saved in ods documents) to Calc's own GCD() function, which is fully ODFF1.2 compliant.The add-in GCD() function is only called when opening xls files, AFAICS.
Text: Patch Set 1:This patch does not repair the add-in function, but removes the add-in function from the UI and redirects old uses (saved in ods documents) to Calc's own GCD() function, which is fully ODFF1.2 compliant.The add-in GCD() function is only called when opening xls files, AFAICS.

text: Patch Set 2:@tml:Yes, The GCD() function is Calc matches the Excel function, with two notes:-Excel has limits for the size of the arguments (must be less than 2E53), Calc doesn't and never had that limit (neither Calc's own, nor add-in function);-Excel GCD accepts only integer arguments in Excel versions prior to 2007 and accepts floating point arguments since Excel 2007, Calc accepts all numeric arguments (both Calc's own as add-in function).It is quite common for Calc functions to be more tolerant with respect to type and/or numeric value limits than their Excel counterparts.
Text: Patch Set 2:@tml:Yes, The GCD() function is Calc matches the Excel function, with two notes:-Excel has limits for the size of the arguments (must be less than 2E53), Calc doesn't and never had that limit (neither Calc's own, nor add-in function);-Excel GCD accepts only integer arguments in Excel versions prior to 2007 and accepts floating point arguments since Excel 2007, Calc accepts all numeric arguments (both Calc's own as add-in function).It is quite common for Calc functions to be more tolerant with respect to type and/or numeric value limits than their Excel counterparts.

text: Patch Set 2:LeMoyne Castle, your suggestion to do the same for LCM_ADD could be a good one; I can't any bug reports on LCM_ADD though and I want this one (GCD_ADD) pushed first before submitting similar patches.The precision limit is not changed with my patch. My comment only intended to note the difference between many Excel functions and their Calc equivalent.
Text: Patch Set 2:LeMoyne Castle, your suggestion to do the same for LCM_ADD could be a good one; I can't any bug reports on LCM_ADD though and I want this one (GCD_ADD) pushed first before submitting similar patches.The precision limit is not changed with my patch. text: Patch Set 6:Hi Markus Mohrhard,As per OOXML specs, TickLabelSkip values from axis properties can not be zero. Thats why I made this change. I think its not correct that we set some wrong value  initially and later change it some other value at some other code. If this value is not available in XML then it should not be '0'. Before submitting this patch I verified UT's and tested many chart files manually too from all formats.Regards.
Text: Patch Set 6:Hi Markus Mohrhard,As per OOXML specs, TickLabelSkip values from axis properties can not be zero. Thats why I made this change. I think its not correct that we set some wrong value  initially and later change it some other value at some other code. If this value is not available in XML then it should not be '0'. Before submitting this patch I verified UT's and tested many chart files manually too from all formats.Regards.

text: Patch Set 1:I hoped you were not right :-) But yes, if there are conflicting settings for different use cases, it could be the case that the client code needs to be adjusted - even with my approach. The chance for this is 2/6 (if I look at the current situation). But despite this matter of different views, for me there's another more interesting question:Did I understand right, that you suggested to also let the caller controll the "--accept=pipe,name=<sPipeName>;urp;" switch? Currently the pipe name is calculated within the bootstrap code and I really think that this is a detail should not be relevant for the caller. It's moving responsibility to a place where it should not be.
Text: Patch Set 1:I hoped you were not right :-) But yes, if there are conflicting settings for different use cases, it could be the case that the client code needs to be adjusted - even with my approach. The chance for this is 2/6 (if I look at the current situation). But despite this matter of different views, for me there's another more interesting question:Did I understand right, that you suggested to also let the caller controll the "--accept=pipe,name=<sPipeName>;urp;" switch? Currently the pipe name is calculated within the bootstrap code and I really think that this is a detail should not be relevant for the caller. It's moving responsibility to a place where it should not be.

text: Patch Set 1:Hi, Rishabh: congratulations and thanks a lot for sending your first patch to LibreOffice! We appreciate it.I have a few recommendations for your commit message:1. When reading a git log, it is useful to have a few details on the rationale behind a change: what problem are you solving, what approach youÔÇÖve followed to fix it, etc. Examples of good commit messages are in PoeditÔÇÖs repo, this is a random example: https://github.com/vslavik/poedit/commit/d6af8b16f386c92af4ad3107346990a57d92d4c5(Of course, you donÔÇÖt have to write novels out of commit messages, but most of the time a few explaining sentences are prefectly fine.)2. We have just (like a few days ago!) migrated to our own instance of Bugzilla (we used FreeDesktop.orgÔÇÖs one before), so thw way we refer to bugs has changed: instead of using the abbreviation ÔÇ£fdo#ÔÇØ we now use ÔÇ£tdf#ÔÇØ.Thanks again your your submission!

text: Patch Set 2:Michael Stahl wrote:> I get the impression that the OrdNum are *supposed* to be consecutive / an enumeration, and that there is some bug in whatever code inserts these objects if they don't end up with consecutive OrdNums.David Tardon wrote:> Yes, what Michael said is true.In that case, I'd be happy for that code to be fixed instead of applying this patch :) (It would fix the user-visible issue in the Base Form wizard, too.) Since AFAIK the Base Form wizard only uses our public API (which any user can use in their scripts), my best guess is that the fix must be in the code implementing these APIs, not in how the form wizard uses them.Maybe "just" a missing RecalcObjOrdNums() or SetObjOrdNumsDirty() call? Or some code that should heed bObjOrdNumsDirty but does not?
Text: Patch Set 2:Michael Stahl wrote:> I get the impression that the OrdNum are *supposed* to be consecutive / an enumeration, and that there is some bug in whatever code inserts these objects if they don't end up with consecutive OrdNums.David Tardon wrote:> Yes, what Michael said is true.In that case, I'd be happy for that code to be fixed instead of applying this patch :) (It would fix the user-visible issue in the Base Form wizard, too.) Since AFAIK the Base Form wizard only uses our public API (which any user can use in their scripts), my best guess is that the fix must be in the code implementing these APIs, not in how the form wizard uses them.Maybe "just" a missing RecalcObjOrdNums() or SetObjOrdNumsDirty() call? Or some code that should heed bObjOrdNumsDirty but does not?

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1Looks lovely to me - but - I'm a tad concerned; in terms of making this a pure re-factor I think we need to ensure that widgets are destroyed at the same time as they were ...void IIIMPStatusWindow::dispose()+{+    m_aStatusBtn.clear();So - all of these type of dispose impls should be:if (m_aStatus.get()) m_aStatus.dispose(); m_aStatusBtn.clear();-except- that we really ought to have a helper method here to avoid recursion so:void doDispose(Reference<Foo> &rRef){     Reference<Foo> aTmp(rRef);     rRef.clear(); // we should use some 'swap' method ideally ;-)     rRef.dispose();    // unref as goes out of scope}And of course - we really need to move the body of ~Window into Window::dispose - (like almost all of it - and guard it against double disposes too ;)With those two in place this starts to look really sexy.Many thanks !
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1Looks lovely to me - but - I'm a tad concerned; in terms of making this a pure re-factor I think we need to ensure that widgets are destroyed at the same time as they were ...void IIIMPStatusWindow::dispose()+{+    m_aStatusBtn.clear();So - all of these type of dispose impls should be:if (m_aStatus.get()) m_aStatus.dispose(); m_aStatusBtn.clear();-except- that we really ought to have a helper method here to avoid recursion so:void doDispose(Reference<Foo> &rRef){     Reference<Foo> aTmp(rRef);     rRef.clear(); // we should use some 'swap' method ideally ;-)     rRef.dispose();    // unref as goes out of scope}And of course - we really need to move the body of ~Window into Window::dispose - (like almost all of it - and guard it against double disposes too ;)With those two in place this starts to look really sexy.Many thanks !

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1RES_CNTNT does not refer to a continuous section break, but to the "content" of a Writer TextFrame. Given that a paragraph will never have that property, you're in practice adding a "|| 1" in the code. I guess that's not what you wanted to do. :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1RES_CNTNT does not refer to a continuous section break, but to the "content" of a Writer TextFrame. Given that a paragraph will never have that property, you're in practice adding a "|| 1" in the code. I guess that's not what you wanted to do. :-)

text: Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,As per our xChat discussion, a separate issue will be logged for the visual disparity which is highlighted during this fix./------------------------------------------------------------------------xChat discussion------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------/<Rajashri> vmiklos : Hi, This is regarding https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/9914/ Thanks for the review :). I checked xml difference between => RT file on master & RT file on my patch. I have one observation here : the sequence of writing the text and the table is not changed. Kindly have a look at the screen shot : http://wikisend.com/download/593286/XML_Diff.png . To my understanding there is no technical difference in the xml, though there is a visual disparity. This doesn't seem to be caused by this fix. I had a suggestion, if we can deal the issue for corruption in this patch and the visual disparity issue dedicatedly. Thanks a lot to share your opinion on the same :)<vmiklos> Rajashri: if you want to do that in a separate commit, fine. but then please comment on https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/9914/ what is the URL of the second change, so they can be merged together. obviously if a review is requrested, the last thing we want is to approve it when it is known that it introduces a regression.<Rajashri> vmiklos : ok.  I will put the comments on the link. I will also update the master and upload it[as it has been long time that it is not rebased with master]. Thanks :)/------------------------------------------------------------------------xChat discussion------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------/I have re-based and build the patch with latest master.Kindly have a look. Thanks :)

text: Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,- I have been looking into the issue for visual disparity.- In order to understand the root cause of the visual disparity, studied what is missing/added to the XML which is leading to the visual disparity.- Compared the round trip file on master with the original file.- It is observed that the round trip file on master and the original file is not the same. The order of exporting the text and the table is different even on master.- Next, compared the round trip file  on my fix and the round trip file on master.- The sequence of writing the text and the table is same in these round trip files[master RT and fix RT].- Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.- Next, studied the styles.xml [master round trip vs fix round trip], it is observed that there is absolutely no difference.- Request you to have look on the screen shot --- http://wikisend.com/download/730630/OriginalMasterFix.png- I discussed with the DEV team here, as per our understanding, we can go ahead to with this patch as there is no technical difference between master and the Fix RT.- There is no critical issue like data loss and the main issue is with the corruption which has been resolved.- Let me know If I can re-base the patch with latest master and we can go ahead to merge this issue to master. Thanks :)
Text: Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,- I have been looking into the issue for visual disparity.- In order to understand the root cause of the visual disparity, studied what is missing/added to the XML which is leading to the visual disparity.- Compared the round trip file on master with the original file.- It is observed that the round trip file on master and the original file is not the same. The order of exporting the text and the table is different even on master.- Next, compared the round trip file  on my fix and the round trip file on master.- The sequence of writing the text and the table is same in these round trip files[master RT and fix RT].- Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.- Next, studied the styles.xml [master round trip vs fix round trip], it is observed that there is absolutely no difference.- Request you to have look on the screen shot --- http://wikisend.com/download/730630/OriginalMasterFix.png- I discussed with the DEV team here, as per our understanding, we can go ahead to with this patch as there is no technical difference between master and the Fix RT.- There is no critical issue like data loss and the main issue is with the corruption which has been resolved.- Let me know If I can re-base the patch with latest master and we can go ahead to merge this issue to master. Thanks :)

text: Patch Set 5:> Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.Sorry, this is not what I see. http://people.freedesktop.org/~vmiklos/2014/gerrit9914/2014-08-01/ clearly shows the regression this patch would introduce. Fixing a bug by introducing an other is not ideal. :-)I know, it sometimes happens, but the purpose of code review is to try to detect such problems *before* the patch goes in. This is exactly that situation, so I hope you understand that you can't expect me to approve this patch as-is. Please improve the patch to not break the visual layout of the existing test document, then I'm happy to approve the patch.Thanks! :-)
Text: Patch Set 5:> Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.Sorry, this is not what I see. http://people.freedesktop.org/~vmiklos/2014/gerrit9914/2014-08-01/ clearly shows the regression this patch would introduce. Please improve the patch to not break the visual layout of the existing test document, then I'm happy to approve the patch.Thanks! :-)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Sorry, I think if the header/footer position goes wrong somewhere during import + export, then that should be fixed, instead of working that around with grab-bagging. Grab-bag is to be used for features we don't support.On the import side, writerfilter's SectionPropertyMap::PrepareHeaderFooterProperties() takes care of mapping the OOXML values to our document model. If that looks good, there is similar mapping on the export side as well. One of these should be fixed if you see here a problem.Could you please adjust your patch accordingly? Thanks! :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Sorry, I think if the header/footer position goes wrong somewhere during import + export, then that should be fixed, instead of working that around with grab-bagging. Grab-bag is to be used for features we don't support.On the import side, writerfilter's SectionPropertyMap::PrepareHeaderFooterProperties() takes care of mapping the OOXML values to our document model. If that looks good, there is similar mapping on the export side as well. One of these should be fixed if you see here a problem.Could you please adjust your patch accordingly? Thanks! :-)

text: Patch Set 1:michael@linux-tc27:/opt/libreoffice/master/icon-themes> find -name 'links.txt' | xargs grep ar/./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_bold.png cmd/lc_bold.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_bold.png cmd/sc_bold.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_italic.png cmd/sc_italic.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_italic.png cmd/lc_italic.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_underline.png cmd/lc_underline.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_underlinedouble.png cmd/sc_underlinedouble.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_underlinedouble.png cmd/lc_underlinedouble.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_underline.png cmd/sc_underline.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_undo.png cmd/fa/sc_undo.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_undo.png cmd/fa/lc_undo.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_redo.png cmd/fa/lc_redo.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_redo.png cmd/fa/sc_redo.pngThe themes are stacked - and as such so are the links. So we include links.txt from several themes.So in this case (I guess) this results in a sym-link pointing at a sym-link. Better debugging to the pack-images script appreciated etc. but ... it's the best we have as of now.So - you need to take into account the Tango stuff too - it seems like they use the same image anyhow (?) or we need to improve packimages; -or- if I'm confused [ the syntax is ln -s ordering FWIW ], then we need to think again =)
Text: Patch Set 1:michael@linux-tc27:/opt/libreoffice/master/icon-themes> find -name 'links.txt' | xargs grep ar/./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_bold.png cmd/lc_bold.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_bold.png cmd/sc_bold.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_italic.png cmd/sc_italic.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_italic.png cmd/lc_italic.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_underline.png cmd/lc_underline.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_underlinedouble.png cmd/sc_underlinedouble.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_underlinedouble.png cmd/lc_underlinedouble.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_underline.png cmd/sc_underline.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_undo.png cmd/fa/sc_undo.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_undo.png cmd/fa/lc_undo.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/lc_redo.png cmd/fa/lc_redo.png./tango/links.txt:cmd/ar/sc_redo.png cmd/fa/sc_redo.pngThe themes are stacked - and as such so are the links. So we include links.txt from several themes.So in this case (I guess) this results in a sym-link pointing at a sym-link. Better debugging to the pack-images script appreciated etc. but ... it's the best we have as of now.So - you need to take into account the Tango stuff too - it seems like they use the same image anyhow (?) or we need to improve packimages; -or- if I'm confused [ the syntax is ln -s ordering FWIW ], then we need to think again =)

text: Patch Set 1:@miklos : I think not negative or positive values implies being in background or foreground. It depends on there order.Specifications for z-index : Specifies the display order of overlapping shapes.A number that represents the stackingprecedence. Shapes with higher numbers are placed ontop of those with lower numbers.Even if you check XML of UT file. 'z-index' for both shapes is positive number.
Text: Patch Set 1:@miklos : I think not negative or positive values implies being in background or foreground. It depends on there order.Specifications for z-index : Specifies the display order of overlapping shapes.A number that represents the stackingprecedence. Shapes with higher numbers are placed ontop of those with lower numbers.Even if you check XML of UT file. 'z-index' for both shapes is positive number.

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1(1 comment)Next to the build breaker thing I have an idea how to make thisoptimization better. I just wonder why not store the primitive datain an array (as glTF stores it) instead of map with std::string key and an Attribute object can specify the start index and the length of it's primitive array (as in glTF). It saves the time of searching primitive in a map.It seems more effective to store primitive data like that and so we can use the same algorithm for simple models too (code would be more simple).

text: Patch Set 4:I agree with Michael - it's great to switch to shraed_ptr [ though I'd prefer a non-interlocked intrusive ptr operating on the same ref-count personally ;-]. But the pImpl pattern is quite valuable to us.In general we use the FooPtr rather than the PtrFoo convention for smart pointer types too - should be an easy sed on the patch though =)Thanks for doing this ! be great to have more std. ref-counting around the place.
Text: Patch Set 4:I agree with Michael - it's great to switch to shraed_ptr [ though I'd prefer a non-interlocked intrusive ptr operating on the same ref-count personally ;-]. But the pImpl pattern is quite valuable to us.In general we use the FooPtr rather than the PtrFoo convention for smart pointer types too - should be an easy sed on the patch though =)Thanks for doing this ! be great to have more std. ref-counting around the place.

text: Patch Set 1:So LibreOffice supposedly freezes strings in release branches, and yet translators have a big overhead, not everybody will have time to update strings to accommodate changes like this in our time-based release process, and we'll be left releasing LibreOffice point versions with regressions in translations. Is that what we want? (Rhetorical question).If some ESC member wants to invalidate my point with a stronger one, then it's fine I guess...

text: Patch Set 1:The advise to use size_t is correct for common code but there are a few differences when dealing with binary formats.It is much more important to pay attention to the size of the types and we had in the past problems with refactorings silently introducing bugs when they changed the type.I think it makes more sense to keep the sal_uInt8 and if really necessary (I'm not sure that more than potentially an assert is neccessary right now) add a check in one central place.The two places that use sal_uInt16 look fine to me as they are like that to make the casting explicit.So all in all I don't see a reason why we would need to change anything in that piece of code right now.
Text: Patch Set 1:The advise to use size_t is correct for common code but there are a few differences when dealing with binary formats.It is much more important to pay attention to the size of the types and we had in the past problems with refactorings silently introducing bugs when they changed the type.I think it makes more sense to keep the sal_uInt8 and if really necessary (I'm not sure that more than potentially an assert is neccessary right now) add a check in one central place.The two places that use sal_uInt16 look fine to me as they are like that to make the casting explicit.So all in all I don't see a reason why we would need to change anything in that piece of code right now.

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1As far as I see, our Python situation is like this:- on Windows, we use internal Python (3.x)- on Linux, we try to use system Python 3.x, if available- on Mac, we use system python (10.9 has 2.7, as far as I see)So yes, I would prefer requiring 2.6 (or even 2.7), writing Python code that is OK on 2.x and 3.x is next to impossible when 2.x is 2.5.Douglas, if you could please adjust configure.ac instead and leave the python scripts alone, that would be great. Thanks! :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1As far as I see, our Python situation is like this:- on Windows, we use internal Python (3.x)- on Linux, we try to use system Python 3.x, if available- on Mac, we use system python (10.9 has 2.7, as far as I see)So yes, I would prefer requiring 2.6 (or even 2.7), writing Python code that is OK on 2.x and 3.x is next to impossible when 2.x is 2.5.Douglas, if you could please adjust configure.ac instead and leave the python scripts alone, that would be great. Thanks! :-)

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hmm, what's more important: any reason you add this as a layout option? I think it would be cleaner to extend the document model, so that when the user creates a document from scratch in Writer, it's possible to enable this as well. The "RecordChanges" property of SwXTextDocument may be a good existing similar example (just here internally you can store a real bool, while RecordChanges is only a bool at an UNO level).That would be more clean an a new layout compat option. Does that make sense? :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Hmm, what's more important: any reason you add this as a layout option? I think it would be cleaner to extend the document model, so that when the user creates a document from scratch in Writer, it's possible to enable this as well. The "RecordChanges" property of SwXTextDocument may be a good existing similar example (just here internally you can store a real bool, while RecordChanges is only a bool at an UNO level).That would be more clean an a new layout compat option. Does that make sense? :-)

text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1So - I'd like to see a bug report referenced here; Reading the CFDictionary documentation - when we create the dictionary here:    mpStyleDict = CFDictionaryCreateMutable( NULL, nMaxDictSize,        &kCFTypeDictionaryKeyCallBacks, &kCFTypeDictionaryValueCallBacks );We create it with the kCFTypeDictionaryValueCallbacks - this guy should acquire and release any CFType derived type - the docs seem to suggest that the CTFont is thus derived:https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/Carbon/Reference/CTFontRef/Reference/reference.htmlSo - while the patch would work, it makes the code longer, bigger, and potentially leaky if that key is set again before destruction (surely) ? =)Anyhow - I'd love to know what this fixes =)Thanks though !
Text: Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1So - I'd like to see a bug report referenced here; Reading the CFDictionary documentation - when we create the dictionary here:    mpStyleDict = CFDictionaryCreateMutable( NULL, nMaxDictSize,        &kCFTypeDictionaryKeyCallBacks, &kCFTypeDictionaryValueCallBacks );We create it with the kCFTypeDictionaryValueCallbacks - this guy should acquire and release any CFType derived type - the docs seem to suggest that the CTFont is thus derived:https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/Carbon/Reference/CTFontRef/Reference/reference.htmlSo - while the patch would work, it makes the code longer, bigger, and potentially leaky if that key is set again before destruction (surely) ? =)Anyhow - I'd love to know what this fixes =)Thanks though !

text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I don't think we need a special release_assert in addition to normal assert.  All it takes is to not define NDEBUG for release builds.  Any existing assert calls that are inappropriately resource-intensive for release builds can be wrapped in OSL_DEBUG_LEVEL etc. (I assume there to be very little if any of those).(I also see no need for what is effectively a redefinition of a typical C runtime's assert macro definition; all C runtimes that are relevant for us should already offer at least the same quality with the stock assert macro.)(Also, introducing macros with short, easily clashing names into a base include file would not be good.)
Text: Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I don't think we need a special release_assert in addition to normal assert.  All it takes is to not define NDEBUG for release builds.  Any existing assert calls that are inappropriately resource-intensive for release builds can be wrapped in OSL_DEBUG_LEVEL etc. (I assume there to be very little if any of those).(I also see no need for what is effectively a redefinition of a typical C runtime's assert macro definition; all C runtimes that are relevant for us should already offer at least the same quality with the stock assert macro.)(Also, introducing macros with short, easily clashing names into a base include file would not be good.)

If you have some basic macro that triggers the new code paths, it may make sense to share it.

Having the positional tab properties attached to a \t placeholder sounds intuitive to me. Feel free to choose an other placeholder, of course.Regarding testing from basic: sure, you can create uno structs in basic, like:
Dim props(0) as new com.sun.star.beans.PropertyValueprops(0).Name = "mirrorIndents"props(0).Value = TrueoPara.ParaInteropGrabBag = props
Giving -1 just to reflect the "this is a work in progress" in the commit message.
Text:
Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedYou may do it differently, but so far all these special attributes (like anchored fly frame, etc) are attached to a placeholder character. Having the positional tab properties attached to a \t placeholder sounds intuitive to me. Feel free to choose an other placeholder, of course.Regarding testing from basic: sure, you can create uno structs in basic, like:
Dim props(0) as new com.sun.star.beans.PropertyValueprops(0).Name = "mirrorIndents"props(0).Value = TrueoPara.ParaInteropGrabBag = props
Giving -1 just to reflect the "this is a work in progress" in the commit message.

text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, approvedThis is awesome - I'd love something like this in master.IMHO osl::Condition is gratuitously dangerous; and I just wasted a chunk of time on it's inadequacies.Having said that - I'd love to redeem osl::Condition - to deprecate it's "set" and "reset" APIs, and add some proper: 'signal' 'broadcast' and 'wait (withMutex)' - or have some nice API that allows us to associate a mutex with the condition atomically.

text: Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,SDR object`s SetName() and GetName() functions are used for storing the shape's <id> value.In the case of a watermark object, this value is something like "PowerPlusWaterMarkObject93701316".Word uses the shape's ID to determine if this is a watemark object (it looks for the pattern "PowerPlusWaterMark" in the shape's ID).So, specifically with watermark objects - the shape's ID needs to be preserved.Thus the use of 'GetName' and 'SetName'.In addition, the 'o:spid' needs to be preserved, thus the addition of the new variable - 'msShapeOriginalId'.Hope this clarifies it.
Text: Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,SDR object`s SetName() and GetName() functions are used for storing the shape's <id> value.In the case of a watermark object, this value is something like "PowerPlusWaterMarkObject93701316".Word uses the shape's ID to determine if this is a watemark object (it looks for the pattern "PowerPlusWaterMark" in the shape's ID).So, specifically with watermark objects - the shape's ID needs to be preserved.Thus the use of 'GetName' and 'SetName'.In addition, the 'o:spid' needs to be preserved, thus the addition of the new variable - 'msShapeOriginalId'.Hope this clarifies it.

text: Patch Set 4:I think that this change isn't worth it because it mostly just adds churn to Git, makes it harder to integrate code from AOO, etc. There is plenty of precedent for functions that Enable() stuff to take a boolean parameter to disable. Anyone qualified enough to write C++ in LO won't find that function a real stumbling block. I think these sorts of mechanical changes should have a goal in mind, like moving towards a new string class or something. But just going around renaming every suboptimal function in the product could take years and still not really improve or simplify the product in the ways LibreOffice greatly needs.
Text: Patch Set 4:I think that this change isn't worth it because it mostly just adds churn to Git, makes it harder to integrate code from AOO, etc. There is plenty of precedent for functions that Enable() stuff to take a boolean parameter to disable. Anyone qualified enough to write C++ in LO won't find that function a real stumbling block. I think these sorts of mechanical changes should have a goal in mind, like moving towards a new string class or something. But just going around renaming every suboptimal function in the product could take years and still not really improve or simplify the product in the ways LibreOffice greatly needs.

text: Patch Set 1:I'm sorry/frustrated to hear of your displeasure with Python here.  I intentionally wrote this test in Python because I'd like more code/test coverage of the Python pathways.  Indeed, while writing this test, I encountered a number of issues that are at best gotchas.I also hope that having more Python examples, even if in the tests, is a starting place to give other noobs like myself more examples of the Python/LibO API (which I currently find difficult to grok, weak documentation notwithstanding).
Text: Patch Set 1:I'm sorry/frustrated to hear of your displeasure with Python here.  I intentionally wrote this test in Python because I'd like more code/test coverage of the Python pathways.  Indeed, while writing this test, I encountered a number of issues that are at best gotchas.I also hope that having more Python examples, even if in the tests, is a starting place to give other noobs like myself more examples of the Python/LibO API (which I currently find difficult to grok, weak documentation notwithstanding).

text: Patch Set 1:So, I dug this quite a bit:- not sure why frame is used (and why is frame's vml a special shape)- following patch makes the image a simple rect - and works - which is probably correct rather than using customshapes--- a/oox/source/export/preset-definitions-to-shape-types.pl+++ b/oox/source/export/preset-definitions-to-shape-types.pl@@ -151,7 +151,7 @@ my %shapes_ids = (     72 => 'irregularSeal2',     73 => 'lightningBolt',     74 => 'heart',-    75 => 'frame', # pictureFrame+    75 => 'pictureFrame',     76 => 'quadArrow',     77 => 'leftArrowCallout',     78 => 'rightArrowCallout',In short this probably requires more work/confirmation - so that it doesn't break existing documents/spec.Can you re-confirm, please? (Even references to spec would surely help)

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedThe invariant here (ImplEdgePointFilter::Input, ImplEdgePointFilter::LastPoint; tools/source/generic/poly.cxx) apparently is that mnLastOutside is only read if mbFirst is false.  And as mbFirst is initialized to true, and mnLastOutside written when mbFirst switches to false, all is fine as it is.If you really feel the need to initialize mnLastOutside in the ctor (to silence false warnings from static analyzers, say), a better way than to arbitrarily pick 0 for initialization is to go with value-initialization and probably a comment, see <http://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/libreoffice/2013-October/056756.html> "[Libreoffice-commits] bogus WaE: 'bValue' may be used uninitialized in this function."
Text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedThe invariant here (ImplEdgePointFilter::Input, ImplEdgePointFilter::LastPoint; tools/source/generic/poly.cxx) apparently is that mnLastOutside is only read if mbFirst is false.  And as mbFirst is initialized to true, and mnLastOutside written when mbFirst switches to false, all is fine as it is.If you really feel the need to initialize mnLastOutside in the ctor (to silence false warnings from static analyzers, say), a better way than to arbitrarily pick 0 for initialization is to go with value-initialization and probably a comment, see <http://lists.freedesktop.org/archives/libreoffice/2013-October/056756.html> "[Libreoffice-commits] bogus WaE: 'bValue' may be used uninitialized in this function."

text: Patch Set 2: Do not mergeosl::Thread::create does it in two steps for a reason---otherwise, the spawned thread would not be guaranteed to see its "own" osl::Thread::m_hThread set to the correct value.
Text: Patch Set 2: Do not mergeosl::Thread::create does it in two steps for a reason---otherwise, the spawned thread would not be guaranteed to see its "own" osl::Thread::m_hThread set to the correct value.

text: Patch Set 1:Use git commit -a --amend instead, that does not overwrite the hook output / existing commit comment.If you preserve the ChangeID, gerrit will automatically associate your push with the earlier patch.Your other explanation sounds plausible, it still might subtly change behaviour on what gets merged / picked up in the loop. Maybe adding a unit test excercising the three code paths would be good.
Text: Patch Set 1:Use git commit -a --amend instead, that does not overwrite the hook output / existing commit comment.If you preserve the ChangeID, gerrit will automatically associate your push with the earlier patch.Your other explanation sounds plausible, it still might subtly change behaviour on what gets merged / picked up in the loop. Maybe adding a unit test excercising the three code paths would be good.

text: Patch Set 1:Uhm, so yes, seeing the patch and reading the bug, I indeed didn't realize that the intent is the opposite. However, are we sure this would be a worthy effort?My understanding is that typically a random source file in $srcdir/$module/source/sub/foo.cxx has -I for:- $srcdir/include- $module/inc- (sometimes) $module/source/sub/incIf getting rid of the second is the target, and the benefit is one less compile switch at a cost of modifying tons of source files -- is that really good?
Text: Patch Set 1:Uhm, so yes, seeing the patch and reading the bug, I indeed didn't realize that the intent is the opposite. text: Patch Set 2:> 1) IMHO the negative year fix should go in independently of the time zone issue.negative year fix pushed to master> 2) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for> the start value and one for the end value?it appears to me to unnecessarily complicate things with 2 timezones inDateTimeRange; also it makes it possible to have Start timezoned and Endnon-timezoned which is rather meaningless; having just 1 timezone putsthe obligation on whoever constructs the thing to make it consistent> 3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.> What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for? in XMLSchema-2 a Date is really a 24-hour interval... so the timezonewould shift the interval on the "universal" UTC time-line.http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#date> For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,> one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining> 2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?that's a very good question.  apparently Time is a set of infinitely manypoints on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).so i think the DateTime you get by combining these is uniquely determined byintersecting the Date 24-hour interval with the Time set of points. > FWIW, SQL does not define a DATE WITH TIME ZONE type.> > 4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.> How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?> Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?yes> If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),> then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?> The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...> Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date> to apply them.there is no difference: both denote the same set of inifinitely many instants.> Alternative approach to your "isTimezoned": have a separate struct "DateTimeTZ"?yes... but that has the disadvantage that everything that currently handlesDateTime would need to be adapted to handle DateTimeTZ too.probably there are a lot of places that pass a DateTime from A to B withouteven looking at it (... and we _could_ have just added DateTime2 etc. structsinstead of changing them, but it was too much work).> Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".possibly, if times all were converted to UTC; but not if all times wereconverted to local time.> Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value> in memory? We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on> import/parse/read and store only UTC in memory.we could (as i already outlined in the other mail).  but clearly there arefile formats where time zones are not specified or optional, so it's impossibleto tell where these are exactly on the UTC timeline (see"3.2.7.4 Order relation on dateTime") _unless_ one makes some assumptionthat is not guaranteed by the standard such as all un-timezoned valuesbeing local time.> 1) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import  or export a date with timezone?dunno about OOXML, but ODF at least has numerous attributes of typedate.  it says nothing about time zones so by referencing the XMLSchema-2types they are allowed _everywhere_ a non-time-zoned date is allowed.examples are user-defined Document Properties and field created from them,variables, (non-text) table cells, database columns (presumably default value?).> 2) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import  or export a time (*not* datetime) with timezone?most of the same as "date" apparently.> 4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import>    or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as>    without timezone?good question... it is quite likely that there are many implementationsout there that do not support time zones at all, such as older LO versions,and for interop with these it would make some sense to preserve at least theun-timezoned values as-is (by writing the same string value that was read).for timezoned values this is probably less important since such consumerswon't handle it correctly in any case.> 5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import> or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve> it as without timezone?basically the same reasoning as 4) i.e. interop with non-zone-aware consumers.
Text: Patch Set 2:> 1) IMHO the negative year fix should go in independently of the time zone issue.negative year fix pushed to master> 2) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for> the start value and one for the end value?it appears to me to unnecessarily complicate things with 2 timezones inDateTimeRange; also it makes it possible to have Start timezoned and Endnon-timezoned which is rather meaningless; having just 1 timezone putsthe obligation on whoever constructs the thing to make it consistent> 3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.> What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for? in XMLSchema-2 a Date is really a 24-hour interval... so the timezonewould shift the interval on the "universal" UTC time-line.http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#date> For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,> one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining> 2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?that's a very good question.  apparently Time is a set of infinitely manypoints on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).so i think the DateTime you get by combining these is uniquely determined byintersecting the Date 24-hour interval with the Time set of points. > FWIW, SQL does not define a DATE WITH TIME ZONE type.> > 4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.> How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?> Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?yes> If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),> then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?> The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...> Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date> to apply them.there is no difference: both denote the same set of inifinitely many instants.> Alternative approach to your "isTimezoned": have a separate struct "DateTimeTZ"?yes... but that has the disadvantage that everything that currently handlesDateTime would need to be adapted to handle DateTimeTZ too.probably there are a lot of places that pass a DateTime from A to B withouteven looking at it (... and we _could_ have just added DateTime2 etc. structsinstead of changing them, but it was too much work).> Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".possibly, if times all were converted to UTC; but not if all times wereconverted to local time.> Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value> in memory? We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on> import/parse/read and store only UTC in memory.we could (as i already outlined in the other mail).  but clearly there arefile formats where time zones are not specified or optional, so it's impossibleto tell where these are exactly on the UTC timeline (see"3.2.7.4 Order relation on dateTime") _unless_ one makes some assumptionthat is not guaranteed by the standard such as all un-timezoned valuesbeing local time.> 1) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import  or export a date with timezone?dunno about OOXML, but ODF at least has numerous attributes of typedate.  it says nothing about time zones so by referencing the XMLSchema-2types they are allowed _everywhere_ a non-time-zoned date is allowed.examples are user-defined Document Properties and field created from them,variables, (non-text) table cells, database columns (presumably default value?).> 2) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import  or export a time (*not* datetime) with timezone?most of the same as "date" apparently.> 4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import>    or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as>    without timezone?good question... it is quite likely that there are many implementationsout there that do not support time zones at all, such as older LO versions,and for interop with these it would make some sense to preserve at least theun-timezoned values as-is (by writing the same string value that was read).for timezoned values this is probably less important since such consumerswon't handle it correctly in any case.> 5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import> or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve> it as without timezone?basically the same reasoning as 4) i.e. interop with non-zone-aware consumers.

text: Patch Set 2:> > 2) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for> > the start value and one for the end value?> > it appears to me to unnecessarily complicate things with 2 timezones in> DateTimeRange; also it makes it possible to have Start timezoned and End> non-timezoned which is rather meaningless; having just 1 timezone puts> the obligation on whoever constructs the thing to make it consistentOn the other hand, a DateTimeRange may start in one timezone and end inanother, for example flights.> > 3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.> > What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for?>  > in XMLSchema-2 a Date is really a 24-hour interval... so the timezone> would shift the interval on the "universal" UTC time-line.> > http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#dateOh My Goodness..> > For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,> > one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining> > 2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?> > that's a very good question.  apparently Time is a set of infinitely many> points on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.> > a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).> > so i think the DateTime you get by combining these is uniquely determined by> intersecting the Date 24-hour interval with the Time set of points.I'd think one converts 2003-05-17+05 to UTC and 23:00-06 to UTC andcombines them, then throws a dice whether to convert the result toUTC+05 or UTC-06 ...> > Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".> > possibly, if times all were converted to UTC; but not if all times were> converted to local time.Indeed, times without any timezone information are not even UTC, butexpected to be the same local time wherever viewed.> > Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value> > in memory? We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on> > import/parse/read and store only UTC in memory.> > we could (as i already outlined in the other mail).  but clearly there are> file formats where time zones are not specified or optional, so it's impossible> to tell where these are exactly on the UTC timeline (see> "3.2.7.4 Order relation on dateTime") _unless_ one makes some assumption> that is not guaranteed by the standard such as all un-timezoned values> being local time.Exactly. Per current usage, almost all datetime values we store areun-timezoned. Except for example the change tracking times in Calc thatare stored in UTC and converted to local time on read (or so it was..).> > 4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import> >    or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as> >    without timezone?> > good question... it is quite likely that there are many implementations> out there that do not support time zones at all, such as older LO versions,> and for interop with these it would make some sense to preserve at least the> un-timezoned values as-is (by writing the same string value that was read).So far all user-visible datetime document content is assumed to beun-timezoned. You do not want the document to change when loaded ina different timezone.> > 5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import> > or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve> > it as without timezone?> > basically the same reasoning as 4) i.e. interop with non-zone-aware consumers.And even zone-aware consumers, see above about document content.
Text: Patch Set 2:> > 2) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for> > the start value and one for the end value?> > it appears to me to unnecessarily complicate things with 2 timezones in> DateTimeRange; also it makes it possible to have Start timezoned and End> non-timezoned which is rather meaningless; having just 1 timezone puts> the obligation on whoever constructs the thing to make it consistentOn the other hand, a DateTimeRange may start in one timezone and end inanother, for example flights.> > 3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.> > What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for?>  > in XMLSchema-2 a Date is really a 24-hour interval... so the timezone> would shift the interval on the "universal" UTC time-line.> > http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#dateOh My Goodness..> > For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,> > one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining> > 2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?> > that's a very good question.  apparently Time is a set of infinitely many> points on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.> > a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).> > so i think the DateTime you get by combining these is uniquely determined by> intersecting the Date 24-hour interval with the Time set of points.I'd think one converts 2003-05-17+05 to UTC and 23:00-06 to UTC andcombines them, then throws a dice whether to convert the result toUTC+05 or UTC-06 ...> > Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".> > possibly, if times all were converted to UTC; but not if all times were> converted to local time.Indeed, times without any timezone information are not even UTC, butexpected to be the same local time wherever viewed.> > Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value> > in memory? We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on> > import/parse/read and store only UTC in memory.> > we could (as i already outlined in the other mail).  but clearly there are> file formats where time zones are not specified or optional, so it's impossible> to tell where these are exactly on the UTC timeline (see> "3.2.7.4 Order relation on dateTime") _unless_ one makes some assumption> that is not guaranteed by the standard such as all un-timezoned values> being local time.Exactly. Per current usage, almost all datetime values we store areun-timezoned. Except for example the change tracking times in Calc thatare stored in UTC and converted to local time on read (or so it was..).> > 4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import> >    or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as> >    without timezone?> > good question... it is quite likely that there are many implementations> out there that do not support time zones at all, such as older LO versions,> and for interop with these it would make some sense to preserve at least the> un-timezoned values as-is (by writing the same string value that was read).So far all user-visible datetime document content is assumed to beun-timezoned. You do not want the document to change when loaded ina different timezone.> > 5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import> > or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve> > it as without timezone?> > basically the same reasoning as 4) i.e. interop with non-zone-aware consumers.And even zone-aware consumers, see above about document content.

text: Patch Set 2:> Don't artificially introduce different values that denote the same. If we really> are to consider that a time is a value in timeline quotiented by 24h interval> (that is a representative of the equivalence class "all moments in the timeline> separated by 24h intervals), then we have no reason to allow (for the timezone> value) anything overlapping. Your code currently says everything has to be> between -840 and +840 inclusive. With this interpretation, we should make> one of the following choices:>  - timezone between -719 and +720>  - timezone between -720 and +719>  - timezone between 0 and 1439That simply doesn't match reality. Currently we have values from UTC-11(SST Samoa Standard Time) to UTC+14 (LINT Line Islands Time), they dooverlap, see http://www.timeanddate.com/time/map/Daylight saving time may change things, didn't check.So at least (!) values between -720 and +840 need to be supported,rather -840 to +840.

text: Patch Set 2:>> Don't artificially introduce different values that denote the same. If we really>> are to consider that a time is a value in timeline quotiented by 24h interval>> (that is a representative of the equivalence class "all moments in the timeline>> separated by 24h intervals), then we have no reason to allow (for the timezone>> value) anything overlapping. Your code currently says everything has to be>> between -840 and +840 inclusive. With this interpretation, we should make>> one of the following choices:>>  - timezone between -719 and +720>>  - timezone between -720 and +719>>  - timezone between 0 and 1439> That simply doesn't match reality. Currently we have values from UTC-11> (SST Samoa Standard Time) to UTC+14 (LINT Line Islands Time)> So at least (!) values between -720 and +840 need to be supported,> rather -840 to +840.You removed crucial context, namely, that the discussion was *time* values(and not date or datetime), *and* that the semantics of time had been definedas:>>>> Time is a set of infinitely many points on the "universal" UTC time-line, with 24 hour distance between them.>>>> a Time with timezone is simply offset that much (modulo 24:00).You see? An offset modulo 24:00, i.e. an offset modulo 1440 minutes. By this definition, it makes no sense to store offset values in a range bigger than 1440. I repeat: *by* *this* *definition*.Because the value 04:12:20+13 and the value 04:12:20-11 denote (again: *by* *this* *definition*) the same infinitely many points on the same time-line, it is bad data structure design to code them differently. Obviously, when parsing string, we can be *much* more liberal, and even accept e.g. "04:12:20+253". But when parsing "04:12:20+253" (253 = 10*24 + 13) , we wouldn't put "15180" (253 * 60) in the offset, right? So why allow 780?For DateTime, *obviously* '2009-05-04 04:12:20+13' and '2009-05-04 04:12:20-13' are not the same.If we take a *different* definition, for example one of: - a time with timezone is the time-part of a datetime with timezone - a time with timezone is a time in an unknown date;   the date can be "filled in" by providing a date without timezone or   date with the *same* timezonethen *yes*, going from UTC-14 to UTC+14 for times makes sense. But *not* with the definition that was in context.

Your code currently says everything has to be>> between -840 and +840 inclusive. An offset modulo 24:00, i.e. an offset modulo 1440 minutes. By this definition, it makes no sense to store offset values in a range bigger than 1440. I repeat: *by* *this* *definition*.Because the value 04:12:20+13 and the value 04:12:20-11 denote (again: *by* *this* *definition*) the same infinitely many points on the same time-line, it is bad data structure design to code them differently. Obviously, when parsing string, we can be *much* more liberal, and even accept e.g. "04:12:20+253". But when parsing "04:12:20+253" (253 = 10*24 + 13) , we wouldn't put "15180" (253 * 60) in the offset, right? So why allow 780?For DateTime, *obviously* '2009-05-04 04:12:20+13' and '2009-05-04 04:12:20-13' are not the same.If we take a *different* definition, for example one of: - a time with timezone is the time-part of a datetime with timezone - a time with timezone is a time in an unknown date;   the date can be "filled in" by providing a date without timezone or   date with the *same* timezonethen *yes*, going from UTC-14 to UTC+14 for times makes sense. But *not* with the definition that was in context.

text: Patch Set 1:You are very brave for stepping into this can of worms :-)In lcl_ConvertTimeZone() in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, you are attempting to convert times between timezones.I don't think this can be done safely without access to a DST (Daylight Savings Time) database.You need to know what DST offset was in operation at that specific source date, in order to be able to convert it to a UTC time, and then you need to know the DST offset for the destination date in order to correctly switch to it.See here for a good discussion:http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2532729/daylight-saving-time-and-timezone-best-practicesThe specific recommendation from that stackoverflow article that we should probably follow is that,if we are going to store a TZ offset with our Date/Time objects, we should also be storing a DST offset.Also, if we're going to create new commonly used types/structs, perhaps we can use shorter names, like DateTimeTZ?
Text: Patch Set 1:You are very brave for stepping into this can of worms :-)In lcl_ConvertTimeZone() in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, you are attempting to convert times between timezones.I don't think this can be done safely without access to a DST (Daylight Savings Time) database.You need to know what DST offset was in operation at that specific source date, in order to be able to convert it to a UTC time, and then you need to know the DST offset for the destination date in order to correctly switch to it.See here for a good discussion:http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2532729/daylight-saving-time-and-timezone-best-practicesThe specific recommendation from that stackoverflow article that we should probably follow is that,if we are going to store a TZ offset with our Date/Time objects, we should also be storing a DST offset.Also, if we're going to create new commonly used types/structs, perhaps we can use shorter names, like DateTimeTZ?

text: Patch Set 7: This need some tweaks before it is mergedIf it really crashes, this is great catch.My problem is that I do not see the crash and the new behavior is a bit confusing.Before the patch:When I select "Connect to an existing database" in the "Welcome to database wizard", the combo box mentions "JDBC" driver. When I press the "Next" button, it shows "Setup a connection to a JDBC database" => no crash; it really knows that JDBC database is selectedWith the patch:When I select "Connect to an existing database" in the "Welcome to database wizard", the combo box mentions "JDBC" driver but the "Next" button is disabled. If I were a normal user, I would be confused and would not know what to do. Of course, it helps to click on the combo box and select "JDBC" but it is not intuitive.I think about two better solutions:   + either make sure that GetSelectedType returns the      first available type by default (could be done in      constructor?)   + or modify the combo box to show "select type" instead      of JDBC by defaultDid I miss anything?Could you please have a lot at the alternative solution?In each case, you do great job with the wizards. Thanks for working on them.

text: Patch Set 7:Maybe the crash is in the case that java/jdbc is not installed/deactivated? Then, if the default is jdbc, it is not a valid choice, which could lead to a crash.If my guess is right, then indeed probably the best plan would be to:1) make sure a decent (and available in this particular run-time environsment!) default is *dynamically* selected2) make sure the *display* and the *backend* agree on the selection at all times (since the very beginning and not only after explicit choice).
Text: Patch Set 7:Maybe the crash is in the case that java/jdbc is not installed/deactivated? Then, if the default is jdbc, it is not a valid choice, which could lead to a crash.If my guess is right, then indeed probably the best plan would be to:1) make sure a decent (and available in this particular run-time environsment!) default is *dynamically* selected2) make sure the *display* and the *backend* agree on the selection at all times (since the very beginning and not only after explicit choice).

text: Patch Set 1: This need some tweaks before it is mergedI reproduced the problem, and I think it is better to ifdef out use of the  DocumentLockFile API in sfx2/source/doc/docfile.cxx in the non-desktop case. Probably HAVE_FEATURE_MULTIUSER_ENVIRONMENT from config_host/config_features.h is the thing to test here, and yes, the interaction between DESKTOP in BUILD_TYPE and the more fine-grained stuff in config_features.h is a work in progress and not necessarily fully logical at the moment.

(And a LO built with his patch does seem to work fine on OS X, I even tried one of the Python wizards.)"But you unconditionally remove the two urelib symlinks, and unconditionally change macosx-change-install-names.pl so that any newly built extensions will use @executable_path/../Frameworks instead (so will no longer work in old LO versions).I'm not sure how many extensions including native UNO components for Mac OS X are out there to test this with.
