(And a LO built with his patch does seem to work fine on OS X, I even tried one of the Python wizards.)"But you unconditionally remove the two urelib symlinks, and unconditionally change macosx-change-install-names.pl so that any newly built extensions will use @executable_path/../Frameworks instead (so will no longer work in old LO versions).I'm not sure how many extensions including native UNO components for Mac OS X are out there to test this with.

text: Patch Set 1:Anyway; sure, I can put in symlinks to make sure old binary extensions keep working.At least in a non-sandboxed build, my idea was that for a sandboxed build (if TDF or somebody at some stage wants to distribute LO through the Mac App Store) it might be good to use as few symlinks as possible. But whether Apple actually has any requirements that apps in the Mac App Store must have only the single executable program in the MacOS folder and all dylibs and frameworks in Frameworks, etc, I don't know.

text: Patch Set 1:"make classfile.cxx use the "_java_target_ver" variable to determine what class-file version number it should spit out":  But why change classfile.cxx at all?  Generating 1.5 .class files there in all cases works just fine, at least as long as we have no need to make use of more recent features in the generated .class files anyway.  (Originally, the generated .class files were even designed to work with then-relevant 1.4 while also making use of 1.5 features where available, though that needed to be changed later with <http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=26643fb59e0005f0bc83708b785d20d62d8e7411> "codemaker: write version 49 (1.5) class files.")
Text: Patch Set 1:"make classfile.cxx use the "_java_target_ver" variable to determine what class-file version number it should spit out":  But why change classfile.cxx at all?  Generating 1.5 .class files there in all cases works just fine, at least as long as we have no need to make use of more recent features in the generated .class files anyway.  (Originally, the generated .class files were even designed to work with then-relevant 1.4 while also making use of 1.5 features where available, though that needed to be changed later with <http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=26643fb59e0005f0bc83708b785d20d62d8e7411> "codemaker: write version 49 (1.5) class files.")

text: Patch Set 1:There seems to be some misunderstanding how Java versions work, and how Java is used in LO.IMNSO, this whole "configure the JVM version" thing has no purpose at all.LO, to the best of my knowledge, requires a minimum version of Java, but other than that has no Java-version-specific code at all.And Java is fully backwards-compatible. A newer VM can __always__ run .class files from an older VM.So allowing the user to change the version of .class files we produce has no benefit, and only adds unnecessary complexity.The only thing we should be doing at autogen time is confirming that the version of Java available to autogen meets our minimum version requirements.
Text: Patch Set 1:There seems to be some misunderstanding how Java versions work, and how Java is used in LO.IMNSO, this whole "configure the JVM version" thing has no purpose at all.LO, to the best of my knowledge, requires a minimum version of Java, but other than that has no Java-version-specific code at all.And Java is fully backwards-compatible. A newer VM can __always__ run .class files from an older VM.So allowing the user to change the version of .class files we produce has no benefit, and only adds unnecessary complexity.The only thing we should be doing at autogen time is confirming that the version of Java available to autogen meets our minimum version requirements.

text: Patch Set 1:@Noel: Well, in theory targeting a newer VM might give you optimizations and faster execution, shouldnt it? In practice, there likely is no relevant improvement in JVMs on that since 1.5.So in practice, having yet-another-configure-switch for this minor benefit is not entirely justified. At least not without some serious profiling.IMHO _that_ is the rationale to decide this on (and indeed -- as of now to respectfully reject it), as for the rest the decision will be on the packager anyway and is mostly none of the projects business (which should care about the source and not about the binaries).
Text: Patch Set 1:@Noel: Well, in theory targeting a newer VM might give you optimizations and faster execution, shouldnt it? In practice, there likely is no relevant improvement in JVMs on that since 1.5.So in practice, having yet-another-configure-switch for this minor benefit is not entirely justified. At least not without some serious profiling.IMHO _that_ is the rationale to decide this on (and indeed -- as of now to respectfully reject it), as for the rest the decision will be on the packager anyway and is mostly none of the projects business (which should care about the source and not about the binaries).

text: Patch Set 1:@David, that flag does NOT impact end-users.It perfectly possible to compile our LO code with "-source 1.5 -target 1.5", and for the customer to use Java version 1.6 or 1.7 or 1.8 language features to write their own extension or plugin code, just as long as they also install a newer JRE.So changing this flag has no useful purpose.
Text: Patch Set 1:@David, that flag does NOT impact end-users.It perfectly possible to compile our LO code with "-source 1.5 -target 1.5", and for the customer to use Java version 1.6 or 1.7 or 1.8 language features to write their own extension or plugin code, just as long as they also install a newer JRE.So changing this flag has no useful purpose.

text: Patch Set 1:Yeah, and this commit is a *huge* merge, so I couldn't easily figure out *which* line of the commit message refers to that change :-(Probably the best is to break into this method and see under which conditions it is called, and what the different codepaths do ("tbreak linenumber\njump linenumber" is a nice gdb recipe). From reading the code, I "see" that it is called when the report is in "insert mode" as opposed to "selection mode". My guess is that "select mode" is when (in the reports control toolbar) "Select" (the arrow mouse pointer) is selected and "insert mode" is when some kind of control is selected (e.g. "Label field", "text box", ..., "Vertical line", etc). But the mystery is: what is a "custom shape" that needs this special treatment? Which of the reports controls (and/or other options available in "Insert" menu) are a "custom shape" and which are not?
Text: Patch Set 1:Yeah, and this commit is a *huge* merge, so I couldn't easily figure out *which* line of the commit message refers to that change :-(Probably the best is to break into this method and see under which conditions it is called, and what the different codepaths do ("tbreak linenumber\njump linenumber" is a nice gdb recipe). From reading the code, I "see" that it is called when the report is in "insert mode" as opposed to "selection mode". My guess is that "select mode" is when (in the reports control toolbar) "Select" (the arrow mouse pointer) is selected and "insert mode" is when some kind of control is selected (e.g. "Label field", "text box", ..., "Vertical line", etc). But the mystery is: what is a "custom shape" that needs this special treatment? Which of the reports controls (and/or other options available in "Insert" menu) are a "custom shape" and which are not?

text: Patch Set 1:thanks for looking at this.Before submitting the patch, I double checked that it showed  File > Template > Save as template                  > Editas shown in the menubar.xml files, and where edit performed .uno:TemplateManager, i.e. for me the new TemplateManager.Now I tested with a clean user profile and indeed I only see the menu   > Save as template.Thus something happened while creating this patch.Steps I did1. first I had .uno:TemplateManager in the xml files.   Gave the result as you reported.2. Then I changed the xml file to OpenTemplate   Gave the File-Open dialogue.3. Then - after looking at a way to start the   templatemanager as launched by File > New > Template    (the dynamic AddDirect ), and not able to find that ..   I again used .uno:TemplateManager (not having sharp   in mind that I already tried before).   Then after top-level make && make dev-install  the menu    Template > Template Manager appeared.4. Changed the GenericCommands.xcu to show Edit in stead of   Template Manager   That worked5. Then saw that in sfxcommands.h this definition was   lacking ..   CMD_SID_TEMPLATE_MANAGER   ".uno:TemplateManager"   and added it.6. After top-level make && make dev-install the menu was   still OK so I prepared the patch.But now, with a fresh user profile, it is not OK.Apparently I did something that triggered a change in the behaviour that ended in the user profile?A diff of the two registrymodification.xcu files gives a lot output (tried some more e.g. Personas in the build too) so that is not easy for me to get though.Of course, it might well be that I've overseen something.Any hints?(I can do something prolly Thursday evening / Friday afternoon).
Text: Patch Set 1:thanks for looking at this.Before submitting the patch, I double checked that it showed  File > Template > Save as template                  > Editas shown in the menubar.xml files, and where edit performed .uno:TemplateManager, i.e. for me the new TemplateManager.Now I tested with a clean user profile and indeed I only see the menu   > Save as template.Thus something happened while creating this patch.Steps I did1. first I had .uno:TemplateManager in the xml files.   Gave the result as you reported.2. Then I changed the xml file to OpenTemplate   Gave the File-Open dialogue.3. Then - after looking at a way to start the   templatemanager as launched by File > New > Template    (the dynamic AddDirect ), and not able to find that ..   I again used .uno:TemplateManager (not having sharp   in mind that I already tried before).   Then after top-level make && make dev-install  the menu    Template > Template Manager appeared.4. Changed the GenericCommands.xcu to show Edit in stead of   Template Manager   That worked5. Then saw that in sfxcommands.h this definition was   lacking ..   CMD_SID_TEMPLATE_MANAGER   ".uno:TemplateManager"   and added it.6. After top-level make && make dev-install the menu was   still OK so I prepared the patch.But now, with a fresh user profile, it is not OK.Apparently I did something that triggered a change in the behaviour that ended in the user profile?A diff of the two registrymodification.xcu files gives a lot output (tried some more e.g. Personas in the build too) so that is not easy for me to get though.Of course, it might well be that I've overseen something.Any hints?(I can do something prolly Thursday evening / Friday afternoon).

text: Patch Set 1:Thank you for the patch! :-)In order to be able to test that - can you please add a reference to the bug in bugzilla, or describe the scenario this commit is fixing in the commit message?Regarding the code itself - it would be great to be more careful about indentation; eg. the block checking for "vnd.sun.star.GraphicObject:" should be at the same level as Size aOriginalSize; - but this is of course only nitpicking.  Also, OUString has a startsWith() method these days, might be easier to use than indexOf().Either way - I am glad to see improvements in DrawingML, I am looking forward to the updates here.
Text: Patch Set 1:Thank you for the patch! :-)In order to be able to test that - can you please add a reference to the bug in bugzilla, or describe the scenario this commit is fixing in the commit message?Regarding the code itself - it would be great to be more careful about indentation; eg. the block checking for "vnd.sun.star.GraphicObject:" should be at the same level as Size aOriginalSize; - but this is of course only nitpicking.  Also, OUString has a startsWith() method these days, might be easier to use than indexOf().Either way - I am glad to see improvements in DrawingML, I am looking forward to the updates here.

text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveWell, according to http://nabble.documentfoundation.org/PATCH-Remove-linked-git-functionality-td4024277.htmlthere might still be some troubles with it. I would prefer to remove this for three reasons:- our ./configure is already way too complex- this is not really a build configuration thing (but some DSCM topic) and doesnt even belong in ./configure- having this in ./configure suggests it to be a 'supported scenario'. Given the limited amount of users for this, I dont think we should do this.IMHO, such DSCM tooling should better be done over there in the dev-tools repo.
Text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveWell, according to http://nabble.documentfoundation.org/PATCH-Remove-linked-git-functionality-td4024277.htmlthere might still be some troubles with it. I would prefer to remove this for three reasons:- our ./configure is already way too complex- this is not really a build configuration thing (but some DSCM topic) and doesnt even belong in ./configure- having this in ./configure suggests it to be a 'supported scenario'. Given the limited amount of users for this, I dont think we should do this.IMHO, such DSCM tooling should better be done over there in the dev-tools repo.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisFor one, the change to OfficeIPCThread::EnableOfficeIPCThread would introduce a wait even in the successful PIPEMODE_CONNECTED case.For another, <http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=0157f0b1ba364f7f9af2aacd1be9fbb5ddec2b4d> "Related: fdo#38606 keep style dialog open when apply is clicked" gets rid of the connection-to-self entirely, and I assume that it solves any deadlocks (whatever they would look like exactly) that this patch wants to address.
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisFor one, the change to OfficeIPCThread::EnableOfficeIPCThread would introduce a wait even in the successful PIPEMODE_CONNECTED case.For another, <http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=0157f0b1ba364f7f9af2aacd1be9fbb5ddec2b4d> "Related: fdo#38606 keep style dialog open when apply is clicked" gets rid of the connection-to-self entirely, and I assume that it solves any deadlocks (whatever they would look like exactly) that this patch wants to address.

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHi Joren,Removing various rtl:: prefixes is not a goal. Especially, Reference can be uno::Reference and rtl::Reference, so turning rtl::Reference to Reference actually makes the code harder to understand, so please don't do that.Second, it's planned that all rtl::O<some string class> is changed to their non-prefixed versions automatically:http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.documentfoundation.libreoffice.devel/41219So possibly it's better to not work on this at all, there are much more interesting easy hacks out there. :-)In other words, I guess the best would be to just abandon this change.Thanks,Miklos
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHi Joren,Removing various rtl:: prefixes is not a goal. Especially, Reference can be uno::Reference and rtl::Reference, so turning rtl::Reference to Reference actually makes the code harder to understand, so please don't do that.Second, it's planned that all rtl::O<some string class> is changed to their non-prefixed versions automatically:http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.documentfoundation.libreoffice.devel/41219So possibly it's better to not work on this at all, there are much more interesting easy hacks out there. :-)In other words, I guess the best would be to just abandon this change.Thanks,Miklos

text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisIn general, such ifdeffed-out code should not be removed just blindly, but one should check for how long it has been ifdeffed out, and whether there is any comment indicating it is soemthing a still active developer intends to get back to, etc.In this case, I think this code might well be useful, if only we had somebody who was working on this part of the code and was interested in this self-check functionality.(Personally I have no idea what a "job" or "job URL" is.)There is a comment in joburl.cxx that says: "It's used for internal purposes only and never a part of a legal product. Use it for testing and debug only!" so I think it's clear that the intent is that you #define ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK only in your own work copy while working on this code, and that such a #define never gets into version control.Now, another question is then whether we have anybody who knows what this code does, and is interested in debugging and developing it. Would it be better to test DBG_UTIL instead of ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK, to at least make sure the code still compiles (in a --enable-dbgutil build) and doesn't break at run-time?SOme discussion on the mailing list needed IMHO.
Text: Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisIn general, such ifdeffed-out code should not be removed just blindly, but one should check for how long it has been ifdeffed out, and whether there is any comment indicating it is soemthing a still active developer intends to get back to, etc.In this case, I think this code might well be useful, if only we had somebody who was working on this part of the code and was interested in this self-check functionality.(Personally I have no idea what a "job" or "job URL" is.)There is a comment in joburl.cxx that says: "It's used for internal purposes only and never a part of a legal product. Use it for testing and debug only!" so I think it's clear that the intent is that you #define ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK only in your own work copy while working on this code, and that such a #define never gets into version control.Now, another question is then whether we have anybody who knows what this code does, and is interested in debugging and developing it. Would it be better to test DBG_UTIL instead of ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK, to at least make sure the code still compiles (in a --enable-dbgutil build) and doesn't break at run-time?SOme discussion on the mailing list needed IMHO.

text: Patch Set 2: AbandonedRenaming configure options has quite a large impact on the costs of all distributors - in general it's nice to keep this to whatever minimum is achievable. In this case it is a new option. So far the packagekit code only enables font installation (quite possible) - but in due course it will do much more: clipart, help etc. so I'd prefer to keep it as --enable-packagekit.Thanks ! :-)
Text: Patch Set 2: AbandonedRenaming configure options has quite a large impact on the costs of all distributors - in general it's nice to keep this to whatever minimum is achievable. In this case it is a new option. So far the packagekit code only enables font installation (quite possible) - but in due course it will do much more: clipart, help etc. so I'd prefer to keep it as --enable-packagekit.Thanks ! :-)

text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveThis is the right direction to go I think :-) linking to VCL directly would allow us to remove quite a bit of cruft in there and simplify things a lot.However - I think we need first to stop this being an 'extension' which (in theory at least) can't link to VCL and turn it into a 'component' that can. Pragmatically they're basically the same thing - both UNO components ;-) if you follow the 'mork' example - that is a component you'll see where we need to change the gnumake files, scp2 etc. to effect that change.Does that help ? and thanks so much for digging into the presenter console :-)
Text: Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveThis is the right direction to go I think :-) linking to VCL directly would allow us to remove quite a bit of cruft in there and simplify things a lot.However - I think we need first to stop this being an 'extension' which (in theory at least) can't link to VCL and turn it into a 'component' that can. Pragmatically they're basically the same thing - both UNO components ;-) if you follow the 'mork' example - that is a component you'll see where we need to change the gnumake files, scp2 etc. to effect that change.Does that help ? and thanks so much for digging into the presenter console :-)

text: Patch Set 1:>This is the right direction to go I think :-) linking to VCL directly would allow us to remove quite a bit of cruft in there and simplify things a lot.Also as far as I know it is the only way to check for RTL interfaces.>However - I think we need first to stop this being an 'extension' which (in theory at least) can't link to VCL and turn it into a 'component' that can. Pragmatically they're basically the same thing - both UNO components ;-) if you follow the 'mork' example - that is a component you'll see where we need to change the gnumake files, scp2 etc. to effect that change.Understandable, but I think I will leave that for you experts to decide :)>Does that help ? and thanks so much for digging into the presenter console :-)Yes it does.We have more in the pipeline, but they all depend on the vcl.

text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitHeh - as rene says - the solver is not a solver - it is a legacy of our build system. All the final binaries that are built are moved into the solver, all the inter-module headers we compile against are located in the solver.The hope is that completing the gnumake work will kill the solver - and we can use the workdir/ instead - which has a friendlier name - and (hopefully) run the app directly out of that.Any chance you could re-work the README's and submit a new patch ? I just pushed a few cleanups for your previous commit that would be worth looking over.Thanks !
Text: Patch Set 1: Do not submitHeh - as rene says - the solver is not a solver - it is a legacy of our build system. All the final binaries that are built are moved into the solver, all the inter-module headers we compile against are located in the solver.The hope is that completing the gnumake work will kill the solver - and we can use the workdir/ instead - which has a friendlier name - and (hopefully) run the app directly out of that.Any chance you could re-work the README's and submit a new patch ? I just pushed a few cleanups for your previous commit that would be worth looking over.Thanks !

text: Patch Set 2:I am still not convinced this is a good idea. We are mixing two kinds of dependencies there: build time and run time (i.e., a library does not need any resource file for build). There are other kinds of resources that are needed at run time, e.g., dlopened libraries. IMHO the only approach that would really work is to postpone running the tests _after_ the build phase of a module.
Text: Patch Set 2:I am still not convinced this is a good idea. We are mixing two kinds of dependencies there: build time and run time (i.e., a library does not need any resource file for build). There are other kinds of resources that are needed at run time, e.g., dlopened libraries. IMHO the only approach that would really work is to postpone running the tests _after_ the build phase of a module.

text: Patch Set 1:So, I've done a little more research..Note that this was not meant as cleanup.I've done make sw.all or maybe it was also make writerfilter.all and this patch helped me to build that way.Original motivation is failing tinderbox because of missing deps."you are assuming that for every resource target there is a library with the same name; this is not actually the case; for example see extensions/AllLangResTarget_upd.mk"I wish it to be true, it is in most cases but sometimes it's not. But what bad can happen ? There will be new target, which will be, hopefully, ignored."furthermore i don't actually know whether even if there _were_ a library for every resource target, this approach would work, because i don't know how these resource files are loaded: are they always loaded from exactly one library, or can it happen that there are 2 libraries that load the same resource file?"Sure, it's not perfect. There are also resource files opened with the same library. So there still are going to be missing dependencies.I think I did not remove any dep and created a few more, some of them useful and some of them not but they should not hurt.So, I think the patch improves the situation.Would be better to rename resources and use it correctly but...Thanks
Text: Patch Set 1:So, I've done a little more research..Note that this was not meant as cleanup.I've done make sw.all or maybe it was also make writerfilter.all and this patch helped me to build that way.Original motivation is failing tinderbox because of missing deps."you are assuming that for every resource target there is a library with the same name; this is not actually the case; for example see extensions/AllLangResTarget_upd.mk"I wish it to be true, it is in most cases but sometimes it's not. But what bad can happen ? There will be new target, which will be, hopefully, ignored."furthermore i don't actually know whether even if there _were_ a library for every resource target, this approach would work, because i don't know how these resource files are loaded: are they always loaded from exactly one library, or can it happen that there are 2 libraries that load the same resource file?"Sure, it's not perfect. There are also resource files opened with the same library. So there still are going to be missing dependencies.I think I did not remove any dep and created a few more, some of them useful and some of them not but they should not hurt.So, I think the patch improves the situation.Would be better to rename resources and use it correctly but...Thanks

text: Patch Set 1:As an after-thought, I think that the 2 loops are actually needed since the first one updates rMin and rMax (passed by reference to lcl_CheckMinMax), which then are used (read only) in the second loop.Maybe adding some comments could be useful to clarify the behaviour of the original code.
